articleText:
"ORIGINAL CORRESPONDENCE.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,-Observing a, paragraph in yesterday's issuo of the Fice Press, in reference to tho non-publi- cation of the manifest of the Boomerang, I beg in reply to state- the following facts.- Mr. Pugh called at my office about nine o'clock, requesting a copy of tlio manifest ; as I was employed at the time in making an alphabetical rtbstract from it, of the consignees and cargo, preparatory t'o com- mencing to discharge at six o'clock tho following morning, I informed-him that I. conld not just then spare the book, but that ho could havo it or

my abstract when completed, which would be in ' less than an hour. Tho manifest was at his service all the previous afternoon, had it been applied for, and my abstract was equally so after

ten o'clock.

1 am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

GEO. li. WEBB,

Agent for the A.S.N. Co.

t South Brisbane, 27th August.

GOVERNMENT SALAMES.

Toiliit Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,-With your parmission I should liko to draw the attonthn of your readers to a subject which to mo seams likely to infiujnno the future wolfaro of tho colony moro than at first might be imagined, vi¿. tho Salaries of Government Oriicers.

Many mombers of tho Legislative Assembly, impressed it may bo willi a desisa to cultivate ecoinJSpy, and perhaps also thinking that retrench- ment nuci dave- caro in spending tho people's monoy may bo popuísr subjects for the hustings, have cut away right and loft, nnd have in some instances, one might almost imagine, endeavoured to see upon how little mon may be able to live. Tînt is such policy wiso ? Are not mon placed in temptation hy suoli treatment? If a man hold a rem?cos)ble position, ought he not to bo paid ac- cording to iii? ro5ppnsib¡lfiy ? is it not a notori- ous fact that in KuSSÜV the government officers aro ill paid! And what is the consequence? Throughout ovory dopartmeni Mlwy »»'J cor- ruption prevail. Aro the United Stales St' Anie riôa, M here salaries are small, l'reo from these oviis i í heliovo not. And are we to oxpeot that iiiim.r1 naturi is «\8ttw '» Australia than in ltus =r ",."A . Ö «iirgiy TO may oxpoot liko onuses

s a or Amanea? . *' ?«\w; ¿, " ft3 «ill produce liko iosults in iu.. ..'- ^ ftl.p any other. And if such rotilly bo tna >. ' ?

those logislators consulting best for tim Intorosts , of tho colony who are trying to cut down the j salaries, so that, whilst they study economy in theory, the government ollicers aro obliged lo tlo so In practico? Much isjiaid at the prosont time about education, but whatever men's opinions may be about (he best systoro, nil must ndmit that it

is absolutely noces'aryfor the welfare of a people, that integrity and honour should" be upheld. And far be it'from me to say that at present there does not exist from the highest to the lowest in the government employment a destitution of that which is mean and dishonorable, but woe be to those «ho would grind down tiiair~somnts~«o ascto mi.ke tho temptation to fdiihouo<ty great. As a nation, the English rank the highest in the world for integrity; muy her colonies bo at lonst'equ.il to her ! But in order to make them so, oa^ht not the govern mont to seek out honorable ino", ami then oiiirht not tho people to pay them liborally? If tho object of members bo to get the most work dono for tho least piy, would it not ba botter to advertise for tenders for government appointments, stiting that'the lowest tender would be nooepted? No

doubt some would bo found who would mulei take -. any duty whatever, from (.hat of Governor-Gene- ' nÜdowrin^l(1s. bit whether all who might offer theimelfeä" ifould be'deshable nortons even far any office ia doubtful.. It would not be difficult «ven in a moro mcicaiitilo point of yian-, to shew that a pooplo a'o benefittod by pijing well those whon^thoy employ, but enough has been written to bring the subject before the public. If able writers are induced to enter more fully into tho subject perhaps good may result from these few observations of one who not wishing to bring for- ward solf, but the subject of government salaries, will sign himself, Mr. Editor,

Yours, <fcc.,

Brisbane, January 7,1857.

articleText:
LOCAL IMPROVEMENT. p,

Tb the Editor of fie Moreton Bay Courier.

Bi»,-Dr. Woolley having, in 'his e\celiont lecture at the opening of tho School of Arts in Maitland on tho 9th tilt., clearly and eloquently shown tho great benefits that would accrue to society from the establishment of Indies colleges throughout the colony, permit mo to draw atten- tion to the urgent necessity that exists for insti- tutions for tho education and training of women to fit them for wives and companions for the men of this generation, and to be the mothers of tho next, who will rise np after us.

While the colonists havo been scrupulously careful regarding tbo qualities and the pedigree of the quadrupeds they importod, they and their .gents seem to havo utterly disregarded tho biped». Let any ono take up tho Government Gatette and examino the report of the Emigra- tion Board, they will find that in about two thirds of the arrivais throughout tho year tho .ingle women are marked "bad solection," "un- suitable for the colony," " not Rtiitablo for sor- tants." Now as theie are all, or nearly nil, married in a comparatively short poriod after their arrival, does it not as a matter of course follow that many a man makes a " bad selection" for a wife, and finds a most unsuitable mothor for his children. Hence marriages ate no silken tics, hut iron bonds eating to their heart's core ; and by ita weight crushing the hopes and onergies of both : and while tho result is sometimes desertion or uQfiiitbfulness, it is oftoner the oause of the husband becoming broken-spirited, taking to brutal Indulgence, and ending in besotted drun- kenness ; and the wife becoming cross, dirty, and sluttish, and sometimes following the example of her husband. Where tho atmosphere of home (wah as it ii) is thus impregnated with tho ole faesU of discord and vice, the children will grow tip the Wfltima of rudo and selfish passions, and with cross and gnarled tempers they will go ont

into tho world,

But, Sir, lot it »ot be thought that I blame the waiker sex for all the social misarios that rankle and fester in society. Very for from it, But it is regarding that sox that I am writing. It is because their influence is far greater at home and among their children than a husband's influence. It is because by tbair example they aro a law to their families, where their authority is of no uso unless they can inspire rospaot by their aminblo neu and" usefulness. If the trao is not good, it is «estrary to general experience to expect tbo

fruit should be good.

Now as ve Vß provided with female omigrants of the classes aboye described, supplying us with the mother» of the nott inhabitants of theso lands, is it not of the utmost importance that we proyide some mode of improvement for them, and fornl »omo such institution as will enable tbo young worni».'1 who may bo willing to devote somo of hor earning» Í* improving her knowlodgo of either the kitchen or the wardrobe in tho first Îilace j then .to the improving her tastes and her ntelleot j and afterwards to fcljfl acquiring of ns many accomplishments as she possibly can. It is not the fault of those girls not io lt»ovy vhat

they nei'er had any opportunity of learning, and, i > although in »onie families thoy are taught just I as much a» will »nebia them to aot their part In I ' one department, yejb $e knowledge they acquire 11 tf wb.lt cofleerw ft biWytvW, bflweyw hujnbfy {? ,

very limited indeed. No doubt the servant that boiled the sandglass with the eggs for breakfast the other day, will be aware not to make the sarna mistake in futuro, and that the other girl who tried to bake the cabbage with the joint for the dinner will also know better for timo to como. Yet these, and other not much less ludicrous mis- takes, shows the necessity for some means being provided to teach the requirements of domestic life, and whore can they loam it among us at present? Many a servant girl would instt act her- self if she could obtain that instruction in a suit- able way by paying for it. And as we have young men's societies, and associations for their improve- ment, why should young women be neglected, on whom the happiness of young men so much depend Î

It has been sometimes a question with debating societies " should women get the same education that men get?'' I would say they should have tho samo education that men should get. Their influença on our happiness is really incalculable, when we consider that many of those young^ creatures wero brought up in institutions, and never knew what a home of any kind requires. Many of thom have no relation in this distant land. Of how mnoh importance then is it to have some means of instruction within their reach, so that they may have some further ideas of the duties of life than merely to catch a husband and get a legal claim to his protection and support?

It does not matter by what name the required institutions should be known, suffice it to say they aie wanted. Not only would servants pay for their own instruction, but parents wonld also send their daughters to such seminaries, and many a joung man would send the future partner of his life to acquire some of the many lessons which she as a rational being will find necessary in her social capacity, or for the advancement of her intellectual and moral natuie. So that she may be to him a "crown of glory," and not, as too often in these days, only prove " rottenness

to his bones."

1 must refer to this subject again, with your permission, meantime

I remain,

Your obedient servant,

Brisbane, 14th May.

TOIL.

After what has passed, Mr. Holt must be moro than ordinarily obtuse to require any such in-

formation.

Tho meeting on Monday night, convened by and for his "supportera only," is cortninly not one that would bo accepted as a test of public opinion by a representativo really Milicitous to obtaiu the opinions of his constituents. The frank diaoussion and impartial estimate of Mr. Holt'« qualifications cannot be expected. And it is not to be supposed for one minuto that tho electors generally will consent thtt such a ono-sided mooting shall aii nouiico its decision as tho expression of a puhlio

political opinion.

Lot tho friends of Mr. Holt call a publia mooting of tho " whole" of the oleotors, when I have no doubt that tho " honest" bur>it of indignation will bo snllioiunt to sutisty Mr. Holt that ho has mU talcon his vocation, and induct) bim at once to retire into private Ufo.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient sorTnnt,_

25th Juno, 1857.

vmm SIMPLE.

articleText:
INSOLVENT LAWS.

To the Editor j)f the Moreton Bau Courier.

Sir,-When 1 pointed out in the columns of your vnlnable paper tim absurdity of " An Observer's" letter on tho Insolvent Lvws, I certainly did not expect thai it would devolve on mo again to refer to the subject ; as I thought your correspondent would not havo hardihood enough again to appear in print. In this I have been mistaken. Ho complains in hut week's issue, of having had vio- lent and contemptuous auim-idvcrtions cast upon his "open" and "courteous" (?) endeavours to traduce the characters of his fellow townsmen, (for ho insists that tho cases of insolvency, which ho cited, wero not, as 1 hoped, supposititious) ; and further accuses mo of having perverted his state- ments. This latter oharge I -.imply deny-I might retort bx-saying-thai, he has pervaHoct-ilio» "Queen's Eni/lis7i; or, what is indeed the fact,

that his periods lack that somowhat essential fea- ture in composition- coherence. But, as no good purpose can bo answeiod by reciimination, I forbear. Lot us dwell lightly, Air. Editor, on tho

faults and follies of our fellow-creatures. -

It is unnecessary for me to point out the inex- pediency, to uso no stronger"term, of adopting1 .'An Observer's" suggestion, advocating the cul-

tivation of "a little busincss-liko fioedom of

speech among tho merchants of Brisbane" re- specting tradesmens' affairs ; as this " business- like freedom of speech" can moan nothing loss than the parading a man's business nil ovor town. A pinn which, although in particular eases ifc might be attended with beneficial result1!, would, if generally carried out, bo totally subversive of trndo.

The only conclusion I can arrive at, fiom tho peiyisal of-'! An-Observer's" letter, is that he said one thing and mount another (a fault of not very ttnfrcquont occurrence) ; and he is angry with me for reminding bim of the faot. 1 will not pursuo the subject further, haying neither leisure nor in clinatioii to prolong the present discussion.

I um, Sir,

Your most obediont servant.

FO ÜRPEXCE-IN-THE - POUND.

Brisbane, January 2, 1837.

TriE SuT'iiTJ.AKrisiiiRi* Cli:aranci:s.-At this poriod a great majority of the inhabitants wero tennnts at will, anti thorelbro liable to ejectment on getting regular notice ; there were, however, a foiv who lind still existing tacks (although somo had beon wheedled or frightened into sun enduring them), and these woro, of course, unmolested until tlio expiration of their fneks ; they vveio then turned out uko the rest; but (ho great body of tenantry'wcre-in-the formor condition. Atean timo tho factors, Inking advantage of the broken spirit and the prostrate sinlo of the people trembling nt their words or even looks, betook themsehes to a new scheme to facilitate their in« tondeil proceedings, and this was to induce every householder to sign a bond or paper containing a promise of removal ; and alternate threats mid promises wero used to induce thom to do so. Tho promises wore never realised, but notwithstanding the people's compliance, the threats woro put in exécution. In about a month after tlio'factors lind obtained this promise of removal, and thirteen days beforo tho Alay term tho woilc of dovastolion was begun. They commenced by selling firo to t'io houses of the small tonnnts in «tonsile dis, ti icts-parts of the parishes of Euri-, Tiogart, Golspie, and the whole parish of Kildonan. 1 waa an eyc-witnos3 of the scene. This calamity carno on tho people quite unexpectedly. Strong -parties for each district, furnished vith faggots and other combustibles, rushed on tho dwellings of this de- voted people, mid immediately commenced setting fire to thom, proceeding in their noik with tho grontest rapidity till abontjlirep hundred houaea were iriJl.un<-at-^Hvo'eo'''5"tcriiaüon and confusion woró"óxtremo; little or no time «as given for re- moval of persons or property-the peoplo stiiving to "remove the sick* und tho helpless-nett, strug- gling lo Biivo the most valuable of their efibrts. Tho cries of the womon and ohildron-the roaring of the affrighted cattle, hunted nt the same tima by tho yelling dogs of tho shephoids, amid tlio smoko niul firo-altogether presented a scene that completely bafflos deaoiiption ; it required to bo seen to bo' believed. A dense cloud of smoke en- veloped tho wholo country by day, and even ex- tended far on the sea ; at night, an aufully grand but tcrrifio scene prosentod itsolf-all tho houses in an extensive'district in ¡laines at oneo. I my- self ascended a height about olevon o'clock in tho evening, and counted two hundred and fifty bias- ing houses, many of the owners of whioh were my relations, and all of whom I personally know ; bu'fc whoso prosent condition, whether in or out ol' tho (lames, I could not tell. The conflagration lasted six days, till the wbolo of the dwellings were re duoeil to ashes or 'smoking ruins. During ono of these days a boat lost her way in tlio dense smoke ns she approached the shore ;*bnt at night she wai enabled to reach n Inndiug place by tlio light of the flames,-Donald M'Leod, on the Sutherlaml

shire Clcaraitees,

Tiifi'Soiti for Vises.-Tim vino is very ac- commodating in respect to the soil provided for it, ripening its fruit in almost any kind of soil stirred 1o tho depth of two feet, thoroughly drained, and in a olimiito similar to any part of Australia, whore troos aro found to grow, and they aro or havo beon. Plant your vines, as a matter of coufiio, if pos-iiblo, on tho sunny and shellored side of n ¡lill sheltered by higher bills. tilo purposes of- extortion - when squatter, j

articleText:
*¡bthi Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIB,-The" manner in which you allude, in your Leading Article of the 23rd ultimo, to my Parlia- mentary career, as one of the mombors for tho Stanley Boroughs, demands my acknowledgments. I had recoived many letters, from personal friends and others, expressing warm approval of my con- duct-to thom, as well as to yourself, I feel grate- ful. Par be it from me to despise public opinion, when expressed with due consideration, through its legitimate organs, and it certainly affords mo satisfaction to know, that my earnest endeavours to perform my duty, in conjunction with tho other members for the Northern Oistriotsnre appreciat- ed by those whoso approbation is valuable. This justice being done to me, I cannot deny my o,vn fallibility. In point of talent you might have chosen many mon who weie far superior to me, although none could havo surpassed me in integrity of purpose and zeal for your interest. I regret that I was unable to do more, but I cm truly say, that I have dono my best. It is highly gratifying to rae to [earn, that the measures which I had the honor to introduce, were considered by you as of " a highly beneficial tendency, and that I have appeared ansious to redeem roy pledges at any

rate."

Rut, Sir, I must regret that you still speak of my vote on the buundary question as n faux pas on my part. If I have " not yet put myself right with my constituents" on that point, it may be attributed to my wane of ability, hut I lind thought that the Rev. Dr. Lang, whose intelli- gent zeal in the cause of Separation is universally acknowledged, had effectually performed thnt service for me. The reverend gentleman, in a lecture delivered in Bii&b.me on the 11th April last, as reported in your journal, thus speaks of

tho resolutions for which I voted :

" I examined thom very carefully, and found Hist thero was really nothing in them that could give tho slightest uneasiness to an inhabitant of yonr'district." Before recording my vote for those resolutions, I also, like Dr. Lang, "examined them very carefully," and the conclusion I carne to was tho very samo as that arrived at by the Doctor, when ho told his audience in Brisbane that " there was nothing in fact, that you could not embody in a potition of your own."

I would invite yon, Sir, and your readers, to a calm re-perusal of the resolutions, which I append hereto, and to consider whether the impression made upon the mind3 of Dr. Lang and mysolf was not natural and reisonablo. I freely acknowledge, that in the course of the debate, ronny of tho members wandered far from the question before the House. Tho language of some of these gen- tlemen was such as to provoko strong feelings of indignation on tho part of tha inhabitants of your ' district. Instead of confining themselves to the

true question-namely, whether the inhabitants of New England and the Claronce.should bo con- sulted as to the government under which they preforred to live-the gentlemen alluded to, con- temptuously scouted tho idoa of Separation alto- gether, and used to Moreton Bay and its inhabit- ants, language which from personal experience, 1 knew to bo that of unjust disparagement.

It was thus very natural, that in tho indigna- tion of the moment, readers in your district should not clearly distinguish between those obnoxious speechos, and the simple equity of tho principles laid down in the resolutions. It is quite possible that many of my constituents may, for a time, have identified me with those violent Phillipies, in whioh my voioo bad no part, and with which my mind had no sympathy. But I erahraco this opportunity of recording my utter repudiation of the unwarrantable language used by some of thoso speakers. Indignant ns 1 was to bear it, I was precluded from replying by having apokon in tho early part of the debate. I therelore endeavored, na I invariably do on such occasions, to dispol from my mind all extraneous matter, and to con- fine my attention to tho simple question before the Hjuso. Now that you and my constituents seem disposed lo do me justice, I will candidly confess this : that, though I saw nothing in the resolutions, but what was strictly consistent with my own good faith, as well as with justice and equity, jet, if anything could have induced me to vo\o against them, it would have been the in oxomablo language of some of the speeches in their favor. But the resolutions alono will be considered by her Majesty« Government, and, as Dr. Lang veryjustty observes, they contain "nothing that you'could not embody in a petition of your own." The speoches will certainly nover bo read by the Queen's Ministers, and havo only Berved to raiso feelings of .indignation, which, although well merited, aro deeply to bo deplored.

With referenco to the Requisition that was ad- dressed to me, 1 did at first intend to havo des- troyed it ; but, on reflection, there appeared some force in tho argument, that it was to some extent a public documont, and ought not to be so dis- posed of. I was further indnood to preservo it after an examination of tho signatures, whereby I perceived that unjustifiable means had been re- sorted to for the purpose of increasing the num- ber of names appended.

I have the documont now in my possosnion, and can produce it if necessary in proof of the accu- racy of what I now assert. Eighty-eight of the names are not on the olectoral list, several names ure signed twice, many names follow oaeh otbor in the same handwriting. This has been defended by the assertion that the names were written with tne authority of the owners : but the circumstance appeared auspicious, and more especially from what I am now about to mention. A gentleman very long resident in your district, addressed me, on a matter of private business, and I roplied by expressing my surpriso that bo should do so, as his name was appended to a document, which ac- cused me of no less a orimo than that of breaking my pledge. To this letter I received an answer, which is now in my possession, and from which I make the following extract :- ,

I havo not expressed my opinion on your vote, by sign- ing, or authorising any person to sign, such document for me, nor did I know that suoli a ouo existed, uatll I Baw your answer to the same in the publio prints. I have not read the Requisition from tho Elector;) to you. I do not know of any other person bearing tho uamo of * * * « * iu these distrtotfl but myself.

Now the gentleman who wrote thus to me, is well known and highly respected in your district. His name is by no moans a common ono, and cer- tainly I nover hoard of another person of tho same name. The christian and surnames are written in full on tho Requisition, and tho writing by no means corresponds with this gentleman's usual signature, but is exactly similar to that of several other names on the paper. I would ask you, therefore, Sir, whether I was not fully justified in looking upon this document with suspicion ? I may montion that another gentleman, a resident of Brisbane, whoso name appoars on tho paper, personally domed to mo, with every appearance of earnestness, that ho over signed, or sanctioned the signing : and ho gave as his reason, that ho had himself hoard mo at South Brisbane, guard my approbation of tho proposed boundary, by the * proviso, that it should be with the consent of the

inhabitants.

I am snro thataftor the candid treatment which

I havo recently mot with in your columns, you will deem these circunistancos quite sufficient to justify »very diflbront tone, in my reilly from that which I should adopt, in answering a proper Requisition, from a majority of my constituents, who might think meare inefficient guardian of their interests. To me, who had certainly no motive for my public conduct, but the dosiro todisoharge conscientiously my duty to the country, tho attacks that were levelled at me wore most irrititiug. I was well aware that amongst thoso who joined and stimu- lated the outory, there ware very many whose op- position to mo was grounded upon political causes totally unconnected with your distriot, and upon party feeling, in which I*quite agree with .you, the people of Moreton Bay, need tako but little interest. If tim political' party, by dislodging me from my seat, could have secured ono moro voto to themselves, they would havo oared littlo.and perhapi havo rejoiced, if tho member were as litter an anti-soparationist as any of the many now in

their ranks.

I have already expressed my opinion, which all authorities show to be atriotly"constitutional, that no honorable man would submit to the dogrado, tion of accepting a seat in tho House us a Dolo galo-he can only sit asa Representativo. If from inability or difference of opinion bo coases to roprcisoiit Vis constituents, ho is bound in honor to resign, and if I beliovod that on any important question, there existed a substantial différence of opinion botween my constituents and mysolf, I would tender my resignation forthwith. " But I know of no Buch difference, nor havo on any occa- sion beon at iääiie with my constituents on any iubjcot savo that upon whioh I trust all mis- understanding ia now for over dwpolkd,

There is another oSroamstaneo to which t will tako this opportunity of adverting. During tho excitement of a contested eleotion, many things may occur which calmer reflection will disapprove, nnd I do not think it dishonors a man to express regret for anything whioh upon mature reflection

he conti wish undone.

Tho inhabitants of Brisbane mid Tpswioh will ? hear me witness that at the time of rav election,

the contest was not very calmly conducted, hut Í havo no hesitation in oxprossmg my disapproval now, of some language tint fell from myself, with ! reference to two electors, who were most active in

their opposition to my return.

¡ It would have been much better, and I should

feel greater s.itufaction now, if I had not mndo the remarks alluded to ; for, after all, every elector had a porfei't right to think and vote as he pleased, and my kind supporters were so nnmornus, that I mi;rlit vyoll have dispensed with irritating allusions | to otheia.

I trust that neither you nor your readers will misconstrue my motives in thus re-opening a sub- ject which appeared to have been almost closed. I would not have done so, but for the gratifying and complimentary terms in whioh you have al- luded to tbe services which, nt least, I have at- torn nted to render. I have been desirous of show- ing that, if indeed I have not set myself right with my constituents, it has not been for want of an anxious wish to do so. My present lettor may subject me to further misrepresentation in some quarters ; but you must be well awaro, that the retention of a sent in the Assembly, can be no part of my object in thus addressing you, for I trust that you will very soon havo a Legislature of your own, with members selected from your own body, to aid, on tbo spot, in developing the splendid resources of your district.

Treated in a fair and candid spirit, I am anxious to respond in a similar tone, and to show that I never intended either to deceive my constituents, or to treat them with disrespect. I do not value the opinion of any man who is incapiblo of doing jii3tico to my motives ; but I respect and honor him, who, dispelling prejudice from his mind, can equally understand a firm resistance to an net of injustice, and a candid ooncossion to an impartial

tribunal.

Trusting that you will favor me by inserting this in your journal,

I remain, Sir,

Your most obedient servant,

THOMAS HOLT.

Camden Villa, 1st Juno, 1857.

Mr. Hargrave moved, pursuant to amended Re-

solutions :

(f). That this House has learnt with regrot, that it is tho intention of the'Imperial Govern- ment to fix the southern boundary of the proposed now Colony of Moreton Bay ntn line "south of the 30th parallel of south latitude."

(2.) That as the interests of the various Dis- tricts proposed to be inoluded in tho now Colony are not identical, this House is of opinion that, in defining the futuro boundary line of the Colony of Moreton, Bay, it is tho duty of the Imperial Go- vernment to consult the wishes of the several Disttiota proposed to bo included in that Colony.

(3.) That while this House fully recognizes the propriety of tho Imperial Government, in accord- ance with the presumed wish of the mojority of the inhabitants of Moreton Bay aud Darling Downs, erecting those Districts into a separate Colony, it submits that on the same principle, it will bo unjust to the inhabitants of New England and the Clarence River to include those Districts in such Colony, if they aro averse to being so

included.

(4.) That in the opinion of this Honso the in- terests and comm'oroial counoxion of New England and the Clarence River are now, and will continue to be, so completely identified with the Colony of New South Wales, and distinct from those of the Districts of Moreton Bay and Darling D.wns, that, if the question whether the first-mentioned Districts shall bo included in the now Colony be referred to the inhabitants of thosu Districts, a very largo majority will be found to be opposed to their being so included ; and, in support of such opinion, that House refers to the Petition, signed by 1551 Inhabitants of New England and Clarence Rjver, praying for the establishment of an Assize* Court nt Armidale, in which Petition they assert that " they do not desire to bo included' in any section of tho Northern Diatriots whioh may bo separated from the present Colony of

New South Wales."

(5.) That this Houso requests that the Imperial Government will defer the final settlement of the southern boundary line .of the new Colony, until the opinion of the Inhabitants of the Districts of New England and the Clarence River, is ascer- tained upon the subject.

(6.) That the foregoing Resolutions be embodied in an address to the Governor-General, with a ro. quest that His Excellency will be pleased to transmit thom to Her Majesty's Secretary of State for the Colonies at the earliest opportunity.

=s====-=s t ItELIGIOUS ENDOWMENTS. p

To the Editor of the Moreton Day Courier.

Sm,-Not only have the State-supported ohurclies in these colonies identified themselves with in- fidels, and angmentcd their numbers from the ranks, of the Atheist and the Deist, for which they thus obtain so muoh per head, being paid from the Treasury according to their "numerical strength," lint they teach to the ontiro community a lesson of practical infidelity in thus proclaiming that they want the crutches of tho State to support the church of the Redeemer-that they do not believe in the providential government of the world-that they must have as little interposition of a Divine power as possible. Like the Epicu- reans, they admit the existence of the gods, but deny that they interfere in the concerns of the Universe. They cannot disoern tho "finger of dod" unless it point to the Treasury. Their re- ligion is therefore earthly ; it presents tho humi- liating aspeot of a deep sleep, from which it is more than even possible that the national awaken- ing may be such as is not at prosent anticipated. Jf any one will take the trouble to read the ap pandix to the report of the Select Committee of tlio Legislative Council of New South Wales, in 1854, appointed to take ovidonce on the condition and prospects of the colonial clergy, they will find from tho atatemonts thero mado, one clergyman of the Church of England saying, " No clergyman would think of coining hore if they knew the cir- cumstances of the case, and few would stop hero if they could got back." And through tho whole examination the poverty and starvation of tho teachers of religion shows such a state of disorder in financial matters that ought not to continue for one week, The government expecting the peoplo to co-oporato with them in paying the ministors of religion which they havo not done, nor nover will do while government supports various sects, each sect considering that thore must bo plenty of funds at tho disposal of a go- vernment who pays so many churches in ono place, and the feeling is, while they pay-I'll

give them nothing.

Now, Sir, Christian churohes would nothosHato one day to throw thomsolvos on tho support of the community, who is well ablo to support them. The people in towns and the country, except ' where tho population is very scattered, could sup-

port, and would support their religion, ¡f once cleared of its present unhallowed connexion. They will never support Christianity and Co. ; such can have no hold on tho respect and ' affections of {J.'ose of the peoplo who generally stir in snob mattera; they asteom their religion, theroforo they will not .disgrace It hy countenancing its present degradation. Nay, moro, religion will never, in those colonies, flourish until tho peoplo are porfeotly aware that the pastors have no con, ? nexion with the State; for governments and ' churohmen have before notv leagued together to

cloud tho minds of tlio peoplo, and defraud thom of their rights i and wo aro a very strange com- munity collaoted in those colonies, and our govern- ment is not above suspicion at present. Now if any struggle arose, tho churches would have to stand by the government, right or wrong, (js their very existence depends on tlio Treasury, while suoh a proceeding would be of no avail in supporting a tottering power, but only hasten its downfall ; and of oourse, as one of its institutions, fall with it. Bettor be separated in timo, for most assured- ly out of the presont raol-administration and mis- appropriation in the State, and from the any, or every, or no religious sysfem provaldht among State-supported ohurchoe, Christianity appears as worth no exertion on tho part of its adherents, and is left to the countenance and support ol' the ruling powers ; while the community, whoso bo- soms will never warm towards such caricature . churches, aro left' to wealth-worship on the ono " hand, or oxhaüsting their limo and moans on

those orgies or dob'auolieries which bespeak our national prosperity only a curse. It is the» clout +.0 any'discernor that Christianity with us has api^oaohod us near as possible to what Paganism was'in ."Mioiont Rome, Gibbon snys, " Tlio modes of worship whioh prevailed in the Roman world . ' were all considered by th» peoplo ns equally fi ec, by

the philosopher as equally ia'io, and by tho magis- trate as equally useful." And any one who will read the reported spooohes mido against Hi'. Jones' amendment on the additional grant of £14,000 for religious instruction coin« tvooks ago, will at once see that our greutcst, anil wisest, and fejwt men, or those who ñ wo have in tho jiliuu when) OUf greatest, and wisest, and Iwst njen

pujht to Wf tSlff LMWty tllP WUB vipff* of our

Christianity that tho subjects of tho Roman em- pire did of * Paganism beforo tim light of tho gos- pel dawned on them. And wc warn our miers", that in such a community as ours, whero religion is mainly stippoi ted hy tho proceeds of the na- tion's debaucheries an unclean spiiis is fast gain- ing strensrth, which ns snon ns it arisos, will speak b'aspliomies against the God of heaven, and hy no moans will raqicct the powers of the earth. It would bo wiie then to strengthen that which romains of a purer faith which refuses to be iiri gatcd from the revenue drawn from that Lethean stream of liquid fiery poison rando to flow so con- veniently to every door. It surrounds us at our

birth, flows freely at our baptism, wo grow familiar . with it ns we advance ; when wo require excite-

ment, and whon wo require solnce, it is ready at i hand ; on it runs, stained with tho blood of our murdered neighbors, and with tho reeking gove of our suicides; loaded with the throes nnd pangs of many a broken heart, and tho curses of many an illused mother ; ringing with tho ravings uf tho maniac und tim wrongs of the widow and tho or- phan, whilo tho voice of genius has beon drowned by it, and it has extinguished some of our bright- est lights. And from this source, Sir, the ro vonuo is drawn to supply religion for us. State paid ministen of religion, nro your hands clean in this matter, or aro tho sounds I lirive mentioned ascending with your prayers, and the blood of the victims mingling with your sacrifices ? Seo you

to it.

I am. Sir, your most obedient servant,

ORMLY.

Ipsnich, a/ith Feb., 1857.

TAXATION.

I Tot fit Editor of fit Moreton Bay Courier.

Mn EDITOR,- ! hate oppression and injustice, and | ii* much a-- possible íiNuld wish to exert my in- j fluenc* in maintaining what was upright, but j »ometimes through ignorance n person may com- | mit an injury and advocate a bad cuu-e tv hen he I is renllv anxious to benefit and uphold what he ' b-lien s to be good. Mich lieing the CJSC, would I you kindly give me annie ¡iilormatimi tin Mi»- ^nb- I jeßt of taxation. I simieliiiie.s hear eonter-arinn-t i nb.iut taxes, but I conlet-s I do not always under- ' stand tho opinions expressed.

If T ml-tako nut, Mimi'»eera to think tim' sheep, cattle, and horse«, are the only thing« in this co- lony which ought to be taxed.

tint is there, Mr. Editor, any natural affinity between sheep and taxes Î If j ou looked a bullock :n the face, would yon «t once «ay, as it were by instinct, that ought to be taxed ?* AUs, I am iii the dark, I cannot understand why sheep, cattle, and horses, i-hould have so great, uti honor puid to them as to be considered alone deserving of taxa- tion. If sheep, why not pigs? or cocks and bens, turkeys, fen., <fec. ? If two brothers have each £2000, and one invests his money in live stock, and goes into the bush, and the other enters into some* business in a town, is it right and ju-t thtit the former should bo tsxeil for the »uppoi t of go- vernment, but that tlie latter should be fice from taxation ? My impression is, that men ought, if possible, to be taxed necoiditfg to the v.due, nut according to the description ot their pu-sessioi-s, but perhaps I am mistaken. Surely a m.m in possession suv of £500 per annum, whether de- rived from selling wool or Helling calico, ought to nay the »arno »tim towards the expenses of go-

vernment.

The income-tax, therefore, to my mind, seems in many respect« the be»t tax, only a distinction ought to be mudo between an income tieri veil from r»'ul [iioporty und one dei ¡ved (Vom mental or manual labor. Moreover, on iuquishoiiul system must be adopted to find ont a permin'a income, «Iiiflr is very objectionable, heneo I would not advocate an income-tax, but »uroly, Mr Kilitor,' justice requires that all men should, as far as pos- sible, be taxed eipially in proportion to what they possess ? Am I right or am I wrong ? Ina re- sponsible government the expenses are decided upon by the representatives of the people. The people, therefore, having voted away ceitain sums of money, are bound to pay that mi'ncy, (aro thev not?) or in otln-r «olds, they are bound to pay taxes. Perhaps, Mr. Editor, one cpialifieutum for voting at an election might be to shew that tlie person claiming a voto had paid so much taxes ?

What right basa mun, who pays li 11 lo or no- thing to the support ' f government, indirectly to vote the supplie» ? It seem* *o mo tlut tux.ition is neeessnry, and that the collection and expendi- ture of the taxes is conducive to the public good, but justice seems to require that great judg- ment should be used that no cJu-s bo taxed more limn another. i'Jease try and enlighten nie.

Yoma obediently,

ENQUIRER.

2«*orl"i Brisbane, Nov. 9, 1857.

fWe do not understiind'what our correspondent |

is driving at. Wo fear tho "cocks and hens' i" must have awakened bim too early in tho morn- ing, Docs-he mean "that eveiytliing should be taxed or nothing at all Î He would not ta*c "ne coidiug to the description of their possessions'' but an income tix " to his mind »eems the beat," nnd yet " he would not advocate an income tat." We ivould gladly, however, advocate a tux on "feathers"-either cocks'or hens'-if it ««'oui I servo to ..clip" the willys of our iHylity correspondent.-ED. ii. O.C.\

articleText:
To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,-Previous to my departure from Moreton Bay I promised some ot my Brisbane friends that I would, from time to time, through the medium of your valuable columns, give thera -some nccpuut ot the progress of these diggings. Averse to communicating bad news, I li ave hitbetto beon silent, as for tho last six months the diggings havo not been ,veiy prospatous; but now-1 am very liappy in being able to stat», that there is a decided change hero for the bettor, and the miners who have had couiago onough to weather the bad times aro now mooting with the renard of their poisovoiapce. The lee 1 baa again been struck, and promises to bo as neb if not i ichor than even Mount Jones or Mount Welch, and the conrso that it has taken has enlightened many as to the nature of the Rocky Diggings, and will enable them to trace it for a long distance. In tracing it from Mount Jones to Sydney Flat, it was found to bo very patchy, and although many shafts paid very well, a great number would not pay for work- ing; and the sinking bsingveiy heavv, the chances otsuccess wera vaty piecarious. i'lie cause of this has been proved to be, that the bed-iock, taking no (Voided dip, but intarseoted with nu- merous shallow rises and falls, the gold has been scattered over too largo a space of ground to leave any very rich deposita in any part of it ;-but now the two fortunato parties (for there are only two shafts bottomed as yet), have come upon the gutter, and in one shaft particularly the gold is visible, scattered all over the rook. The sinking will vary fiom 80 to J60 feet. The surfa-ing, both on Mount Jones and Mount Welch, is pay* ing uages.

The diggers on the river are, generally speak- ing, doing well, particularly those who have the assistance of puddling machines. To conclude, I am confident îuasseiting, that notwithstanding the gloom that has lately been thrown over our operations., the Rocky will yot provo one of the rich gold-fields of the Australian colonies.

Many will recognise the writer by his subscrib- ing himse'f

' Your obedient servant,

X. Y. Z. ti

Rocky River Diggings, 27th. April, .1857.

-P.S.-I may, at some future-time, write with respect to the apathy shown by the Moreton -Bay people with regard to digging.- . I- beliove that their district contains both coarse and uno gold-

fields. .

articleText:
ORIGINAL COIUESPOlïDENCE.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SinJ-As tho Sydney steamer approaches the shores of your interesting bay with the new3 of last week's proceedings in tho Assembly, I cannot help thinking of the cloud thoy will' cast over your Ohristmns festivities. "Amerry Christmas" say I with all-my heart, "and a happy Kew Year to you" ; " but alas !" you will be icady-to rejoin, "how lo mo can-Christmas bring much, merriment or the Now Year much happiness when I leam," os'l baie done this morning,'that tho object upon which I, in common with the bulk of my fellow-colonists in this quarter, hail sot my chief affection, is still unaccomplished, still in- definitely postponed, still left lo loom, like a Will o-the-wisp, in the hazy distance." Separation is not yet achieved, that Separation for which my editorial heurt has so long sighed, and my editorial pen so assiduously laboured, still remaining a ,iague uncertainty, and nobody ein now ventnie to say w hen the desired boou shall be obtained.^

ïn*these lamentation«, Mr. Editor, I fully sym- pathise with you and your readeis. Whatever may be the general impression produced through- out the country by the news of the dissolution of the Cowper Ministry, I have no doubt that in Moreton Bay, nt least, tho intelligence «ill be re- ceived with'feelings of bitter disappointment nnd deep regret-not from any sentiment of admira- tion for, or fueling of attachment to, a Cabinet which, if wo are to judge of it in the light of it» late proceeding on the famous Land Bill, had cer- tainly no peculiar claim on tho confidence or respect of'the country, but rather from the con- viction that their retention of office a little longer might have enabled tho Legislature to carry through the necessary Bill for the division ol' the debt, ami thus have removed, if not the only, a^

least the mam obstacle that now stands in the way of- consummating the long desired measure-of total Separation. *

Viewed in this particular aspect, the dissolution of Parliament at thevprcsent moment, cannot, in ns far as Moreton Bav is concerned, bo regarded in any other light than that of a publio calamity, inflioung as it does, such " a heavy blow and great discouragement" on your most fondly cherished hopes ; and no doubt, Sir, after recovering from the first feeling of surprise and disappointment which the news of the dissolution is likely to create, 3ou will natuially bo led with eager curi- osity to enquire ns to what part YOUR members havo been taking in the political transactions that have been brought to a close so fatal to tlie-imme diate realization of the object of your wishes. This is a very natural enquiry for you to make, and it is very proper-nay, necessary that you should make it with the strictest accuracy and tho most rigid justice ; and if you do this Sir; . I rather think that the result will in no way re- dound to the credit of the majority of the gen- tlemen by whom Moreton Bay has the honor of being represented. ,. ( I

Yon, Mr. Editor, will of course'eonduot the in- vestigation according to your own independent and impartial fashion ; but observer nud visitor us I merely um, without being in any woy per- sonally identified with the interest of your magni- ficent district, I cannot refrain from telling you how strong is the conviction entertained in sunni quarters, of the inconsistency and infidelity by which the oonduot of at least thioe of your mem- bers has been marked, and how_ strong, moreover, 'is the opinion that if your constituencies deal with these honorable gentlemen ns they deserve, you will take the opportunity which tho ensuing elec- tion affords of sending thom to " Coventry," 'nnd supplying their places with better men.

Was it not well understood by ono and all of your members, that Separation was to bo the great object, to tho attainment of which they wera to bend their utmost energies ; and wero not the' professions and assurances of your last elected member on this point so full mid explicit-nay, even so profuse, as to leoyo not the shadow of'a shade of a doubt that he at least would como up to the mark, and mako all his sayings and doings in Macquiirie-street suhoidilute to tho gaining of jour grand object of Sepaiation? This, I think, will bp allowed on all hands to havo been tlio cuso ; but how, tho people w ill now ask, how have theso professions been fulfilled, or rather, to adopt the use of moto appropriate language, how have they not boen violated and pi iinllc.illy ignored ! On the discussion of tho five »hillings clause in the' Land Bill your members found it convenient, for some purpose of thoir own, to reduce themselves to ciphers by not voting on the occasion ¡ but' «lien tlio Assessment Bill was on tho tapis,-the Bill that proposed to mako such gentlemen ns, Messrs. Holt, Irving, and Leslie, pay something into the publio trensnry for the enormous benefits, they derivo fiom the public hinds, and the Bill,' moreover, of which tho defeat was sure to lend to the indefinite postponement of Separation-on this occasion you will find your three patriotic memheis recording their votes ai>ninst the mea- sure- thereby, by a sort of coup de 7nain, oust- ing the Ministry, deferring Separation, and though last, not least, saving their own darling pockets !

What will the pcoplo say to nil this, and what will thoy do? As to what they may say [ shall leave you to tell us by and bye, und us to what the countiy in general oiiyht to do, in tho present crisis, I bidieve, that in expressing my own,ideas on tho subject, f cannot do better than refer you to a lettei of mino " to the electors of New South Wales" in last Monday's issuo of the Empire, and which, perhaps, you may think it worth while to transfbr iiito your columns.

By-lhe-bio, I ennnot close without giving you 0110 of our latest Sydney political on dits, to Vio cflèct that the honorable member for tho Stanley Boroughs-still haiing an eye to the regaining of his seat-being apprehonsiie that tho electors do not cleaily understand Mm, proposes to pay Hiern a personal visit very soon, to havo a talk with them on fho subject of their imaginary dif f'eionces J ! Nothing uko coinage, say 1, but loiily if tlio lionoiablo member rim roa Hy screw his courage up to tho sticking point of facing his indignant constituents, ho must lnwo almost ns largo a simio nt blass as ho is generally supposed to lan oof gold. Ho may, however, luivo tint ef- frontery lo fuco thom, but if ho talk thom over, my name ¡s^ot

Christmas Morning, Moreton Bay.

SOOTÜS. on

' mi

THE IjJooDaerang arrived at the wharf yesterday afternoon at half-past two o'clock, bringing Sydney paper* to the 12th, and intelligence from Melbourne to the 5th inst. In Sydney little of im- portance had occurred in the Legislature, and the principal topic out of door,s was the affairs of the Empire, which seem to bo in a avery disastrous condition. The leading intelligence will be found in our correspondent's letter. The news from Victoria is important. The Ilaiuos mi- nistry had resigned on a question qf a want of confidence, and Mr. O'shanassy had been called upon to form a miuistry, of which it was said Mr. Duffy was likely to form a member. We look upon this as a prelude to a change in our own old fogy government. The ministerial ob-

structionists both hero and in Victoria

aro beginning to lind their places too hdt

for them.

in the development of the metropolitan district, and the gross neglect of the other portions of the colony, strikingly indicate the evils of a government re- moved from the pressure of public opinion in the locality suffering from its neglect or lnisgovernment. articleText:
BRISBANE HOSPITAL.

To the Editor ofth'i Moreton Bai/Courier.

SIR,-In the papers of this district there aro in- timations ftom the Committee, that tho present medical ollicers, T>rs. Cannan and Bell, Visiting surceons, and Dr. Barton, House-surgeon, aro eligible for iP-olection, and have signified their intention to act if elected. There has been IK> resignation. Notwithstanding this, Dr. Milford, latefy a reddent, has also signified his intention

of offering himself a3 a candid ite for the office of J

Visiting'-surgeon.

Now, accouling to the regulations, at present, there can be but twoVioiting-surgeons, and there- fore, ia the mont of his being elected, one of the present Visiting-surgeons must cease to act.

Dr. Milford^ knowt this ! How, in spite of this,

he can offer himself as a candidate is beut known to himself !

It is true that it is not opposed hy the rogilla tions of the hospital, but it is opposed by all that is liberal and courteous in the profession.

I do no1 Icno.v of an instance of a professional man offering himself as a candidato for an honor- ary office, not previously made vacant by death, resignation, or by some misconduct. It will he allowed that the me Heal olKcers become neces- sarily connected and identified with an institu- tion of this kind, having utall times considerable responsibility, and being liablo to be oalled upon at any moment to act, and theioforo, although they have no legal right, yet they have a right, by previous services and by courtesy, to expect to be again elected.

There can be no doubt that the general feeling of tho Governors, nwaro of what is golngon, would bo to re-elect the present Vislting-stirgcons.

( I am, Sir,

Your very obedient servant.

A SUBSCRIBER TO THE FUNDS OF

THE. HOSPITAL. ? . ? ,

North Brisbane, Jnn. 9th, 1857,

[It.may not be mule according to professional etiquette for a fresh candidate to present himself under the circumstances mentioned by our cor- respondent ; but what is the use of having an elec- tion nt all, unless to afford nm candidates an op j portunity of coming forward ? In the Sydney ' Hospital elections, we believe it is no uncommon

thing tp depart from this law of professional eti qnotte. We do not see _ why tlio samo usages which prevail in tho election of honorary officers of literary and scientific institutions should not he opplicablp in tho caso of the hospital. Wo do not like to see monopoly in tho medical profession more than in any other.-Ko. lil. ti. C]

articleText:
THE ABORIGINES. o'«

I To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier. | di

I Sir,-In the impression of Wednesday last of the '

Free Press a. paragraph appears, signed by T. of I Brisbane, to the effect that it is a moral impos- c . sibility to civilise and christianise the native po- ?

pulatioD of these realms. I admit, Sir, if our only ' motive is selfish, temporal, and worldly, we cannot '

expect to receive from such vain efforts spiritual J or even moral good to result from any efforts man * may make, especially when accompanied with de- v ception, cruelty, and oppression. These beings r aro tho same in'the estimation of our great Creator J, as the fairest Bkinned European that ever trod * Australian shores, freely admitted by T. That ° these aborigines are capable of receiving good J impressions, and reaping benefits resulting from {' colonisation, for the human mind, whether im- " planted in the white or dark-faced man, is the * same, and has sprung from the same great causo. Q We read at the beginning God created man in his " own image, male and female created he them, and ** God blessed them, and saw everything that he had ^ made, and behold it was very good ; on which St. " Paul comments that all mankind after God is j*' created in righteousness and true holiness ; again " in Timothy iii. 4, every creature of God is good, " and none is to be refused. What is then to be " done ? It is my opinion that as christians the 8I first thing we have to do;-a thing which is abso- g lutely necessary, and which cannot fail of being a ll most poworful means,-is that we, the members, n ministers, or preachers of every christian denomi- *i nation engaged in this glorious work of reconcilia- " tion, should preach Christ with living power, not c only by our words, but also by our behaviour, and n that wo should devoto ourselves to the salvation J' of every soul we may have access to, with more <}

love and faithfulness than we have hitherto done. }' When has idolatry, ignorance, and superstition, l< been overcome in any oilier way than by the n , preaching of the cross of Christ, by the vivifying n

proclamation of the goBpel, by ardent love to the * ? Lord and to every one, btaok or white, that be hos ° ? redeemed at so great a ransom ? " Go yo into all '? . the world, and preach the gospel to every orea- °

ture," is the express command of Him who has *j , promised to be with you even to the end'of the B , world. Preach Christ out of the abundance of a 6

l heart which has learned to know him as a Saviour, j1 , and tim» yon will drive away every difficulty, *'

abundant blessings will attend your labors, and *' , immeasurable comforts to your own souls. What- "

soever thy hand findeth to do, do it with all thy 9.' might, whether for the great work of the church d i or for the salvation of a singlo soul. Labor on, w

but never work without Beeking divine aid, with- J)

out fervently calling upon the namo of Jesus, " never let time be wanting for this most import- w ant duty, never stand still in spiritual things. P . If yon are not with Christ, you aro against him ; a

if you gather not with him, you aro scattering ü abroad. St. Paul says, " I nin ready to preach °: the gospel." Why Î " For I am not ashamed of ° ' tho gospel of Christ, it is ti.o power of God unto * ' salvation to avery one that believeth." " i Now, Sir, this is the first part, and to me the . most important practical pian for the amelioration , of this peoplo, whose real value must be estimated . boyond that of the brute creation.

My second part is that a committee be formed 0 from suoh persons who feel an interest in their n future welfare. ti

That a petition bo forwarded to the government- t< requesting a grant of land for the exclusive use of . the natives, for-tho formation of manual labor schools, upon the self-supporting principle, aided by voluntary contributions.

That every faoility shall be given for moral and ^ , religious instruction, including useful knowledge

i in tho arts and sciences. _ 01 i That such schools shall ombraco instructions in le . agriculture, the breeding and oare of animals, the ni . various useful mechanical arts and handicraft oc- cc

cupations. co

Trusting that something may speedily be done gi for the permanent good of this people, g"

I remain, Sir, yours, &o. m

South Brisbane, March 26,1857.

B. F. *

articleText:
To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier,

Sir, -In the Moreton Bay Courier of the 25th July, I have noticed a letter signed Kilana, in which the writer states as follows :

" The committee appointed to watch over these matters immediately put itself in communication with the Member of the district, and the Minister for Lands and Public Works, and it took occasion from the late disastrous floods, to point out to Mr. Hay the urgent necessity for proceeding at once with the public wharf, as the flood had swept the old one almost, if not altogether away. Mr. Hay deserves praise for his promptitude in this matter. Immediately on receipt of this intelligence he wrote to Mr. Halloran, the Commissioner, ac- quainting him that the money would be placed

forthwith to the credit of the Bench, and that the works, especially the wharf, might be immediately proceeded with. Mr. Halloran, however, for some reasons known only to himself, did not apprise the committee of this communication, and the works have consequently been delayed, to the serious inconvenience and injury of those interest- ed. I shall not trust myself to say what I think of the public officer who could be guilty of such conduct, but will leave it to the public, of which Mr. Halloran is the servant, to say whether, he is or is not worthy of its confidence."

In reply to which, I beg simply to say, that the statements of "Kilana" are false and malicious; and that if he for one moment supposes his anony- mous slanders will deprive me of the confidence of the Government and the public, which I have served for twenty-three years, he will find himself greatly disappointed.

The facts are simply these. In May last, during my absence in Sydney, the wharf at Maryborough was damaged by the floods. The chairman of what is here called "The Public Works Com- mittee," Mr. Edmund Blucher Uhr, reported the circumstance to the honorable the Minister for Lands and Public Works, and urged upon that officer the necessity for the public wharf being at once constructed. The honorable the Minister immediately replied to the chairman of the com- mittee, (letter dated 12th June, 1857), acquaint- ing him that the sum of £500, voted for the con- struction of the wharf at Maryborough, would be placed in the Joint Stock Bank to the credit of the Bench of Magistrates, to enable them and the committee to carry out the work in question. A similar letter was addressed to the Bench, and a receipt for the signature of the magistrates for the £500, was at the same time forwarded and a third letter to the same effect was delivered to me in Sydney. The letters and other documents for the chairman of the committee and for the Bench, were received in Maryborough by the chairman before my return to the district ; and it was clearly the duty of the chairman to have acquainted the committee with the result of his application to the honorable the Minister for Lands and Public Works, with which I had nothing to do. If he neglected to do so, it was he who suppressed the information, and is entitled to the censure.

I shall not condescond to offer any comments on " Kilana's" letter. The attacks of such pol- troons (who write anonymously, thereby shewing that they are ashamed of their doings) are beneath the contempt of every honorable man. But as he has brought charges against me of an injurious character, and which I can prove to be both false and malicious, I shall leave " Kilana" in the hands of my attorney, to whom I have written on the subject.

I had written the foregoing, and was on my way to the Post-office with my letter, when I learned from one of the initiated that the letter referred to by "Kilana" was a communication addressed to me by the honorable the Minister for Lands and Public Works, dated the 22nd April last : but as the wharf was not washed away until the latter end of May, as reported to the honorable minister by the chairman's letter of the 27th May, I do not clearly see how the minister's letter, dated 22nd April, could be in reply to Mr. Chairman Uhr's letter reporting the destruction of the wharf by the floods, dated the 27th May. Neither did the letter of the 22nd April say one word about the money being placed to the credit of the Bench of Magistrates, or that the works, espe- cially the wharf, might be at once proceeded with." So I again say, " Kilana" speaks untruly. I will merely state facts, without offering any re- marks. In the latter end of April or beginning of May, I received a communication from the

honorable tho Minister for Lands and Public

Works, dated 22nd April. That letter, as well as I can recollect, for I am writing at a distance from home, and quote from memory, was "acquaint- ing me what sums had been granted by Parlia- ment for carrying out certain improvements in the district, and requesting, that as there was no of- ficer of tho Colonial Architect's department in Maryborough, I would report as to the best means for carrying out the works,- suggesting that I should co-operate with Mr. Uhr and other gentle- men for the purpose of exorcising a surveillance over the works - stating that the Colonial Archi- tect would render such assistance in preparing plans, &c" as the distance from Maryborough would admit-and requesting me to furnish in formation respecting tho sites for the buildings, &o." This letter I looked upon then, as I now do, as a communication from the Head of my De- partment to a Government officer, from whom he required reiable information, and one with which i the committee had nothing whatever to do. I did however, show the letter to one of the com- mittee, a surveyor, from whom I obtained a small plan showing the sites for buildings, wharf, &o. ; and at a meeting of the committee which I at-

tended early in May, I apprised the committee that I had received such a letter, and that at the suggestion of the honorable the minister, I was willing to co-operate with them, and to do any- thing in my power to assist in carrying out the objects of the committee, which I think is noted

on the Minutes of that meeting. At the request of the committee I then allowed myself to be ap pointed an honorary member of that committee, and also at their request I consented to allow the money to be placed to my credit in the Bank, which is also noted on the Minutes of the meeting, the committee objecting to the money being placed to the credit of the Bench of Magistrates. Why the Minutes of that meeting were not for warded to the honorable the Minister for Lands and Public Works, and to the Member for the district, as directed, and why it was at some sub- sequent meeting determined that the correspond- ence of the committee should be in future con-

ducted by the Secretary instead of the Chairman, as I am informed was the case, it is not for me to explain. However, I left for Sydney on the 13th May, and shortly after my arrival there, I accom- panied our Member, and had an interview with the honorable the Minister for Lands and Public Works on the subject of the public buildings to be erected in Maryborough. I then replied to his letter, and furnished the sketch of the sites for the buildings, and subsequently called on the Colonial Architect, and gave him what informa- tion he required for preparing plans, &c., for the buildings. So that how I have withheld informa tion, or impeded the public improvements in Maryborough, I leave the public to decide.

I am, Sir,

Yours obediently,

AUTHUR E. HALLORAN.

Gayndah, 17th August,

rciUflluled, till is September,

articleText:
To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,—It has long been recognised as an axiom in moral philosophy, that vicious habits are the re-

sult of a vicious nature, and this is as demon- strably correct, even to the most casual observer, as that the sun will rise to-morrow, or that the whole is equal to the sum of all its parts. And so firmly is this philosophical truth engrafted upon the human mind, that man is naturally prone to believe his kindred almost as innocent and guileless as when placed by his Creator in the Elysian Groves of the Garden of Eden, until facts, and circumstances, combine to prove otherwise It is as impossible for a person, inherently of a meek and quiet temperament, and disposed to live peaceably with those with whom he is daily

called in contact, to wantonly lavish abuse, injuri- ons to the character and reputation of his neigh- bour, without any tangible assignable reason, as it is for a Feejee savage to demonstrate to you the difference between direct and inverse propor- tion ; or an Australian aboriginal to dilate upon the countless worlds which fill ethereal space, with the powerful eloquence and majestic strains of the illustrious Newton. And by a parity of reason- ing, when newspaper readers think it worth their while to peruse criticisms upon controversial topics of the day, and the letters of correspondents, ex- posing public abuses with a view to their ultimate amelioration, they are always anxious to hear both sides of the question, and to lead the replies of correspondent's entertaining different opinions, be- fore they presume to give a decisive answer upon the subject brought before them ; or as to the ex- pediency of such abuses, if any exist, being recti- fied. Mr. Editor, your readers and the public generally have had the opportunity of perusing the letters and articles which have emanated from the humble pen of the undersigned, relative to judicial and other affairs connected with the town of Drayton. A correspondent, under the nom de

plume of Watchman, in the North Australian of the 16th instant, emerges from his dignified seclu- sion, declares himself the champion par excel- lence of the Drayton Bench—proudly boasts that rights, truth, and justice, must finally conquer, and charges the correspondent whose signature is to him an Egyptian hieroglyphic, with being much too personal in his attacks, and severe in his criticisms. In replying to these charges I shall abstain as much as possible from indulging in unnecessary abuse or vituperative language, because I am fully aware that when such weapons are employed to demonstrate that one is right, and the other necessarily wrong, it is an indubit- able indication of weakness, and of a bad and hopeless cause

I think if Mr. Watchman, et hoc genus homne, had read the letters bearing the (to him) unintel- ligible signature, with common schoolboy atten- tion, he would have observed that I avoided, par- ticularly so, personalities ; and therefore, notwith-

standing his vaunted boast of truth and conscien- tiousness, I unhesitatingly affirm that his state- ments are false, and his assertions untrue. In the first letter which I wrote relative to the Drayton Bench and Mr William Weston, the following paragraph occurs :—"I do not wish to utter a single word disrespectfully of our mag- nates—far from it. I believe many of them in their private capacity to be good and estimable men, and valuable members of the community ; but whilst officiating as magistrates in the adjudi- cation of cases brought before them, they are public property and their proceedings and de- cisions are open to the legitimate criticisms of the press." Is there anything personal or offensive in this? Can Mr. Watchman point to a single word in this or any other portion of my letter, which encroaches upon the private secrecy or household matters of any individual, be he magis- trate or civilian? I think not if it be true that none are so deaf as those that will not hear, it is equally true, that none are so blind as those that will not see, and I would suggest for Watch- man's especial benefit, that he forthwith provide himself with a pair of Wellerian spectacles to facilitate his perusal of the Courier. Had this highly veracious, I almost said insignificant whipster, confined himself truths when intro-

ducing so condescendingly his olive branch of peace, I should have found it much easier to have defended myself against his subtle insinuations.

But as he is a conscientious (?) individual, on all occasions adheres to truth (?) and and is always actuat- ed by the purest (?) and most patriotic motives (?) we must take the most rational and charitable

view of his case, and suppose that at the time of his inditing his grandiloquent epistle, he was la-

bouring under some mental hallucination. But

whether he is a fit subject for a de lunatico in-

guirendo, I shall leave to others more competent to form an opinion. If, Sir, the press is to be re-

cognised as the great palladium of the rights and liberties of subjects of the British empire, the channel through which acts of injustice are ex- posed to the public eye, and justice (heavens, what

thoughts arise when we mention this word) meted out impartially to the rich and the poor, then I maintain that in publishing and severely censuring Weston's dismissal from custody, when a charge of robbery was preferred against him, I performed no more than my duty as a man and a citizen.

Deprive us of the liberty of the press and what would become of our boasted rights and immuni- ties? How those "clothed in little brief au-

thority" would chuckle and gloat over their victims, were it not tor the stunning, deafening,

thunders of the Fourth Estate ?

Even tyrants whom no powers distress,

tremble when they hear the thunders of the Press Roll through their kindgdoms in the civil storm, Proclaiming Justice, Freedom, and Reform.

Yes, Mr. Watchman, I have not the slightest doubt but what you have felt deeply the extreme

keeness of the pen of a newspaper correspondent, and hence your aversion, real or pretended, to anonymous letters. But how singularly unfortu- nate that while enforcing in a very determined spirit, the necessity and duty of newspaper writers affixing their bona fide names to their productions, Watchman himself should be unable or afraid to

act upon the advice he tenders; and if it be not considered an act of sacrilege, I would say to him in the unerring words of holy writ—" Thou fool, first remove the beam from thine own eye, before thou attempt to extract the mote from that of thy brother's" Verily, Mr. Watchman, if you

are without sin cast the first stone.

No doubt it is highly advantageous in large, as well as small communities, that we should live peaceably and harmoniously together. But what has our being on friendly terms with each other to

do with the administration of justice and the criticisms thereon ? Does Watchman mean to propound the strange Utopia, that we are to witness the majesty of " Justice" degraded from

her sacred throne, and not raise our voice in pro- testation, simply because by doing so, we shall disturb and render peculiarly uneasy, the deities

which occupy the judgment seat of Nemesis at Drayton ? If so, the sooner, he conceals his caput nortium among the exuberant vegetation of Darling Downs, the better for himself, and those sacred persons whose unimpeached and unimpeach- able private characters he has arisen, ephemera

like to defend. " A fellow feeling," says the

poet, "makes us wondrous kind," and hence the very, very touching and thrilling (?) appeal of Watchman on behalf of " injured innocence! ! ! !" which I intend to remit, per first steamer, to the Museum in London, as a literary curiosity of a magisterial Watchman in the districts of Darling Downs.

I can assure Mr. Watchman and those whose mouth-piece he has become, that there is not the

slightest disposition on my part "to put down, frighten, or thwart" those who, in performing a

painful duty, only do that which is demanded of

them by their country. I know perfectly well that it is as impossible for a magistrate to give

equitable decisions on all occasions, suitable to the wishes of complainant and defendant, as it is for a newspaper writer to indite in a strain that shall please all and offend none. But the particular cases which I hare alluded to in my respective letters, and which appears to have obliterated the

peace propensities of the Drayton Watchman, were such as to demand a passing notice in the columns of a newspaper. And the feeble, futile attempt at vindication on the part of Watchman, has

rather strengthened my opinion than otherwise. During the five years I have been connected with the press, there are no articles which I have written which I can look back upon with less regret than those which have appeared in your columns, having reference to Weston and the Drayton Bench, Mr. Watchman notwithstanding.

In conclusion, Sir, allow me to observe, that while I shall ever deem it an imperative duty to act I upon the advice of one of the greatest men who

ever lived, and who being dead yet speaketh,— " to watch closely, jealously, and anxiously, the administration of justice." Yet I shall never de- grade the dignity of the press by giving publicity

to statements false and untrue, to gain an unen- viable notoriety, or to gratify a, mean and con- temptible feeling of revenge. And if Mr. Watch- man is particularly desirous of becoming the critic of the undersigned, I would advise him, as a friend, though perhaps not quite a disinterested one, to take an additional lexicographical feed in the shape of a rigid and a careful reperusal of Murray, Walker,

and Johnson.

Apologising for the length of this letter,

Believe me, Sir,

Faithfully yours,

PHILALETHES.

Drayton, Dec. 21st, 1856.

articleText:
INSOLVENT LAWS.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,-When I pointed out in tho columns of your valuable papor tho absurdity of " An Obsorver'a" letter on the Insolvont Laus, I certainly did not expect that it would devolve on mo again lo refer to the bubjcot ; ai I thought your correspondent would not have, hardihood enough again to appear in print. In this I have , boon- mistaken". He complains in last week's issue, of having had vio- lent and contemptuous aiiinindvertions cast upon his "open" and "courteous?'(?) endeiivonrs to traduce tho characters of his fellow townsmen, (for ho insists that the cases of ¡nsolyenoy, wbioh ho cited, were not, as I hoped, supposititious) ¡ and further accuses me of having perverted his state- ments. This latter ohargo I simply deny-I might retort by saying that he has pervorteu the Queen's English; or, what is indeed the faot, that his periods lack that somewhat essential fea- ture in composition-coherence. But, us no good purpose can be answered by rccriiniifiitiou, I forbear. Lot us dwell lightly, Mr. Editor, on the faults and follies of our fellow-creatures.

It is unnecessary for me to point out the inex- pediency, to use no stronger'term, of adopting "An Obsorvei's" suggestion, advocating the cul- tivation of "a little business-like freodom of speech amonç tho merchants of Brisbane" re- specting tradesmens' affairs ; as this " business- like freodom of speech" can mean nothing less than the parading a man's business all over town. A plan which, although in particular cases it might bo attended with beneficial results, would,

if generally carried out, bo totally subversive of

trnni*

The only conclusion I can arrive at, from the perusal of " An Observer's" lotter, is that he said one thing and moant another (a fault of not very nnfrequont occurrence) j and ho is angry with mo for reminding bira of the foot. I will not pursue the subject further, having neither leisure nor in- clination to prolong the presont discussion.

I am, Sir,

Your moat obedient servant,

FOURPENOE-IN-THE.TOUND.

Brisbane, January 2, 1857.

SIR,-4fr. Arthur li; Halloran1* fetter in *your I paper of the 29th ultimo, will,- it is to bo hoped, at last in luco tho Government to institute an in- quiry into the fitness of this gentleman foi' con- tinuing in tho oflico of Police Magistrate at Wido

Bay.

It has surely never fallon to our lot before, to read such1 an inlprdper or vulgar reply from a pub- lic servant to one df th'iit publie. And it certainly shall not be perniittod this " ¿3 years1' recipient of tho public money, to meet awoll or 111«grounded charge in such an offensive manner.

Mr. Halloran views his long connection with thç Governments of this country-which in Na- poleonic' language he infers he has served so well -with far moro self-siiHlölenov and laudation than people in this neighborhood will allow him. Sir, there are many of us who would hear with much

Tho epithets which this Police Magistrate has bestowed in i'our paper upon your correspondent -nro dilations, and refinements of those which he gave utterance to at a storo in this town ; bnt the duty of wiping them away I can safely leave to the so bespattered.

The Government, I am told, is having the mat- ter brought under its notice; and in the mean time it is well that Mr. Halloran should hear that anonymous, because porbnps modest writers to a journal-which only publlohos when in tho pos- session of the writers names-are not so much open to the charge of " being ashamed of their "jjners," as the known,and vulgar, and blustering individu».'8 mSLy k° t0 ",tt^ °f bullyisjn.

I am, Sir, i a
