Whk.y r,'o found tho Herald advocating j ust mu to Moreton Bay, and propounding cert;* ;u measures for our advantage, we felt assured that the abandonment of

Separation by the British Giovcrnuient was cxti.irnely doubtful. Had the strug- gle in which we have been so long cn u'ir -I f'.u-vl so disastrous an issue, we '}> wo some reason to believe that the tone 01 that k/> 'ing organ of the opponents of S'jpiuution would have been more jubi- lant and less conciliatory. The commu- nication nude to the friends of Separa- tion on Tuesday evening last by our fel low-coloimt Mr. D. M'Connelt,, has re- moví' 1 ..! .uubt, if it ever existed in the mimi ol' any one of us, that before long our pJForts will be consummated in the ac! ievi'iiiuut of their anxiously desired result, tile Separation of the Northern DL-fnots f'nm New South Wales. It would uppear from what transpired at the mooting, that although we aro "for a timo" to remain an integral part of the old colony, it is not as the Herald would have us bolievc, for an indefinite period, during win h, like children, we are to be trained in the "art and mystery" of go- verning ourselves, but for such an inter- val only as must necessarily elapse to complete the arrangements required to statt the new colony on its career of self government. Some delay will of course arise in the adjustment of the boundary line consequent on tho resolution of the Homo G-overnment to consult the resi- dent householders between the 28th and ¡JOth parallels, but we apprehend that neither tim difficulty nor delay will be considerable. The settlement of terms for giur.niteeing the claims of public creditors, or auy minor matters, will not prison I au insuporable obstacle to the hpoeily tv fomplishmcnt of the pro je ¡t, i;t' Separation. At all ovents ii, is .-.¡.tisfactory to know that without mure than absolutely needful delay we »hall havo the government of pur district in our own hands, and that we shall not be left to the tender mercies of our »Sydney rulers to provide for us " a Fchemo of administration." The task to which the'people of Moreton Bay must now address themselves is, to secure their wt*f against the undermining opor^

ations of their neighbors, and to seo that tho latter do not " scheme" in some way less calculated to advance the prospects of these dhui icts. We have no doubt that they will be most active in sccurinw to themselves the coveted "slice" laying between tho two parallels-inasmuoh as success in this would attain a twofold triumph iu gaining the prize for their own beneßt, and in effectually crippling the new colony. We have before urged upon the frjends of our cause the neces- sity of unrelated and active exertion. Wo regret that the meeting on Tues- day was permitted to pass without the adoption of some decided measures for future agitation. Wo have cause for surprise ¡it the successful result 'of the movement for Separation. Throughout its whole course our efforts havo been on 'tfrely dcsullory. Thero has beon little if. any oi g.uiisation for our purposes. The necessity of association has been felt in nil political movements. Trom Magna Chacta to the ora of Corn Law Repeal and Financial Reform, combination has b3i'U found to be the inevitable law of political exertion. There is no escape. If you would fully succeed you must as- sociate. To what does this knowledgo direct as'/ To combino as others have

done.

We s.iy then, let future measures of a decided character bo resolved upon. Let ovcry movement of Now South Wales be watched and counteracted, as I fur as we li,ave knowledge and ability. I Let us send'one or more persons to the

Clarence and Richmond River Districts, fully prepared and able to expound our views to the people of those localities, .and let us bo careful that if they should 'decide against us they do so only with the wholo caso before thom and without causo hereafter to reproach us for supine ne3s or indifference in not making known to them the advantages of a connection with.tho new colony. If these things are to be accomplished, they must be undertaken by agents fully accredited by an Association, whoso most conspicuous members shall bo men best known among us for their talent, influence or wealth. Brisbane, Tpswioh, and other towns, how- ever emulous of each other in commer- cial or other matters, should merge all lesser objects in making ono united and determined movement for achioving the final succoss of separation views. The value of such an association would be great in fusing us into ono people, making our sympathies and aims less local, and directing our labors in channols best adapted to cfi'cct the com- mon weal. Wo bclievo that somo one has already been solected to represent us at the Clarence and Richmond Uiver districts. Wo aro not fully informed who has boen chosan for tho purpose. Wo

trust the selection will justify every ex- j pectation. It would, however, greatly |

strengthen, the hands of the gentle- man, whoever he may be, lud he ap- peared as .the delegate of a Union of

the Northern Districts. Such ft position, ' with the gift of utterance, supported by full knowledge of the history of the agi- tation, the justice of his cause, and the manifest advantage to the people of the Cla 'rence and Richmond ia becoming part oí the new colony, would scarcely fail to be followed by the desired issue. The Union should also give a formal sanction to those gentlemen in England to whom wo are indebted for our past success. Wo urge upon our friends to givo a definite form to our suggestions. There is in our mind great occasion still to be on the alert, al- though we do not believe much more is required than a trifling sacrifice of ease. The expenditure of money, which could not be large, would bo cheerfully borne by men seeking the blessings of self-go- vernment. The gentlemon at present in England have of course gratuitously aided their fellow-colonists, and the paid agents would be few in number. Many benefits would grow out of the association we have suggested, not the least among them being the discipline of discussion, and training for combined action, valuable as prepara- tory to the exercise of the functions of legislators.

BRISBANE HOSPITAL. 80

' I To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier. | bj

0

0 Sir,-Agreeably to promise in my last letter, pub i, liahed in your journal, I now beg to make known s to you the correspondence between myself aDd the

Committee of the Brisbane Hospital relativo to u ¡- practice permitted to exist in that Institution for i a considerable time past, and now allowed to con i, tinuo for nine months longer ; whioh practico I n consider disgracefully unfair and unusual both to e the trade of Brisbane and the hospital itself, and

ii reflecting anything but credit to all parties con-1

cerned. *

1 _ "Eagle Farm, March 4th, 1857.

i, " Sir,-Believing your institution to bo one of . tho most useful in our colony, and feeling certain o that to make its value permanent will require the I, united vigilance and exertions of all persons con . nected with it, stimulates and obliges me at the

present moment to address you ona subject which, f Jiowevor painful to myself, still, as a subscriber and . also a trustee of the institution, I feel it roy duty is so to do. During the last few Weeks it has come a to my knowledge that one of the late Visiting , Surgeon* (Dr. Cannan) has been acountomed to o recommend that the prescriptions of his private . patients should be dispensed by the House Sur d geon at the nbove institution, and that this prac-

tice, I am J°d to believe, has existed for some g months past ; that |t has been unknown to the n committeo for the past year, and also to tho pre o sent committee, J. readily believe. I can hardly

for a moment imagine that a body soleotod by tho n subscribers would tolerate a practico so unusual iy or inconsistent with tho proper management of so rt valuable an institution, and I havo to request that n, you will inn]fo this communication known to tho

gentlemen oomposing the oonaraittee at your oar

Jo Iiost convenience.

ot f When leaving the subject to the management 'tf of your oommittoo, I may say I have the utmost n- confidence in their decision, I haye not tim ". slightest doubt but when made aware that their tb hospital has boon used for private purposes, and ')' that by ono of its Visiting Surgeons, they will ho provide such measures that will for the future ho seouro the respectability of tho institution, and ?r- prevent a repetition of sueh unusual and dolo

a- terious practices,

, "I have tho honor to remain, Sir, Vo " 1 our ohediont Borvnnt.

.iy « ambrose eldridge.» "

" The Scorotary of tho Biiibuno Hospital." ^

io «Brisbane Hospita1, loth Maroh, W57. I

" Sin,-I have the honor to acknowledge ro- J' lo colptof your letter of tho 5th ¡iistaut.containing j1 al a oiiargo* against the flonsp Surgeon of tho Hos? J ii- pital, for Going in the habit of d|spens|ngê Dr

pe I Cannan'* prescriptions, to Dr. Cannan's. privat» >

patients, unknown to the Commitíroof the past £ or present yoar._ According to your wish' I sub- \ "mitted'tlns communication to the Committee and ' { nm'requested by them to acqunint you with their ,¡1 decision, which was ns follows :-Proposed by Mr. t D. F. Roberts ; seconded by Mr. J. 5. Turner :- J That referring to Mr. Eldridge's letter, the c Committee disapprove of the House Surgeon dis- 0 pensing drugs to any but his privato patients, 'J and recommend that at the end of the year such 1: practise be shopped, and that Mr. Eldridge bo in- ¡¡ formed of the decision of the Committee Car- j ried unanimously. Signed W. A. Duncan, Chair- li man'. . . . * v

"I have tho honor to be, Sir, 1<

..' Your most obedient servant, c

"J. INNES, »

" Secretary." h

" Ambrose Eldridge, Esq."

I Now, Sir, why the committee should tolerato t this corrupt practice to go on to the end of _ tho

year, I am at a I033 to discover. Their decision in tliia case is certainly a strange and_ inconsis- tent one ; they acknowledge the practice wrong, and still allow'it to exist. I cannot help thinking, Mr. Editor, that tho Press should be admitted to those meetings of committee. 1 imagine it would have a purifying tendency,, and would enable the subscribers and publio to know who are the useful and honest officers of the institution, and who are honest until they are found out.

I believe the Briabane Hospital to be thorough- ly a publio institution ; its revenue is derived prin- cipally from Government grants and police fines, say to the amount of three-fourths of its income, the remainder is paid in by the subscribers. AVhy such a publie|institujiion should bo allowed to profit or benefit a Visiting' Surgeon, or put itsolf np as an opposition against its own subscribers and the good tradesmen of the town, I am at a loss to know. But this I know, that should I be per- mitted to live until the next estimates come under discussion, I will not fail to make the legislators of oar country aware of tho character of the in- stitution thoy have always so liberally dealt with, and the necessity for some new rules for its proper management ; suoh rules that will secure the in- stitution against Visiting-surgeons making dis- honorable compacts to the injury of the hospital, for the sake of what they call professional eti- quette, or rather, in this case, call it professional humbug.

I am, Sir,

Tour obedient servant,

o'

articleText:
MARYBOROUGH.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,--We are a community unknown, compara- tively speaking, and our name, if mentioned at all) is mentioned only for misrepresentation and in- jury. Will you let Maryborough have a corner now, and if need be, at any future time in your deservedly popular paper. It certainly is of no consequence whatever to other communities what we are doing here, and I trouble you not with these few lines to enlighten either one or another on the sayings and doings of Maryborough. It is needful, however, sometimes for truth and right's sake, and for the character and reputation of the place in which one's lot is cast, to say a little, that if possible " pure misrepresentation may not altogether have its own way."

Maryborough, and the districts of which it is the outlet, have been sadly neglected hitherto, but who may be to blame for this I will not take it upon myself to say, suffice it that I shall go no further back in the history of the place than March last ; when it having been seen something was required to be done, a public meeting of the inhabitants was called, at which resolutions were submitted and unanimously agreed to that imme- diate and active stops be taken to represent the claims of the town and districts on the attention of the Government, and especially to secure at once the expenditure of the money voted for public purposes at the late sitting of the Legis- lative Assembly. Tho Committee appointed at this meeting to watch over these matters, imme- diately put itself in communication with the member for the district and the Minister for Lands and Public Works, and it took occasion from the late disastrous flood to point out to Mr. Hay the urgent necessity of proceeding at once "with the public wharf, as the flood had swept the old one almost if not altogether away. Mr. Hay deserves praise for his promptitude in this matter. Immediately on receipt of the intelligence he wrote to the Commissioner, Mr. Halloran, ac- quainting him that the money would be placed forthwith to the credit of the Maryborough Bench, and that the works, (especially the wharf) might be immediately proceeded with. Mr. Halloran, however, for some reason known only to himself, did not apprise the committee of this communi- cation, and the works have consequently been delayed, to the serious inconvenience and injury of those interested. I shall not trust myself to say what I think of tho public officer who could

be guilty of such conduct, but will leave it to that public, of which Mr. Halloran is the servant, to say whether he is or is not worthy of its con-

fidence.

A public meeting was got up on the 2nd inst. at the instance of one or two parties who are dis- satisfied with the committee of public works ;

oon the chairman of the committee, however, read- ing the minutes and the correspondence above ' referred to, and explaining what they had done

towards the fulfilment of their trust, the meeting ' was so convinced of the perseverance and industry of the committee that a vote of thanks were accorded to them.

I purposed at the outset noticing an untruth-ful communication of a Maryborough correspondent of the Sydney Herald, which has gone the rounds of the Moreton Bay papers, but it is not worth my while saying anything about it.

I see Moreton Bay has got £10,000 for her

roads ; Wide Bay has not got a farthing. What has our member been about ?

I am, Sir,

Yours obediently,

KILANA.

Maryborough, July 15,1857

articleText:
ORIGINAL CORRESPONDENCE

í"To <7ie Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.)

SIR,-My attention has beon directed to the lettor of your Drayton Correspondent, of the 2nd Nov., in which my namo is bandied about rather freely in connection with matters deoidedly untrue. .Judging from tho language rando uso of by your vory intelligent correspondent^ your readers may suppose that my complaint of illness und medical certificate was morely an ingenious device to evade the ends ol' justice and law'» just penaltios.

Whereas, on the particular day I wns summoned to appear at tho Polico Oflico, I was suffering from acute inflammation, nnd ordered by my medioal at- tendant to keep in a recumbent position, nnd con- sequently was physically incapacitated from at-

tending.

As to the reflection upon Dr. Armstrong that ho should have attended the court in person and oor tificil to tho fact of my i linos. Tlio idea is one of tho most ridiculous a perverted imagination could possibly conceive. If a witness is sum ' moned to attend tho Supremo Court, and is pro

vented from illness, is not tho judge, tho officer prosecuting for tho Crown or for tho defence, ns the ease may be, perfectly satisfied with a cer- tificate of illness duly attested by a duly qualifie.! medionl practitioner? And if the highest court of judicature in the land is Bntisfied with tho docu- ment, surely your correspondent, even supposing him to be a magistrate can have no ronson to com pluin. Buthodoea not mean to préjudice ni o, how vory charitable. Heaven r ra torvo mo from my friends. Tho assertion that 1 was selling without a llconso for 4 vveoks is most grossly falso. Evon whon I re- ceived tho summons to attend for illicit grog serv- ing I had the license in my possession, and when this was discovered tho charge, if such it may bo called, was abandoned. Yet your correspondent asserts (not to my prejudice bo it remembered, for good soul ho could not bo guilty of snub con- duct,) that I was soiling 4 weeks without a license, and people wondered why such a proceeding should he tolerated. I should uko to know your cones pondenfs definition ol' people, J um indinei' tg

believe we should find the people alluded to wereconceiitrated in hiinselfthe Alpha mid Omeita.

In conclusion allow me to observe that I think

it would be more creditable to your correspondent if before publishing his leports he t< ok the -trouble to ascertain their correctness. We might 'thcn-,be inclined to believe there was somoappear

,ance ofsineeiity in asserting that he did not wish to prejudice 'nie, 'lind not only m« but all those who have tho misfortune to como within theiadius of his goo>o quill.

Apologising for occupying so much of your

space

I remain your obedient servant,

Toowoomba, -Nov.' 17,1.857.

T. BAMFORD. "

I"

MR. HOOD'S PETITION.

Tbtke Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

MR, EDITOR,-This is a Petition earnestly entreat« intf the Queen i to'deprive us of our liberty and Constitution. Darvall, nicknamedSccrpion, never did anything half so bad as tlin.fc, 'he only wished to prevent us from getting Separation, and not knowing us, spoke slightingly of us ; but those men, tbo petitioners, our neighbors (locally) living nmong na and knowing us, misrepresent and ma- lign us. They ure traitors to tlio cause of tlio country. They bow down and wish to compel tis to bow down in the mire to Mammon and tho golden calves and sheep of their idolatry, wbilo the opening destiny of this mighty eastern land looms o'n the horizon in magnificent oatlino and proportions. The contempt of our children's children shall rest on us, if when they expect to have received from our hands bread, thoy find that we have given them a stono.

À month or more had elarsed from tho *jimo .when I was favored with o_ sight of *][,.. Hood's petition now before the public, ati'i '^g publication m your paper of the 7th instit. I bad exercised as muoh pationce as »¿emed to bo virtuous, and began to wonder v-'ÜOn ¡(¡ wouij (¡f QVOrj ]nv M\fo its hole-and-corner, character and como forth, ct be dragged into the light of day. Tho latter operation I began to foal would devolve as a duty upon myself if none of the front rank men did not elfect it. I am relieved of that duty. But now that Mr. Hood has fathered and set forth the ugly brat, we must look at him, and seo whether be is lit for the public service, or to bo sent where his brother production, the earnest prayer and cry for convicts, has gone before him.

Now, Sir, I cannot soe why tho possession of a lease or license from her Slajosty to depasture stock on tho Crown lands, or holding lands in fie, or the possession of live stock of any kind, should

throw any sane man into such a desperate state of i mind as to make bim earnestly desirous of teat lug Oil' from himself tho bithorto'highly vaunted and prized rights and privileges of a British citizon or subject. Perhaps, however, this anomaly is on efleot of thÎ3 antipodean and colonial olimate ; but be that as it may, I nm not disposed to viow the attempt to influence hor Majesty to doprivo others, who also reside in the Northern Districts, of thoir rights and privileges, under any other light than as exhibiting the possess!'.'a by the stockholders who sign that petition, of a kind of stock which they have been too modest to enumerate among thoir other possessions-an unlimited stook of im Etidonceand selfishness-and in somo of thoso who

avo signed the petition at thoir dictation, a stock

of toftdvism and snoaknrv

T?hoy aro vory loyal too, and will continuo thoir allegiance oven after tho Northern Districts aro separated ;--how vor; kind ! And they will allow her Majesty to call the now colony hy any name sho likes ! And 'JO as thoy are such very good boys, thoy venture to "prefer a request tending, ns they humbly beliovo, best to promote tho ful- filment of hor Majesty's gracious intentions."

This is fine indeed. _ Do they intend to foist upon her Majesty the intention to deprive us of our rights and privileges, or is this morely blarney io cover the tendency of their, request to fulfil %boirown ungracious and meanly selfish intentions.

I hone her Majesty will toll them that she seos

through their kind anxiety to put her in the way of fulfilling her intentions, and will grant them an acknowledgment 'if not a reward for their kind advice to her to withdraw the Constitution which ehe has already promised to us, vvhilo they volun- teer to hold her naud as she draws out for us such a Constitution as thoy believe moat likely to suit

their class interests.

They desire earnestly to doprive this district of tho rights it possesso3 now, and think that the scattered state of the population, its small numbw, its inexperience in political matters, and iu the

art oF self-government, justify thoir desire.

Quere Î How does tho smallness of our popula- tion, or any of its other alleged deficiencies, justify »portion of its numbers in oarnestly desiring to do- prive tho whole of its common political rights.

Answer : Bocauso the potitioners suppose that they havo interests differing from, and perhaps antagonistic to, the general interests- and that if a nominee government wero established they, Ïiartly by the inilucnco of thoir licenses, feos,

eases, and Btock, and modoit assurance, would bo thai Government and thoso nominees, and that tuey would thus bo enabled to seouro their particular interests, immunities mid privi- leges, while the riyhts of the community in go- ner?.! might shift for themselves.

Q. But would not the Nominees who would be nominated by the Crown net quite as well if they were nominated by the community.

Ana. Yes, but tho possessors of stock are con0 _ «lent that they would bo nominated by the r'.m.¡,*1'.*

while they would not bo nominate'' ' "',*,"",'

'inunity ; and in tho latter cas* r,DJ .u{° com"

¡Í4 mn,y ^-Its be remarked, that the population cío- "'ítjov Separation, be les3 or moro scatter ".' . inexporionced in politics, or tho art of self government, than it is now, when it performs its part in the government of New South Wales as creditably as ony other part, and is likely daily to imorove in all those .particulars.

The petitioners would also postpone tho con- ferring of tbo full Constitution as now enjojod, till wo witness its aotion and results at Sydnoy. What, then, if the stockocraoy bbould suoceed in making representativo institutions fail, or seem to fail there, by party and faottous proeoodings, aro they thus at one blow to ruin Now South Wales, and enslave Moreton Bay ? Are thoy by proving tho.mselvos unwilling to carry out representative and responsible government, to provo that wo Are unfit to earry tlieso into benefioial action ? No, no, Mr. Hood, that won't do. "ïour guide of ines timablo value to the form of government ultimate- ly best suited for the Northorn Districts, would load the march of intolleit and improvomont the backward way ; and what between the actual re- sults at Sydney, and Hie faithful guidanco of Mr. Hood and his coadjutors, wo might find that we had besn led to the empire of Stocklandin, in which tho fable of tho child's book, called the "Wo Id Upside Down," would bo realised,-when stook in its various shapes would legislate forond comuid'id mankind, and mankind would bo but tools and

«¡lavos of stock and stookmastors.

" Tbo memorialists therefore pray that tho go- vernment of the Northorn colony may bo by her Majesty'! representative, aided by an Executivo Council, and a singlo Legislative Chamber, com- posed partly of members nominated by tho Crown, amongst whom tho officers of tho Crown may sit and voto." But of the representativos of the people, their sittings and votings, tho loss that is »aid tho oasior tho saying will bo mendod. " And ^ your memorialists," &c.

Vory truo. The memorialists, who aro thoy ? Now I cannot, Sir, inform you. But a portion of the liamos attached to tho petition when I saw it, I recollect well, for I was surprised beyond moa Bure nt seeing some whioh wore appended to snob.

ft dooumont. Those which, follow . are put down nearly in the order in which they ocourrod, and arc » good Ramp ta of tUo two çlftSB,«» of wliiob, tho.

mnlàl tlHU*äm*miu*Jmm»m^*mto\.m.n.

list isOdittpdied-i.e., 1st, The intarostcd persons i and'2nd, Their toadies. First, come tbo fortunato Widers, then, dragged through the mire of the stockyard, como the obedient servants to command -the holders of editor, of printor, and last, not least, of surgeon,

Signatures to Mi\ Hood's Petition :

Joshua Bell, value of stock £70,000 ; licence for 30 acres, freeholder of 40 acres,

T. D. L. Moffatt, (for 3 soparatoTruns.)

Donald Coutts, Walter Gray, W.'Craicä;"(lho .paiticulars of these threo have escaped my recol-

lection.) -

Geo. Thorn, license, Normandy.

- Andrews, license, Tarampo. - '

George Faircloth, freeholder, 3,000 acres. -Lyons, editor, North Australian. ^ Edmund Bayes, printor: Arthur Baye*, printer. '

Thomas Ronlands, Surgeon. ^

Wo can understand bow the holdors of stoelr, wishing lo maintain exclusive of 'party advanta- ges, may wish to deprive tbo public of free insti- tutions, which they supposo threaten to interfere with their advantages ; but.vve bave yoi to learn how tho possession of editor, of printer, of surgeon, by airy of the petitioners, proves the impropriety of tho public having tho direction of, or a voice in, thoir own uifuirs, I havo been

laboring for sonio. -years under the impression that the possession of thèse qualifications were held as cvidehco of tho fitness of tho individuals possess- ing them, and the society in which thoy are found, to pmy their part as free citièells bl ti free state. But these {iéísdils aeerti to think that editor^, printer, and surgeon, are only fit to echo the lowing of stock. I am ashamed of them, and in particular protest against the degradation of tbo honorable and liberal profession to whiclr I belong) by tho subservient signature of one of its members, which I find attached to the memorablo memorial of Mr. T. Hood. It may suit tbo pur- pose of a young man, without the ties of homo or children, who may bo hero to-day and away to- morrow, without let or bindranco, to pander to the

Set or interest which he supposo3 will pay him

best, but there aro dthers who have ties of homo and family, who conceive that the liberal and re- presentativo government institutions are their own right, and that it is their bottnden duly to hand them down to their children, and td defend thom when in danger frdm tlio machinations of those who would not oulv soil their own birth-right

for a mess of pottage, but hayo the modest assur- ance to ask tiioso who may have power to do sot to take away tho birth-iigbt qf their neighbours and their neighbours' children. Fie for shame ! Where itofr ure tho men whoso names are usually found signed to requisitions to " Charles Geo. Gray, Esq.," to conveno meetings ? Ought thero not to be a meeting, or ot least a counter memorial, to mdet that attempt, not only to prevent out receiving a boon or right, but to take from the public the liboral form of government which they already possess ? The gentleman who presided in tho chair when we met to thank her Majesty for the promised böoli of Separation has set his nnme to Mr. Hood'^ memorial, and there- fore cannot lead or follow here. Who is to begin now ? If Separation is granted with Mi'..Hood's form of government, it will indeed be a boon to tho stockholders and holders of liconses to depas- ture, good sport for these boys, but it will bo death to the frogs, who will loose their liberty and rights by it, and may croak loud enough when it is too late to be of any uso to do so. Now is the time. Were wo not advised by an influentla

speaker at tho Separation meeting not to ask fo1' any particular form of government, but to tak° what wo could get from tho home government' as by raising that question wo might jeopardise Separation itself, and nothing particular wns urged then ? It is surely time now> seeing that both Separation and representative government aro in jeopardy, to ul-go that the condition promised in the Act giving her Majesty power to separato us

be fulfilled, viz. : That the constitution to bo

bestowed upon us be, as nearly as the circum- stances will allow, like that in operation in the colony from which we aro to bo separated, at the time of Separation. I thought at tho time there could b3 no harm in referring to that statoment, and think that it is imperative now, that we should let tho government know that we expect the fulfilment ol' that arrangement at the least, and aro opposed to Mr. Hood's plan of govern- ment by Governor, government officiais, and

rrnvprnmont nominees.

Tho editor of tho North Australian signed Mr. T. Hood's memorial a month ago. It was published in tho columns of tho Courier on the 7th February, when Mr. Hood called the atten- tion of " persons interested in Moreton Bay" to it. Two issues of his papor havo taken place since thon, and yet on this subject ho is deaf and dumb. Does tho guardian of tbo public interests and rights nod at his post? Is lie gagged or hobbled? Lot him irfer'to the concluding para- graph of his lëa'ier.1 on tho Depot at Ipswich, in his numlyer of "tho 10th instant, mid say whether \\, might not in this instance justly bo altered thus : " Wo consider that tho inhabitants of Moreton Bay have boon most scurvily treated and misrepresented in this affair, both by the squatters who originated it and those who have truckled to them, and wo havo not failed to toll them so plainly. Wo should not, however, be surprised to learn that their virtuous Indignation has been aroused, and that thoy deny tho charge of truculence which wo bring against thom, and their indignation will probably reach its climax when wo tell them further that whenever Separa- tion takes place the services of some of them ara likely to bo dispensed with. It is probable when Buch a consummation of our hopes is accom- plished that the .reign of favoritism, incompe tency and abuse of office, will then bo brought to

an end."

Hero my lottor must como to an cud. It is a long one, but I will not apologise for it on that score. Lot thoso sing mum on the subject who think it important enough to bo Bigned but not

written about. *

. I am, Sir,

. . . . Your verv obedient servant,

UI \{1T\ UUIUIIIIV m.lvuiJV|

FREDERICK CUMMING.

Brisbane-sheet, Ipswioh, Feb. 21, 1857.

articleText:
POLITICAL AGITATION.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIB,-lu your contemporary of Wednesday last .are letters from somo gentlemen who have felt aggriovod at my remarks as contained in your issue of the 4th hist. First, Mr. G. Raff denies .having used the words " it seemed to have tako'n tho screw off him," in referring to the proposer of the resolutions at the meeting in the School of Arts. The writer of this has since taken the

opinion of several who were present as to whether these wore the words used, and they say they wore. And it is well known that the papers do not report all that is said, as also that they soften any ollbnsivo expressions that maybe used/as they

bave dono in this case.

- Nor can I seo why Mr. Raff should object lo Mr. Holt's getting credit for establishing a third bank in Brisbane. I have often heard Mr. Raff getting credit for his exertions in the estub'.ish ment of a second bank in this town when it was much wanted. And will any but those connectod with the other banks say that the third bank was not required, and has iiot been useful, whilo in both cases the banks are also heiielittcd. Why, then, refuse Mr. Holt credit for baiiefitting both the bank and the public Î Again, Mr. Raff de- nies having nsod the expression with regard to another candidate for legislative honors sometime ago ; that "Mr. Hodgson would oblige nie, and wTiv should I not obligo him ?" Now Mr. Raff will recollect, that after Mr, Hodgson's being de- feated for the County of Stanley in 1851, some of his friends dined with him in Brisbane, and the above expression was said to bo part of Mr. Raff's Btioech ou that occasion, and caused some surprise then. I am glad Mr. Ran' repudiated the princi- ple implied in such expressions.

.' The next labored epistle is from Mr. Samuel Taylor Kerfoot, who seems to bo in somo difficulty from which he cannot well extricate himself; anil lie deals out his rmnblo-de-tliumps on those who shelter themselves under any appellation however modost. But a word in your ear, Samuel, " the prudent man hideth himself, while the simple pass .on and aro punished." There is also a heap of .rubbish raised by some literary molo in the same paper, and marked " An Elector ;" but such crea- tures aro not safo to dissect in any clean place, 1 shall therefore wait until he comes noar tho river.

But, Sir, what does all this opposition to Mr. Holt spring from Î Let us soo. The most stronu oas springs from a determination to mako it np "pîartnat Mr. Holt lins really done.somotbing very wrong and this entirely hinges on the fact that if 'Mr. Holt did not do anything deserving theconsure heaped upon him, then we have done something Wrong in our treatment of bim its our member.

And in order to arrive at a fair conclusion we will take the opinion of an ablo writer on thin subject, namely, the duties of a Roproseutatite : " It is Ids duty to represent the opinions of his consti- tuents, and to not and voto upon his own. It has been well remarked, that a Senator should con- sider himself not so much the representativo of one portion of tho community, as n loghlatocfor all ; and ho can fulfill this superior duty only by exercising his individual judgment." And the same authority says, that "if it he found that a majority of his votos are at variance with the de- sires of his e-onstitmnts, ho ought to resign." So then, as'Mr. Holt has only offended hy ono vote, all his other votes being unobjectionable, ho has no right to resign, and wo had no right to ask bim to do so. To this conclusion any unprejudiced - person will como. But thore nre mighty creatures whoso vulture oyo is over ready to fix on any poli- tical limb that may ho exposed, and by their poi 'sonous exertions create a sore. These are the scorpion after his kind, as well ns the musquito after his kind ; and as soon as thoy wound, then Ve have the big blow-fly after his kind ¡ and tho little buzzing blow-fly after his kind ; and all tho maggotts after their kinds (as per swarm), gather to feed on the impurity. It provos there must bo something great in Mr. Holt to attract the atten-

tion of all these. A usoloss muff would not be worth their abuse. And every man who has been a benefactor to his country has had to go through » somewhat similar trial, ns our member is now undergoing, and from which he will emergo purer and brighter than ever.

I will not in futuro notice anything that does ' not appear in the paper it is opened in, consi-

dering that to be the fairest as woll as custom- ary method. And as Mr. Holt's traducors can- not be so well accommodated when thoy como all in a body, perhaps thoy will divide themselves and appear weekly. Say all the slanderers the first week, and the croaking yokels tho second week. In which oaso thoy will receive every attention from,

Sir, your obedient sorvant,

AN OBSERVER.

Brisbane, July 10th, 1857.

articleText:
1 ACTION ! ACTION ! !

To the Bdaor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,-When will dur public men, " the lenders of the people" to whom we naturally look td take the initiatory stopi in all mitters, affecting the public weal, I ask when will our publie men, take the nedessary steps to convene a public mealing» to consider the Boundary. Question, and not only convene a meeting, but come" to it ready for " Action." Yes, Sir, if evor there was a tinte in the history of those districts, when the demand was urgent, for the peoplo to be roused to action, that time is now when the Sydney Government, and all influential portion of the Sydney Press and public, are seeking; to wrest our rights, by fair

means or foul.

Hiavo been led to trouble you with this, lil don-» sequence of the strange apathy of th oso, who have ever been foremost in the struggle of self

government.

, But of what value will .-separation be to us, if the boundary line bo drawn 'close to our doors ; in order to avert which calamity, I would humbly propose that a public meeting be oilled without delny, and resolutions pftsáed calling upon the inhabitants to subscribe the necessary funds, to remunerate one or two activo agents, whoso duty should bo to canvnss tho Clarence, and liichmond Districts thoroughly, ¡n order to obtain signa- tures to a Petition, addressed to the Home Go- vernment, praying that they iniy be included in the New Colony about to be oréete 1.

I am aware, Sir, that you have already drawn attention to this plan, in your able article in the Couiier of 25th ult., hut us no movement appears to be on tho tapis, I would fain hopo by reiterated appeals, to rouse our londarsjto "Action;" procras-

tination will min us.

I would also suggest the advisability of pre- vailing upon some iiilliiontinl gentleman connected with these districts, tn proceed to Melbourne, as a doleg.ite from here, and endeavour (as previously attempted by our " good and true" friend Dr. Lang, who might possibly ha prevailed upon to accompany him) to enlijt tho sympathies of the Victorian Legislature in our behalf, by pointing out the immense disproportion that would exist between the two colories of Now South Wales, and Victoria, (great enough in any case) if tho boundary were drawn at the 28th instead of the 30th parallel, as Mr. Compigne has ably shewn in his letter in your lost week's issue.

But I fear I hiivo aireuly extended this beyond the bounds of prudenco, so will conclude us I

began,

By subscribing myself, Sir,

Your obedient servant, '

South Brisbane, Aug. 6.

ACTION.

To the Editor of the Moieton Hay Courier.

articleText:
- -..CROWN CONFISCATIONS.

. ." To theJidilór of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,-To day, has been sold nt the Court IIouso of this town, a quantity of mm, which tho Chief Constable informed tho public, had been confis- cated by the Crown. From enquiries .which I baie made, I havo ascertained that the ruin in question was seized upon a dray, and we naturally picsume ¡> portion of it had been illicitly sold in - order to constitute it a legal seizure. Now, as

lim afluir had never been publicly investigated, 1 should like to know how the rum in question could be declared and sold as confiscated property. Is there an Aet of Council to the effect that all spirits found on drays are Hablo to be seized ? If 1 so, the sooner it was promulgated the better for '. the mercantile community. Or aro we, Mr. 1 Editor, to como to the conclusion, that this is one of ' those strango instances of majostorial wisdom, ' worthy of being recorded among the voluminous J "eiidence of Mr. Robertson's Commission of En-

quiry?

1 V«..«3 f"."il.P..!l..

PHILÀLETHBS.

' Drayton, January 9th, 1857.

articleText:
To the Rditor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sin,-Although possessing nn'extremely modest [ share of tlu cacoithes scribendi, I cannot retrain

from begging you to allow me space for a Bingle seutonce to notice tho spirit of an emanation from one "Quis" in your last valuable issue, which is bended by au introductory query in the same un chissic.il 'and indelicate style which characterizes

the whole effusion.

Is it tho part of a right-minded citizen to ap- peal to tho columns of the press when it happens that in a EÍnglo inst ince n public officer is out' of the way at any paitmular moment when his ser nuco a>o culled into íequisition? Is it generous, I ask, for any man to call the attention of the community to a trifling personal inconvenience received at the hands ot a_ public functionary which is the result of accident merely, and not of a systematic dereliction of duty? That the instance before you belongs to the latter category it is not for a moment sought to be established..

Had " Quia" possessed the smallest share of proper feeling, he would have endeavored to ob- tain redress by stating his case to the' gentleman at the head of the Custom-bousp, who 1 feel sure, would baie vindicated the department from tb« charge so uncharitably brought against it,r by affording satisfactory explanation, or employed stringent measures to prevent a recurrence of the ovil complained of. Instead of w hieb, Mr. " Quia" at once intrudes his plaint upon your valuable ear, and endejvois to call forth the "reprehension of a sympathising publio.

" Appeal lo the press is certainly a great boon to a people, but it ought to show its appieciatioirof this high privilege by using it aright. No doubt irregularity in the couduot of public business is a great evil,' but I hold that no man has a right to ding his alleged grievances into the public prints until after he has failed to rorreofc the abuse of whicluhe complains by application to the "one in authority."

The»conrso which " Quis" bus pursued in this matter appears tome nt once disrespeotfu' to the Sub-Collector,-nii infliction on yourself, and most undignified on his own part. Verily he would much more happily have subscribed himself " Quis

Ouis." ' "

articleText:
DB. LEICHHARDT.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier,

SIR,-In this day' Herald appears a paragraph reporting that a personal investigation had been made by His Excellency the Governor-General into

the statements of the convict Garbut, at Cockatoo Island, with respect to the alleged captivity of

Dr. Leichhardt and his party, with a tribe of semi savages in the interior. The report adds, that a farther inquiry was about to be instituted, in the pretence of Mr. Hely, who commanded the last expedition in search of Leichhardt, and also in the presence of Messrs. Gideon Lang, Ferret, and J.

Macarthur, all gentlemen well acquainted with the country about the Lower Condamine. This is, so far, satisfactory. Few persons of ordinary intellgence who have read the strange stories of Garbut can doubt that they are purely tho pro- duction of his own imagination, stimulated by a desire to escape from custody. But you will ob serve that the paragraph in question proceeds to anticipate opinions, by declaring that no experi-

enced bushman now entertains a doubt of the story of Leichhardt's murder, as told by the blacks to Mr. Hely and others. If the object of the in- quiry be merely to test the truth of Garbut's statement, there can be no doubt of the result ; but it is difficult to understand why the solution of this question should necessarily involve the question of whether the story of Leichhardts death, as related by the blacks, is true or false ? Until the result of this investigation is made

public, it would be premature to make any further observation ; and I think that the Herald would have done well to have acted upon this principle. If it were possible that the story of this man Garbut could obtain credence after intelligent in- quiry, Mr. Hely's report must necessarily become mere waste paper. But this result is not to be thought of, I apprehend ; and, supposing that the examiners report Garbut's tale as altogether in- credible, than circumstance can add no further value to the report of Mr. Hely, which will rest,

as before, on its own merits.

I should not have troubled you with this but for the manner in which the Herald apparently strives, in the paragraph alluded to, to establish the accuracy of Mr. Hely and those who think as he does in this matter. Your reader, will, no doubt, agree with me that, whatever may be the

result of this inquiry, it is not intended as a test of the value of Mr. Hely's expedition ; and, as resident within the district which Leichhardt made his point of departure, they will probably form and entertain their own opinions as to the

efficiency of all explorations hitherto made in search of the missing traveller. Of this I am sure, that very many " experienced bushmen" in your district believe that no satisfactory informa- tion has yet been obtained.

By inserting this letter you will oblige,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

AN OLD BUSHMAN.

Sydney, May 5th, 1857.
heading: DR. LEICHHARDT. To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

articleText:
MARYBOROUGH WHARF.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,-My attention has been called to a letter in your issue of the 29th ultimo, written hy our 'Police Magistrate, Mr. Arthur E. Halloran-and as that gentleman ha* therein chosen to make my name subservient to his object of misleading the

public- and my conduct appear questionable in- stead of his ow-n- I have to beg you will do rae the justice of publishing this.

Early in March last I was elected Chairman of a Public Works Committee, which had been form-

ed for the purpose of vvatcbing over and assisting 1 in the expenditure of the grants of money voted

for improvements in this town nnd neighborhood by the Legislative Council, and in this capacity I n't once wrote to the Minister for Land and Publio Works, and to our Member. The latter with his usual energy lost no time in acquainting me, that ho entered i'nlly into our views-would co-operate with tis-bad called upon the honorable Mr. Hay, who nppioved of our proceedings-and recom monded that Mr. Halloran should be requested to join tho working Committee

On the 1st of May Mr. Halloran attended a Committee meeting, and upon being asked whe- ther he had received any communication from the Government upan the subject which then called us together, lepliedin a most supercilious tone,

" 1 havo receivod a letter !"

You will bear in mind, that so far the Commit too had only indirectly heard from Government that their proceedings were recognised, and were most anxiously waiting a reply from the honorable Mr. Hay to my March communication.

Upon the 21st May an unprecedented fresh in tlie river earned away the only wharf which

the public hero hud a right to use. The inhabit- ants then urged upon the Committee the greater necessity for the works commencing, and in con- sequence I was again directed to press their wants upon the notice uf the Government, in the hope that some reply would be given us. On the 27th May I accordingly wrote to the Minister for Land and Public Works. You can imagine my surprise when I received in return, not only the courteous

reply from that gentleman marked No. I, but a copy of his letter to the Police Magistrate, marked So. 2, both shewing that Mr. Halloran hid long been in possession of the information the Com- mittee so much wished ; and the lntterinforming us, that as one of the Bench of Magistrates, I ought to have been consulted, according to my reading of the instructions IT gave the Police Magistrate. You will observe the Minister's let- ter to Mr. Halloran is dated 22nd April. On the 1st May that functionary attended a Committee meeting, at which time he was in possession of that letter. Shortly after he left for Sydney carried apparently that answer in his pocket and to this da.) ive must infer that neither the Bench or the Committee would have heard of its existence, lind not Mr. Hay thought it necessary, in explanation of his own conduct, to send us a copy of it. '

Had that letter been properly made known had the Police Magistrate co-operated with us had ho done his duty in fact-shown less official jealous.}-more courtesy-and more candour

vlaryborough would bo in a very different state socially and physically-to what it is.

But Mr. Halloran's explanation is so incredible, that those who know the full particulars of the subject, are amazed at bira and it;-and though from long acquaintance I am not likely to be thrown into this condition, I must be permitted to "astonish the Government and the publie by saying, that so soon as ever I received those let- ters from tho Minister for Lands and Publio Works, I cavried them to the different members of the Committee, and particularly to tho one Mr. Halloran allude« to, when he says, " I did, how- ever, show the letter to ono of the Committee, a surveyor"-therefore it Is impossible his charge of my suppressing information can have a particle of truth in it; and as " this Committee-man and surveyor" did not inform mo that Mr. Halloran had even showed the Minister's letter to bim did not, at any subsequent meeting of the Com- mittee, announce that ho had seen it, I will add, that I sincerely hope that Mr. Halloran has done him injustice likewise.

Mr. Halloran would shiel 1 his conduct under

the announcement that he has been a great many

years in the Government service. One would have supposed that the leisure ho lias thereby en- joyed, would havo enabled bim to acquire the art of thinking, and accusing correctly, would have implanted in bim some knowledge of the require- ments expected from magistrates to magistrates -and from a public servant to tho public. That' ho has failed in the first his false accusations

against myself, and coarse language ngiinst vour correspondent, piove ¡-that ho has fuilcd in the second, tln.se who havo met him ns ficquently on Bench matters as the magistrates hereabouts, can testify ; and that ho has failed in the third, his truly unollicial epithets of slanderer-poltroon malicious falsifier, &e, &c., and his whole conduct in this wharf business amply indicate.

Nothing can be further from my wish than to appear prominently and in print before the public. The unjustifiable mention of my name was as un- expected ns Mr. Halloran's reflections upon itwero unjust and offensive. And my only apology for intruding so much in these respects now, is be- cause I feel it is due to myself and others to refute those unfair explanations and assumptions, and to clear my own character from even the suspicion that his curious language and peculiar reasoning may affect it.

I reranin, Sir,

Your most obedient servant,

EDMUND B. UHR.

East Maryborough, 8th Sept., 1857.

No.i.

(corr.) -

Department of Land and Public Works,

Sydaey, 12th June, 18S7.

Sir,-Tn acknowlcdlng tho receipt or your letter of tho 27th ult., forwarding a copy of a resolution passed at a meeting of the committee for superintending Uublio Works in the Wido Hay District, n lativo to the necessity for the immediate erection of a public Wharf at Mary- borough, I am directed to transmit to you the accom- panying copy of a communication which has been ad- dressed to Mr. Halloran the l'clico Magistrate, on the subject of Publio 'Works goncnilly in that Uistiict,and to inform you that ns the sum of Ave hundred pounds hna been voted in the Lo in Act for the present year for the construction of a Public Wharf at .Maryborough, Mr. Secretary Hay lins been pleased to authorise that «mount being placed in the Joint Stock Bunk, to the credit of tho llonch of Magistrates at that place, for the purpose of onablln; lln-m and tho committee alluded to, to carry out

tho works in question.

I hare the honor, &c,

(Signed.) MICHAEL FITZ PATRICK.

To Kdmimrt n. Uhr, Esq., Chairman Public Works,

Maryborough.

No. 2. (corr,)

Department of Lands and Publie Works.

Sydney, 22nd April, 1857.

Sir,-Provisions having boon made by tho Act of Par- liament 20 Viotorla No. 33 fur the construction of the rforui al Publie Works cnuinera'cd in the margin* in the dlstilctof Wide liny, I inn direct«! by the Honorable tho Secretory for Lnmls and Public Works, to request that you will havo the goodness to roport on the part of tho Bench of Magistrates how the WorkB can best bo carried out, thero being no officer of the Colonial Achi teots Department in tho District.

2. I am at tho same timo to Invite your attention to thofnot that aiomnilttro nppo'ntcd hy the inhabitants of the district, of which your coll ague Mr. UhriB Chnlr man, havo nddressi'd Mr ?? crjtnry Hay through Mr. Sanileman.M.P. oflerlng thiir nosisfvnee. ; and It occurs to Mr. liny that it mlgl t be ndvisablo to Invito with yourself and Mr. L'hr. such other gentlemen as the committee might select for the purpose of taking upon you Iho survo linn o of (he vvoiki. Such a course will probably bo BiitIsfa<'tory to the inhabitants who ara tho persons most interested, and to tho Government which is of courso anxious that tho money provided by

Pnilliimoiit should bo economised and turned to the best

account.

3. If this courso wero adopted, tho Colonial Architect would, ns regards tho buildings, givo sur-h professional ncshlnnco, nu it may bo possible tor one at a distance to nflbrd, anti to nimbin Iilni to do so, ho should bo informed of nil pnitlenlnrs as to tile natiiro of tho sites chosen for such buildings, the matcilals to lie used in their cou tsrucllon, tho extent of tho accommodation to bo af-

forded, &o,

I have tho honor, otc.,

(Signed.) MICHAEL FITZ FATPJCK.

To Arthur D. Halloran, Esq., Pollco Mnglstrato, Wlä»

Bay,

*For tho erection of an Immigration Depot,

Maryborough .... £250 For Improving the navigation of tho bnr

entrance of tho Uiver Mary, from

tho mouth to tho Township . . 500 For tho construction of a Publio Wharf,

Mnryborough ..... 600 For f'o ereotion of a Court and Watch

articleText:
/ ) , , , .THE a

SATURDAY, MARCH 14, 1857. ft]

PARLIAMENTARY REFORM. ti

jf ia pretty commonly acknowledged that the Constitution of New South Wales re- quires amending in several important ?points. It could scarcely to otherwise. ¡Considering the dubious nature 5f the nullifications possessed by many of the jnemfrers of the old Assembly for the work of constitution-making, their anti T)ro°Tessiv-e tendencies, and the imperfect manser in which publio opinion was re- mounted under the then system, wo can- not bo surprised at the Constitution being " found defeotivö in many respects, and at

it* foilino- to meet with tho approbation of the people. The wôiîi of framing a Constitution for a rapidly-rising eOiPny like Now South Wales ought not to havô been entrusted to a clicme or class, .but «tn»Ut to have been shared m by the re

;Sntat?ves if the whole of the inhabit-

ants of the colony. The Legislature of that day did not represent public opinion, and on that ground it has boen assorted that it was not entitled to ant« a consti- tution for us. The Solicitoi'-General himself is of opinion that the old As- sembly was not competent to deal with the matter. It is too late now, however, to disoues this question ; the people have

»till the power to alter the Constitution.

{o mt their present wishes m require. I

lo, ed

nients ; and with this privilege let thom

be content. ' ^

The Electoral Reform League, recently established in Sydney, is likely to do great good in drawing attention to the important subject of Parliamentary Re- form, Without reform in the electoral

system, it ia very questionable what be- nefit we arc to derive from " responsible government." It seems to have been the aim of the framers of the Electoral Act, while malting it, to all appearance, very liberal, and founding the franchise on nearly a universal basis, to encumber the exercise of the latter by many and vexa- tious regulations, and to swamp the popu- lar voice by unequal and arbitrary divi- sions of the elcctoial districts. Thousands of nominal electors-especially single men -have found themselves virtually dis- franchised by the clause enjoining six months' residenccin one house. In theory, the Act goes very nearly the length of universal suffrage ; would it not be well at once to recoguise every man of full age as entitled to a vote, and thus remove the petty annoyances and sources of dis patisfaction which at present exist ? We nie satisfied that it must come to this ultimately; and we are glad that the League has taken the matter up, and insists upon manhood suffrage ; the only qualification being six months' residence in the colony.

Rut the most extended suffrage would be totally inadequate without a re-divi- sion of the clecloial districts. Wc entirely agree with the League that equal electo- ral districts, based on population, is the just principle of representation. We would like to know how the Colonial Se- cretary's systom maintained on a bond of interests, could be carried out; where' " all interests should be so nicely balanced that each should have a fair and equal share of representation." It would be rather a puzzle to fix op the importance or value (ever-changing), of the various interests in the colony ;-the squatting, the mercantile, the agricultural, the dig-* ging, the mechanical, &c. If one poor shepherd is, as Mr. BUCKLEY says, worth as much to the colony as fifty mechanics, what must be the value of a shepherd king himself? Mr. BUCKLEY,-a store- keeper, a mei chant, merely-would have to hide his diminibhed head before the "noble of the land" Such ideas are not woith controverting; but they show to what absurdities people are reduced when they neglect the plain teachings of common sense. This theoiy of inteiest "g I is about the most absuid idea we ever

'j'1 heard propounded, even in a colonial Lc

"¡1 gisldtivc Assembly.

It has been shown that a thousand men taken indiscriminately from any part of the country would be equal to any thou- sand men in any other pait in regal c1 to piopcity. This might seun a fair objec- tion to those who maintain that, by tak- ing population as the'basis of représenta- tion, the rights of property would be sub- verted. But this is not the real objec- tion to tho population system. Our Go- vernment is squatter at heart ; and it is desirous that the squatting element should pievail in the,Lci;islature, as it has pre- viously done. What could bo bettor adapted to secure this than the plan of arbitary electoral distiicts? Than the system of enabling some half-dozen set- tlers, with their dependants, to return as many representatives as would fall to the share of a thickly-peopled locality ? If we want the land-monopoly removed, and our resources fully developed ; if we wish to see the government of the country con- ducted for the benefit of the whole peo- ple, as it ought to be, instead of for the ad- vantage of cliques and intciests,as it has always been, our representative system must be modelled on the basis of popula- tion. By doing so, we not only adopt tlie easiest method, but at the samo time property will bo best represented.

Wo suppose the originators of the re- form movement did not wish to encumber their programme with too many measures. This will probably account for the omis- sion of the ballot, which we consider an important auxiliary in the electoral sys- tem. In Australia, we aie happy to think, there does not exist the same urgent necessity for this protective moa sure as in the old country j but cases of undue influence being exercised must be of frequent occuircnce hero too, and it would be well to give every protection to the voter in the conscientious exercise of his right. The ballot has other recom- mendations besides its protective pro; pcrty. In Victoria^ it, has been shown that the elections which took placo under the ballot were much more quietly con 'du'eted than' they, had been previously under the old system. ?* The Leaguo.may, net wisely in cpnfining their attention at present more immediately,to the suffrage and to the electoral divisions ; but wo hope to see the ballot introduced before long.

Tho late decision of the Assembly, that all deliberative bodies entrusted with le- gislative functions ought to be elected by the people, is a strong indication of the speedy downfall of the nominee system, and shows that the desire for reform among the members of the "Lower House" is more general than might have been imagined from some of their pro- ceedings. Wo do not believe in the co- existence of a representative and a nomi noo Legislature. The two must, from tho nature of things, often como into collision. The pretensions of our Upper House have already been evinced in the desire to inter- fere in money matters,-a privilege which the English House of Lords has long since relinquished With the Assembly within, and the people without, both opposed to the continuance of a nominee legislature, jt may safely be affirmed that the Upper House, as at present constituted, will havo but a very briof existence. It will bo a

matter for futuro consideration whether

a second chamber is really required for { the purposes of legislation. I

These are some of the roforms whioh

we believe rnuS.t take placn in our parlia- ? ^ montary system boiCTG we can «suppôt to j Soo tho government of the country cairied on (is it ought to bo. The Moreton Buy peoplo have perhaps less interest in the matter than tho inhabitants of other parts of the colony; for there is every reason

to tliiiik that Sepwfttion will bo cwuplot: L v

ed before these measures of reform can bccarried out, and we will thus cease to have any direct interest' in the govern- ment of Now'South Wales. But we are

also convinced, that with a liberal con-, stitution and government in New South Wales, it will-be impossible for any clas3 legislatureJor government to maintain it- self for any length^ of time in Moreton Bay.

THE ]

' ]

SATURDAY, AUGUST 1, 1857. 1

? . - 1

DEATH FUNISHMENT.

, Oua attention has Leen painfully called a

io the subject of death punishment during t the present week by the kno\y]edge that a r human being has been destroyed among 1 us in obedience to the stern behest of our f criminal law. Whilst men rose to pursue r the varied avooations of life, whether for r gain or pleasure, another of their race was s awaked to taste the bitterness of an ig- n nomiuious death in the flower of his age, v unripe in all things save in crime. The 1 expediency of death punishment has for t; some years past engaged the earnest atten- li lion of jurists and philanthropists, and e many of the wisest and best maintain its h inexpediency, and recommend the adop- ii tion of some secondary punishment. Hap- le pily their opinions have so far prevailed f<

Mil. i ii ^tammnaeBxaanmÊmimBmammmmmmimmimammam

. that the penalty of death has been re

j served for iw ¡murder; instead of being, as in former

dayi, the convaon sentence for crime of --¡ almost every ¿rade. Until Romilly suc

e ' oeeded in hiA merciful endeavors lo reform

. j the Engliih'Pfiii»! Code, the poor wretch

,' who lifted ha'f--. -yatd of ribbon from ¡t i ¡ shop couatjr, o' Blo.le .1 sheep, suffered the

¡/¡une pu'iiihm-'iit as the vilest mtirdeier ! The progtssi oi enlightenment has cor- rected the error, which made all crime ! equal in degree,and visited every criminal

alike. Abolished as it has been for crimes

of a lighter dye, men begin to ask why retain deatii .is a fitting punishment for " I he murderer? What end dowe seek , from the adoption of penalties for crime ? . On either side of the subject extreme 9 opinions have been advocated. Some

CJntendiiK: ¡nat the murderer has no right to live, and that society is under a divine ; command »oshed Mood for blood. Others 3 maintaining that society has in fact no . such command, and that man has not, . under any circumstances, a right to de , stroy his fellow man. Those who uphold j tile death-punishment,appeal to the Jewish » law a., a dmiie injunction, binding upon '* ns ; but if this be sp, we must accept-that t edi » ltrr. jiid inflict death upon those

who disobey their parents (an offence ¡ which we 'reit as venial) unless, indeed,

it can be shown that there is some com

' mand abrogating the law in regard to such

minor offence. For our own part we "adopt neither of these extreme opinions. '.We have no f ilse sympathy for the crimi îpal-noue of that sickly philanthropy . ; vSjhich weepiover the dying murderer,and

jfi?-.;*ts hi'; dead victim. Nor do we hold 1 ! "..it?- tifjie who consider the main design , of »punishment to be the reformation of

the culprit. We believe, on the contrary, i that tho primary object of all punishment ? shiuld be the protection of good men

against evil doer1;. If, then, the safety of j human life depends upon the death of the i) murderei, we believe that the law may,

i as a matter of necessity, require his life. 7 But if, on the contrary, the reformation ,' of the offender will belter secure that end, , then ive say our discipline must be re i formatory. In older, however, fully to ' justify itself in taking life, a community

1 must be satisfied that the crime is not a

. fruit growing naturally from some of the \ peculiar institutions of their own framing.

Tf they have for their own purposes mul- tiplied the means of degradation and neg , lected the holier influences of education

, and moral teaching, if gin-palaces abound ; ! whilst schools are sparely scattered through :

the length and breadth of their land, how can they count themselves free to destroy one who has been corrupted by these evil

influences'? Take the case of the un-

happy man Ti-.jn.gle. He was sent out to this country as an exile when only 13 , yeais old ! Nineteen years have rolled

away, during part of which he completed liii servitude in the society of men older in years and more advanced in villainy than himself; and the remainder of his brief catcer was spent in drudgery, and devotion to the lum-bottle ! Cradled in

' crime, all his evil passions trained to ' their full development and fired by ardent

spit ita, nhat followed, might almost have

been foreseen 1 We ask

'- ._" When tlio last account 'ttvixt heaven and

eaith

la to bo made,"

how much will society claim credit for on

this miseiable man's account? The

1 question between the criminal and society

.should thus be placed upon the founda- tion of strict justice, If the punishment > of death operates in any way as a safe ' guard to society, it can only result from Í the terror it is supposed to inspire de "x terring otheis from committing the crime

. to which it is attached. Men do not - commit murder except under the influence ' of some overmastering passion which di-

vests death of all it.s alarms. There is . something in life more terrible than > death itself, uheu the grave is even ' anxiously coveted as a desirable relief, " rémoise of conscience, keen poverty, dis , »¡.pointed affection, and almost every form ; of human suffering, will make the miser ) able accept death rather as a boon than " a thing to be dreaded. We believe the

I ciiine of murder is to be repressed, not so

\ ¡ mucn by making mau afraid of death as ' i { by showing him that even in the hands '

' ¡-of the law it is a precious jewel not to be '

i lightly cast away. We would have him \

r educated both by precept and example, .

! j to logi.d human life as sacred. When '

. | we consider the weakness of human judg- . 1 j went -nid the great danger of trusting to

a circumstantial evidence, an additional i j motive is supplied for pausing before we 1 i incur the heavy leapt nsibility of taking

j human life, and probably placing it be ? j youd our power to íestore to liberty, and

[compensate, one who may afterwards be j ¡noved to have been innocent. No en-

lightened jurist or lawyer would maintain that society is called upon to avenge the killing of any of its members. Revenge - is not known to the true spirit of laiv. " This is a power which the Almighty has . reserved to himself alone : " Vengeance

is mine," saith the Lord, " I will repay," ; and in mysterious ways, which the know ,' ledge of man does not enable him to pur - sue, the great purpose of divinewisdom ¡ is, we are assured, accomplished.

! The law, by adopting private executions

has abandoned its attempts to teach mor ? ality from the scaffold. Nay, at its very

foot, undismayed by the lesson thus brought before their eyes, thieves, profli- gates, and the most abandoned of man- kind pursue their evil courses. We do not believe that any means, purely human, will entirely uproot the crime- of murder. We conceive that the adoption of a second- ary punishment would tend to diminish the number of cases, because it will be

more certain, as juries will be less unwil- : ling to convict where their verdict is not : followed by a sentence of death. The ' moral sense of the people is evidently op- 1 posed to capital punishment, when jurors < shrink from convicting the prisoner of 1

murder. The mau who has been con- I

victed of murder should be imprisoned for I life, without hope of regaining his liber- ( ty, and deprived of all those objects which I he sought to gain by his crime. If his < early education has been neglected, and t he has been left to grow up under vicious 1 influences, some relaxation might be al- t lowed ; but no man, with the blood of his c fellow-creature upon his hands, should be I

?»?/?. ? ... , ?_

let loose upon society i this boon should bo reserved for those alone who, after a convic- tion are discovered to be innocent. We would urge at least a trial of abolition,

and the substitution of pome other mode of punishment. Stich an experiment must, of course, be carefully made, with ample . appliances for obtaining accurate statisti-

cal information as to its effect.

We observe, in mtnnetuns instances, - and in TiíAüix's case for one, I tie mur- derer had been under sureties to keep .the peace on account- of previous threats and acts of violence. Such mea should 'be

under the surveillance of the police, so far at least as to prevent publicans sup^ plying them with drink. We really think that some law. to this effect would save many from an untimely end. ;

SATURDAY. DECEMBER 26, 1857.

OUR ex-Premier DONALDSON lias evi- dently imagined himself to be a political oracle. When the people of the North asked for Separation, ho said J' No," and

then . i

"Jlope withering fled!" ;

But, we have outlived his oracular nega- tive, and hope soon to see the advent of our separate Government. A few months ago he piraded himself before the House, on introducing the PARKER-DONALDSON, budget, as a perfect financial Wizard. We took caro at the time to shew, that he was moro "juggler" than "necro- mancer." . But tb.e hobby-horse which DONALDSON dreams ho rides well is

j Finance. Tie is iuflated with the pom i pous idea tlint ho is a Southern reflex 0/ I the mighty PEEL. Shade of that sainted I politician, what a resemblance ! Person-' j ally we may concedo some likeness j ALEXANDER STUART DONALDSON is i\_ i burly man, he fills the same space in the world's oye:-bodily-that PEEL did j but 1 when we look for the mens divinior, th* ¡ Qobler part, that which proves the gifted

politician, the far-seeing Statesman, 01 I the warm-hearted patriot, we find only ' The long-eared member in the lion's skin, ¡ PLEL 011ts.de, but DONALDSON withm.

j Mr. DONALDSON'S highest conception of

the management of finance is, io be able to borrow. Beyond this his ideas have I never ranged ; bo has never believed the 1 possibility of managing the business of

the country so ns to preservo it from au overwhelming burden of debt. To b< , able to borrow, DONALDSON must havf t an adequate security-ho is sufficiently j " up" in finance to know that-and ac I cordingly, when the available pledge foi ' future borrowing is fast becoming "small by degrees, and beautifully less," his spirit is troubled; and when he brings in his budget ho ruefully declares he sees Separation as " a dark cloud on the horizon." Littlo did we imagine, some months ago, when wo were demolishing tho Herald's pretty story about a part- nership between Moreton Bay and New South Wales, and its various other silly fallacies that we wero in fact replying, to the Premier himself, who had trimmed the lamp of the Herald to give to tho world the light of his wisdom, on the Separotion Question ! We have heard a whisper which accounts for the strange similarity wo had noted, with some misgiving as to tho authorship, in the opinions and languago of the ex Premier and the Herald on this subject. Mr. DONALDSON is stated to bo the writer of the leaders in that journal. Wo aro at no loss to discover the cause of tho marvellous bitterness of those pro- ductions The great financier is loth to see the lands of tho now colony removed beyond the power of hisloan.iaising sor- cery, no longer

Touched by the Judos-fingers of the state, Bleed -gold for Ministers to sport away.

But whatever Mr. DONALDSON or tho

Hernia miy Pay or rrife, wo feo! i^u'Oiî I that Separation is a settled question not ' to bs re-opoued even by Uli* roi.owdl of ?.se ' eUhu on-the part of Mr. VrE\iwoatn I and his fellow deben'I'te-Uubbrq vhidij we exposed at the time it ' ,1 »i do a¡- ¡ more pclitic'vl move to del..1 y Ö u a..oon < This <xacstiop if feecurity may, bowevt... ,

be made a protest for one^ <) ']< I iy j

We felt astonished juid iiuhcaaut ou

roteiving our 1 ist'advk o í l'i cm ty J i.< y. i ( s,e <i J Üiöllwlld Ct ." MJ. r JS . ,, i had reived in one long d'.utr.be, , l"i

transmission to England, the whole .of

those unfounded statements, transparent j

fallacies," and unreasonable demands / which "we have denounced at inter- vals a3 they appeared in the columns of that journal. Shall we inflict on our readers the three additional dreary columns, which the task of travelling again over thoseihallow objections would involve ? Wc certainly will not. There are only a few novelties in the Herald to which we deem'it at all requisite to ad- vert. .These are equally discreditable with the rest of its assertions. We took occasion last week, but necessarily in a hurried manner, to glance at them. By tho way we may obesrve that we have stood alone from the beginning in denying the justice of making our lands a security for the whole public debt of New South Wales, [f. is admitted by the Executive Council of that colony that we cannot be justly jharged with the debt incurred for rail- ways, sewerage, and water supply in and near Sydney. Wah what justice than, we would ask, can our lands and conso- lidated revenue be given in mortgage for 'hat debt? The inconsistency is too glaring to require further exposure.

Those who havo boen anxious to pur-

chase speedy Separation, at any sacrifice, may now see bow much it is likely to cost tbem. A bold front should all along have been maintained. If we yield *a inch to Sydney, wo shall lind no limit to har demands. The concession of any- thing more than a rigidly just appor- tionment of the public debt, will give

rise to exorbitant demands. It is mani icst from the tone of the Herald that there

is a party as strongly as ever opposed to Separation ; who will oppose it, delay it, or do anything rather than complete it. Imagine the cool proposition to retain Moreton Bay uutil the public debt of New South Wales is paid of ! In what year of grace may that feat bo accom- plished ?

Mr. DONALDSON and his supporters in Lho House endeavoured to impede the passing of the Debt Bill, the only measure which stands between us and Separation. The ancient Sydney game of delay and shuffles is to be played again. We have ilways*maintained that.tho clausbin Mr. Labouchere's despatch, which reserves the division of the debt for the Function of

Her Majesty's Government, was au es- sential protection to the New Colony. We never folt easy at being left in,the hands of New.'South Wales. We thought, however, when she had the power in her hands she would havo been anxious to secure a fair adj ustment of the debt. We were not preparod to find any party in the Colony, much less tho mighty DON- ALDSON, advocating a refusal to legislate ! "Wo observe now" says the Herald (or tlie ex-Premier) " that we are under no obligation to legislate." Wo observe then, the British Parliament have power to set it right, and you may, if you will, leave it alone. We shall not got a worse bargain by going home for it. Among the uovclties sug- gested by the Herald are a request to the Home Government to guar- antee the public debt (!) repudiation by Moreton Bay, and consequent insol- vency and repudiation, or " the sponge," by New South Wales. As to repudia- tion by our neighbors, wc can only say they know their own business best, but we hold that tho Northern colony will pay its share. With regard to a guar- antee of the public debt, the Biitish Lion would most probably grin at it, if the Kangaroo presented a "bit of paper",for his acceptance or indorsement.

[Sinco the above was in type wo have íeceived later news. By tho dissolution of Parliament the Bill has been lost. Wo, of course, are thus deprived of the opportunity of appealing to the Home Government uutil the Colonial Parlia- ment positively refuse to legislate. To this it will doubtloss come at last, as the Sydney press expresses a hope that thoy aro relieved fiom it forever. The Empire now shews its true colors.]
