i" OCR SHARE OF THE PUBLIC DEBT.

j We publish in another column the des- 1 , patches of Sir W. Denison relative to the

i boundary and the publie burdon of the ^ j new colony. The deoision of the Seore- F ; tary for the colonies on the boundary o . I question, has made the chief feature of » i the Governor-General's despatch on that ï

point familiar to our readers, and the " ' views of the Northern Colonists upon the l

matter, have bceu already placed before ' the world. The despatch of tho 5th < l?ebuary last is new to us. Wo have c waited anxiously for it. Our experience, \ 1 in connection with tho boundary dispute, '

only faerved to strengthen our anxiety in <. regard to the apportionment of the pub- ' lie liabilities. We may frankly admit ^ dint wo were scarcely prepared to 1 find it so equitable and just as it appear* ' to be in its main features. Wo took oc- i ension in our issue of the 5th of Soptom- l ber List, in our remarks on Mr. Donald- t son's financial statement, and in subse- t . {uontissues,tolaydown tliogonorulprinoi- ' pie which wo considered should govern the ' livision of tho public debt between the 6 two colonies. 1

Tho despatch is identical with the opin- * ion we then ventured to express. Wo ^ i'laím no credit for this, inasmuch as our £ views woro only the irresistible conclu- £ sions of common sonso and common 1 'loneaty. Wo may, however, bo excused '

for hiivipg doubted that tho Governor« I1

at General would make a just apportionment or of the public debt when we found the ,ie ministerial journal, our old friend the °" Herald, urging lüílt we should bear a Tn portion of the Sydney railway expenses, ah «ti the grouud that we were parties to '" the bargain. It would seem, however, en that the motion of Sir W. Dexiso.v on ¡J1,! the "greatcopartnership" between More- ll- ton Bay and New South Wales, differed "*" materially from those of our contetn «b porary. It is we^> an(l tue people of

.Moreton Bay can mention it with pride ht and satisfaction, that they have not asked

« for more than was strictly just. We ,rt have urged that we ought not to pay for ¿" Sydney or Ilunter River Railways, or for id Sydney Sewerage and Water Supply, aud « these the Governor-General has by a '" stroke of his pen swept away. We have '*'. shewn that the only items fairly charge ie able against U3 are for our share of Im al migration and Public Works, in fact for ot any sum specially expended for the

1(? benefit of our district. So soon as we

io saw the claim of Mr. AVe.vtwoiitii and

id other debenture holders to mortgage

the lands of the Northern Colouy » for their advances for Sydney railways, bo we protested against its injustice. The "J Governor-General, although he.does not v- think it unjust, appears to deem it iuex 8t pedient and unnecessary to claim any 1,1 security on this account upon our public to lands. Should the balance, therefore, on

?d a statement of account between ourselves

ll> aud New South Wales, be against us, '' our lands will be charged only with the ," liquidation of such balance, and not it held in pledge for the whole pnhlio ".i burden of New South Wales. We }* showed at the time that the public ere e'a ditors knew that these advances were re 1\ quired for Sydney purposes, and we con iji tended that tho lauds and general ro ei' venue of our neighbour were justly *l chargeable with the whole, and were w indeed sufficient for tho purpose. We ?h are glad that the Governor-General holds Hl the same opinion as the people of the j¿ northern Districts. We were not sur- tí, prised that our money-loving patriot

; Wentworth should advance such a claim. '? That astute gentleman knew as well as tl wo did that his protest was ' what we r. designated it " a mere move on the part ig of Sydney politicians to delay Separation

*< and to embarrass us in our endeavours to

*' establish the new colony." On reference ,. to clause 3 of the February despatch it e, will be observed that the Council of the I»- Southern Colony wish to state the "j account in 3uch a manner as to charge ;r us with our share of the expenses of the t. general government. We should be Jl fairly chargeable with a proportion of the 1'" money expeuded for that purpose, but tlte

difficulty would be to ascertain what suras = could be placed to our credit for' the

receipt in Sydney of taxes on articles al imported for .consumption by the people

or of these districts. The Governor-General

desires to avoid the " interminable dif

,,. ficulties" of this portion of the accounts it- and accordingly ho neither debits us with n- the cost of the general government nor "'. gives us credit for our contributions to %l the general revenue. Had these parti in oulais beon entered into it is possible the

state of tho account might have been 0' greatly altered, but whether to our ad-

vantage or otherwise it is not possible to " asserí without sufficient data.

If the Government are unable to trace

the necessary particulars, either colony 11 must submit to the loss as the case may m be. We shall, so soon as opportunity . serves, impose upon ourselves the labour li of prepariug, as far as the figures may !r' come within our reach, an approximate

account under this head. The state of

"J. this account and the knowledge of the

Sydney Government on the subject, if rd the balance be against thom, and they '1 should be aware of it, would destroy the

justice of the despatch on this point. '£ It suffices, however, that in all essen-

tial particulars the views we have enun bv ciated in regard to the division of the ~* debt have been founded on just principles ld and not upon more popular clamour, ii, We are inclined to believe that by

the proposed plan of taking the account, '- the balance against us, when the details

are gone into, will be considerable, but - when compared with the extent of our re-' - sources it will be a mere trifle ;.and it - is clear that in the event of any separa-

tion from us of districts to the northward 0 they must bear a proportion of the bur 1 den should it then remain unliquidated. 3 We trust, however, that such an occur 4 renee as separation from us is far 5 distant, and that the government 5 of the new colony will endeavour to _ avoid it altogether by an equitahlo

expenditure of the public revenue. Every item of the account with Sydney must bo scrutinised by our members.

_ Wo hope that thoy wiíl be on the alert,

and that every assistance will be givctr to them by thoir constituents.

POLITICAL AOITATION.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bag Courier.

Stn,-Tho meeting in the School of Arts on Mon* day evening last, convened to toko into considera- tion whether Mr. Holt, our member, should bo requested to retain hissent, exhibited several fruits of-character worthy of some notice.

The gentleman who proposed tho resolutions favorable to Mr. Holt urged, among other matter, that he, Mr. Holt, had been instrumental in getting a branch of tho Joint Stock Bank established in

Brisbane, which lightened tho depression, took oif the screw, &c. The proposer of the amendment, who is a Director of a rival bank, in alluding to this said, it seomed to havo taken the screw off bim, meaning tho proposer of tho resolutions. Surely such personal allusions from a Bank Direc- tor regarding money mutters on n platform, comes with a very bad grueo ; mercantile and financial transactions are not safo in such leaky vessels as this gentleman seems to be.

The proposer of tho resolution» on that evoning has fought the bailies of the pnblio cv £? sinco ho carno to tho colony. He opposed tho renewal of transportation to these shores when, lind ho con- sulted his pecuniary interest, ho would havo been on tho other side. Ho strenuously opposod tho wealthier classes, and aided in tho return of tim lato Mr. Jones as memberfor tho Stanley Boroughs. Did ho then consult his interest? Or was it not the interest of his country rather ? Did he deriva any pecuniary advantage from his exertions in favor of Dr. Lang when that gontleman was' re- turned for the County of Stanley ? and when this leaky Bank Director was doing iii) ho possibly could for Mr. Hodgson ? His motivo beinjr, to use his own words, " Mr. Hodgson would oblige me, and why should I not obligo him?" The insinuation that he, the proposer of theso resolutions, was under any pecuniary obligation to Mr. Holt, was vory much out of placo, and uncalled for on such au occasion, as all bis publio exertions havo been for the good ol' the community, whllo the exertions of tho Bank Director has been for self.

But, Sir, combination of parties nt. tho nhovo meeting was really wonderful. Tho general dealor in Qticon-sti cot backed uptho merchant in Whnif street. Thus showing tlittt whon mi innocent man is to bo accused and condemned, partios who were formerly nt viiiinnuo can unitoover their victim in thoso days as well as thoy could in lho days of Piluto and Herod. While moi o recent transactions nilli reference lo n certain document, addressed to Mr. Holt, sho.iv a want ol' common honesty in tho camp of tho non-contents, and entitlo them to all tho credit they can take fioin knotting that thoy havo lho sympathy and tho support of tho impcui

tont thief.

It was tho opinion of many that tho chairman of tho mooting was clvvlro-biologixcd, mid his bum]! of numbul' somehow preyed. Be that as it may, when ho counted thu votes ho must havo been clairvoyant, vido his Iel 1er in tho In ee Prêts of Wednesday last, when ho kin w a man'M quulili ention as an elector by tbo sight of his hand, for IIB could not, in immy cases, heo lho face, oven if lie would know alitlioi'lecturs iii tho three towns! ! It is to bo rewi'ded to Mr, Holt's credit that uouo

of his opponents could point loone objoctvotmblo voto given by him during tho session, except that one" regarding tho bound try, or 30th pirallel of latitude, which landina.k u in a. hit way of be- coming as immortal n.a llarney O'itetrdon's Noi

flist course.

I remain, Sir, tours, .te ,

AN OBSERVER.

Brisbane, July 2nd, 1807

articleText:
' %iJ-nU)AY, pCTpBfel J /, 186?. t

v '" LAND,"TliANdi«'iIlW.

Hk'im&Ê appeared An^i^^\j.ehGfßio:^eui Ä^ftho lïoi? i st rár "?a fc -Ä üc lil i jiiiiiî ;.aib,üífít»-^ tlio

iuâè#i."gï:-cbiiï^^^^

opinicu, will;'íUpefw^'A^lf-;¿^";)^!3¿cnt in use, aa<r,OQü'fet;úpou tUe'-puröIiasei? tv valid title at a trifling cost; <

Although many great and important improvements have been made in this branca of the law, it is still by its teoli ' " nicaUies, and the prolixity of its forms,

a great hindrance to the expeditious dis Eopal of landed estates. It will, perhaps,

ardly be oredited, that in England no general system of registration is in éx wtçnoe-the evidences of title remaining . in , the custody of the ostensible pos ; wssor-and many able lawyers maintain

that it would be dangerous to establish a registry in that country, as it would cx Sose titles, to tho designing, who would

c enabled to take advantage of any de -? feet which would be made patent upon ,... tie f*ce of the registry.. We need hardly

/(«ay.'.thiat this danger could be easily ob i- TJat«d by limply recording the name of "s the.present possessor, and the description

of his eitata, and tho danger of any future .weakness of titlo would be effectually

. "rdeâ against by the clear evidence -.: -.'.o;,--..> ..*!'ph\;ai'íystem would afford of :[\,-JA???.!!. I!.' U' '?-.?'i': tha title/ so that there ,-, y 'j''; " : "T:r:---.-,^"danger of parties '.'? -x A.'>?.??> .'??.:?.' -"»ssary. to give

E.

before tbo lapse of years and frequent j

change of possession shall have exposed titles to the danger of getting involved, that we should establish a system of con- veyancing which shall at once free us from this hazard, and recommend itself by its economy and safety.

it would be late in the day to argue chat registration must continue to be

iart of this system. It" is recommended ?y the protection it affords against the

iss of the muniments of title by acci- dent, robbsry, or fraud, their destruction, ir their alteration by forgery, for to all

"tese perils they are constantly exposed vii i 1st they remain in the hands of the owner of the estate or his agents and unrecorded elsewhere. The system of registering in this colony is Alphabe- tical, but from the frequent recurrence of the same names it is found to be ex- ceedingly defective when a search for any of the registered conveyances becomes necessary. The Registrar at Auokland it appears has devised " a Numerical sys- tem of Registration not encumbered with any of the difficulties to which reference has just been made, nor yet with those under which thealphabetical mode is weigh- ed down, namely, the accumulation of par- ties holding the same name, and having by the same tedious process to ferret out all tlio various instruments which have re- ference to the same property. The Nu- merical system, though it provides a separate designation to every property and every subdivision of the- same as clearly defined as No. 1 Î3 from No. 2, at the same time provides »hat all be entered conscoutively in the same book, so that any one of them can be as easily arrived at as the other. It, virtually spoaking, provides but one designation for all ; and again, by its mode of opera- tion, it follows that if you are in posses- sion of the number which has been en- dorsed by the Registrar upon any one of rhera, you have the key which opens the title page assigned to that particular pro- perty, where at a glance you see the wholo chain of deeds which have been registered affecting the same. By this din pie contrivance-although the pro- perty referred to may have been cut up into 250 original pieces, and each of these again into as many more-still a refer- ence can be made to any one of them with the same facility as to the original, and by any party, however inexperienced, ns well as by the Registrar himself, simply by plaoiug in his hand the Book of Num- bers, and such a search c»n bo made within the spate of two minutes." The Regis- trar does not enter into the details of his

plan, but we can easily believe it to be perfectly practicable by means of a change

of numbers-whioh admit of almost in- finite permutations-to identify every parcel of land with all its subdivisions, however numerous these may be. Such a system would result in making the Re- gistrar at the same time the-Conveyancor, and would in effect supersede the inter- vention of a Solicitor. Tho registration ivould likewise be the conveyance. If iny deed passed between the parties, it would merely declare that "AB trans- fers his property to CD," and this would be followed by the registration number. ¿The parties might add the usual sur- veyor's description. This would reduce transactions in land to the level of any other -kind of commercial dealing. AB and CD might walk into the Registrar's office and transfer landed estate» as easily fa^they could buy potatoes or corn. Such seems to be the practical end of the Numerical system. We desire greatly to see some simplification of our present conveyances. " I have in my office," says the Registrar, " a deed 254 folios long, alienating a small piece of land. I fancy I could have reduced the whole, with advantage, to a single folio !" Con- veyancers, in the introductory portion of their deeds, make a practice of reciting or shortly stating the contents of some of the previous title deeds. Where the deeds ure not registered this is absolutely ne- cessary, and even where they are, the usage cannot bo departed from in all cases. The registration by making every part of tho title a public record, almost avoids the necessity of recitals, and con- sequently shortens the conveyance and diminishes its cost. Under the Numeri- cal system, however, the conveyance would be little more than a " bought and sold

note."

Thus far we have traced the proposed plan of the Registrar and its assumed consequences. Wo feel the great hard- ship of imposing on a man who buys £10 worth of land the necessity of a transfer which costs him £5 or £6 more. We

believe the Registrar's system sufficient where the transaction is a mere sale. But men dispose of their property in many other ways besides by sale. They .make wills and marriage settlements, and ojther instruments changing and affecting property in a variety of ways, to gratify their vanity or caprice. The law has made a tvill for every man. It gives the real property to the heir-at-law, and the personalty in certain proportions to the next of kin, It leaves, however, to every man the option of disposing as he thinks best of his possessions, with certain re- strictions required by public policy. Ac- cordingly, as he ha3 some one to disin- herit or another specially to advance, he makes a disposition of his estate oontrary to the usual statutory distribution. In many instances tho objects of his gifts cannot possess them until some deferred period, on attaining ago, ¡fee. Now to apply the concise plan of conveyancing to these cases would be somewhat difficult. We do not say it would be impossible. We merely throw out these hints for the use of any person who may have given his attention to this subject, and to show that men have themselves in some mea- sure to blame for the existing complica- tions in the law of real property. The Registrar docs not appear to have glanced at wills and settlements in his communi-

cation to the New ¿ealander. We gather from his letter that he ia a "Captain KEW/V," and probably his knowledge of the more recondite portions of the law is not very extensive. It seems to us, how, ever, that whore a conditional disposition and not an absoluto sale of the property is made, there must bo something to sup ^ment his present plan, that the Regis

. -«14 gag ¿t ¿iäouit to COiabiüe

with his ooloo the functions of the Con veyancer, and that the state of the title could scarcely be ascertained in " two minutes." There are also many changes of ownership not affected by deed or will, such as the death of parties, some of them under agc, a?d others leaving issue, &o. Now for all these accidents some provision must be made in order that the state of the title rri'iy clearly appear upon the re- gistry. When we view all these difficul tjes_although we do not consider them insurmountable-we seriously recommend that any such sweeping change in the ex- isting practice should be made cautiously , and by some persons fully informed . on ? the existing law, and skilled in its prac-

tical application.

$ïj? îtafott $ag jlaiimr,

SATURDAY. NOVEMBER 21, 1857.

20 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

S; -

8"' - FOREIGN LABOR.

FOR two-or three weeks past there lins appeared, in the columns of this journal, an advertisement intimating the intention of Mr. BUCKLEY, the member for the Stanley Boroughs, to introduce into this district a consignment of Basque, or Swiss laborers. To tho commercial aspect of the proposed immigration we 'have, per- haps, no right to allude. It may bo rpf no consequence to the people of this district whether these Basque and Swiss peasantry aro to be brought out for mere commercial profit; whether they are brought hero under contracts binding them to a life-long travel with barrel organs, to a perpetual exhibition of white mice, or to follow any other of the numerous "light employments" in which these continental gentry excel ; whether they may for awhile prove useful in tending sheep, or whether they may shortly disappear from the service of their employers and re-ap- pear on new scenes as foreign " barons," or " counts," or " captains," with vast imaginary possessions to correspond to these titles ; all these affect most the individual employer and are irrelevant to the question raised by this now announce- ment. We intended to have given earlier attention to the question, but the pres- sure of other matters has precluded us from doing so. Wo have no desire to shut out the native of any country from coining here to seek his livelihood. We would glnilly welcome the really indus- trious foreigner who should come among us and givo us the benefit of'his know- ledge, industry, and skill, in whatever art or profession he might be able to ex- ercise them. With so many industrious and well-deserving countrymen of Locicn UAUDr in our country wo would notrniso an unmeaning cry against a man simply be- cause he is a foreigner. What we object to is tho wholesale importation of rude uti

k lied la^ioi fiom a foreigii countiy. Wc have no tyrâpatliy willi tlie paitip.vho

seek this d<"5uiption of labor. Tlicy are j general'y, if not cntiicly, of tlic pio-l transpoitallon party, tho«e who would I deluge us with the feloniy of tin mothei-. country-and who «odld gia-,p at clieip labor, fur which they are perpetually craving, although it might reduce the wnikiiig man t~ the level of a meit bca-sl of bin den, toiling for food and shc-1 ter only. 1, We svmnathLe with the emigration «y-, t tem, which will relieve the mothei-couq

try of its poor, and bring the willing hearts and strong bands of Great Britain to toil for us, and receive a fair îeward The men who would introduce whole cargoes of foreign peasantry seek to keep the working classes in a state of semi starvation, reducing wages by a deluge of labor of the cheapest description. We pity the foreigner. These men deceive and victimize him too. They engage

l3 him in his own country at a price which, ho although it seems a princely sum ilicre,

is greatly below the real value of his ': labor here. The man quickly discerns

that be has sold his only birth-right

his bone and sinew-fora mere "mess of

pottage." Discontent and desertion fol- low. We do not point these observations at Mr. BUCKLEY-A or 13, or any other dealer in foreign labor, will serve for an example. ,

We consider itiíangcrous to the best ¡I interests of the community to permit any to citizen to establish a wholesale system of

foreign immigration into this country without the supervis'nn and control of our Government, to be exercised both here and in the countries from which M he immigrants are to be procured. What guarautec have we that the immigrants do not bolong to the class of felons? How easily may we be deluged with the crime of foreign countries !

o In this way Australia may have poured

' into her lap the villainy of the half of

Europe. We have made a long struggle against the'deportation of criminals from Great Britain into these colonies. Shall el we be more content to receive the felonry ,r of Germany, Spain, or Switzerland, and

to place it in competition with free British labor? Will the men whoso lately peti y tioned for British convict labor scruple >.}' to circumvent us and introduce the cheap ,s labor of the foreign criminal ? The smug-

gling of criminals into' another couutry is no novelty in the history of the world, and a foreign prince could not be blamed for clearing his prisons and his galleys if he found a merchant willing to íelievc ii him of the trouble and risk of such a pro- of cecding or simple enough to be made the

unwitting tool for woiking out such a '¡f scheme. "We do not say that'such a sys at tem is actually in existence among us,

but, simply that .wc have no guarantee that it is not, or that it may not arise .under the proposed or any other plan of foreign immigration by private enterprise. The " anticipated partial cessation of emi- gration from Great Britain," which is the ostensible reason put forward for the Basque and Swiss immigration, hasnosup port in fact. Emigration from tbe motkor counlry bas not either wholly or partially ceased EO far as the colonies generally aro concerned, nor is thero any reason to sup- pose that it will; and if it had, there is no necessity to travel so'far as Spain, Switzer- land^ Germany,for labor For sometime past the labor market of Victoria has been overstocked, and by the Litest ac- counts from that colony we learn that several ships within a few days bad added 100O souls to the population of Mel- bourne. The want of employment in that colony has so largely increased the number of abandoned females as, in the opinion of the people of Mel- bourne, to call for a legislative remedial measure. As we have an acknowledged demand for labor in this district, and single men and women are readily on gaged, why should we not drain off some 13 of the surplus labor of Victoria ? But H suppose that the Government emigration jjj from England had entirely ceased, could l7 not a Bupply of British labor be

t7 obtained by private enterprise, instead I 9 j of Basque or Swiss ? Britain has

stronger claims upon us than other coun- J tries. A British population is most to be desired, and the most profitable labor is that which wc obtain from them. The es- timates for the en-uing year propose to appropriate a sum of £75,000 for the in- troduction of immigrants from the United Kingdom, and we have yet to learn that there is . any necessity to resort to the foreign labor market for a supplyof hands. With so many of the industrious poor at home, of our own race, who might be in- duced to come to this country and give us the benoßt of their services, we need not resoi t to the wholesale introduction of the foreiguer.

articleText:
THE

SATURDAY, JUNE 20, 1857.

====================== rj

PRISON DISCIPLINE. \\

THE Report on Prison Discipline, recently published by order of the Legislative Assembly, though somewhat lengthy, is well worthy of a perusal-not only on ac- count of the information that it contains of the actual condition and mode of work-

ing of the prisons and penal establish- ments in this colony-but also for the sake of the suggestions it contains for their improvement.

It is a " vexed question" this of Prison Difcciplinc,-various systems have been tried in many countries with varied suc- cess-and in the position in which we are in this colony, it is a great advantage that in trying to improve our own vre can refjr for our guidance to the results of the working of other systems elsewhere.

All the good systems of Prison Disci- plina recoguiso work as their basis-not woik having no definite object, or only the object of punishment-but work with a vi«w to instruction and profit j to assist in the reformation of the prisoners j-.and to help to defray the cost of their main- tenance; punishment, with a view to the prevention of crime, being of course the chief end ; reformation and profit sub- ordinate considerations, but still if pos- sible to be conjoined with it ; particularly when wo find thut competent authorities lix the proportion of incorrigibles at only S'K per cent, uf tho entire number.

The birbarous and now obsolete sys- tem of the tread-wheel had in view nn.lj» ~. ,,.*...O11.U1UM0 ui nie prisoner; and its effect generally was to rouder him a greater criminal than before, by degrad- ing him, and rendering him by a natural ab >ociation, averse to all labor; for though work has a beneficial effect on the moral as well as the physical nature of men, it has this beneficial effect only when the emi or object of the work is what we may call moral, i.o., useful and profitable when this object is neglected, and work is enforced solely as a punishment and degradation, it defeats its own intention, and instead of helping to the prevention of crime, it helps to the propagation of it.

With regard to tho prisons and penal f-tablishments, and the system of prison discipline at present existing in this co i lony, we find that there are seven gaols | and two penal establishments; the gaols j ,'ituated respectively at Sydney, Parra i matta, Maitland, Goulburn, Bathurst, j IVisbanc, and Berrima, (the latter unoc i cupicd) ; the penal establishments at

("kokatoo Island and Newcastle.

In none of the gaols does there exist means for tho employment of the pris- oners-with the exceptions (and these only partial) of Sydney and Paramatta ii' all the other gaols the sentence of im- prisonment with hard labor becomes less ..jvero than that of imprisonment only |( j" because in neither case does the pris ) I n'ner .work, while the one sentenced to it j hat d' labor receives a much superior and

¡nord expensive ration than the other."

Another evil is that in none of all the

gaols does there exist means for the pro- per classification of tho prisoners. 'During .the day-time, they are supposed to bo ^divided into six classes iu Sydney-gaol j out of Sydney there being only the two classes-those who ave sentenced to im

prifionraeut only, and those sentenced to imprisonment with hard labor-but in nil tho gaols the prisoners herd together at night indiscriminately; and when wo consider how many classes may bo brought together iu a gaol-from the juvenile offender and common drunkard to the invotorate and trebly convicted felon, wo can easily f.moy what are likely to be the result* or the effects on tho less

guilty. The disciplino at tho penal es- tablishments is different from that of the gaols-the prisoners being entitled from good conduot to a ticket of-leave, and being also allowed to shorten the period of imprisonment by task-work; both of these principles arc considered objection- able by tho Board.

Tho system recommended for adoption by tho Board is tho Auburn or Silent System of America.

Tho Auburn or Silent System, and the Ponns3'lvanian or Solitary System, aro tho two ohief systems ¡n operation in

A monea.

In the Auburn System, each prisoner has a soparato coll, in which ho takes his meals, and sleeps, and spends all the time not engagod in labor ; in the day timo all the prisoners work together in sheds rangod round the prisou yard, but a pro- found silonco is obsorved, and inspectors are stationed at intervals to see that no communication of any kind passes be- tween the prisoners. Any broach of tho regulations is puuislied. by flogging and.

confinement in their Sells with short allow- ance. This system is recommended for adoption with the exception of flogging, which as a means of coercion is aisap proved of>

under the Pennsylvanian System, the prisoners are confined separately in cells by night and day, the cells being large enough to serve as workshops. Each prisoner is conducted blindfold to his cell, and,sees no one save his keeper during

his confinement

The effects of this species of confine- ment for a term of years on the mind and body of the prisoners are so injurious, and with other objections the expense is so onormous, that this system is not re-

commended.

In both these system?, however, and indeed universally the principle is recog- nised that useful work rai'sfc l)ô enforced -not merely for punishment, but as the meanfj of reformation-and to encourage this latter object, it is purposed that each prisoner should rooeive & small proportion of his earnings, and if they exceed a cer- tain amount, that a limited portion of his term of imprisonment should be re- mitted. The portion ofearnings received by eoeh Would serve to maintain him after his discharge, till he could obtain some honest employment, the want of

which often drives to the renewed com- mission of crime. The advantage of the third object contemplated by a sys- tem of labour, v¡£., self maintenance, is strongly marked in a country like this, ?where labour generally is so scarce, and so costly, and where in many places the most necessary public works are wanting.

It is too bad to see the labour of hun

i dreds of able-bodied prisoners absolutely

wasted, while the roads in some places, or rather the want of roads, is such that the traine is liable to be interrupted by every rainy day thatooGurs; and this too when the country is faying at the rate of <?25 per annum for supporting these

men in idleness.

It is scarcely- possible to conceive any place in a more primitive state with re- gard to such necessary public wi.rks, as streets, roads, bridges, &c, than Brisbanfc and its vicinity. It is strange to kee a town, the capital of a largo and flourish- ing distiict, so long in existence without even an attempt to form the streets, much less to metal them. We question if ever any levels have been taken of the streets, so that a person building now in any stieet cannot bo sure that when the street comes to be formed to its level, his

house may not be several feet either above or below the centre of the street, to the great injury of bis property.

The uumber of prisoners usually con- fined here may not be great, but such as it is, if thoy had been employed constantly in such works as the formation and repair of the streets and providing metal, the

streets of Brisbane and the roads in its neighbourhood would present another appearance than they do now. A town or district surveyor to direct where and how such works should bo performed, is a want that should have been supplied long sinos.

O-t. ",:i", tl»o augglibtlOUSTOnilipiu-r.

ing tho system of Prison Discipline con- tained in the Report would tend greatly to remedy if adopted, as may be seen in the case of the State Penitentiary in Columbus, in the United States, conducted on the Auburn or Silent System, -which is the system recommended for adoption here by the Board appointed to report in the matter. This prison containing on an average 500 confines iu addition to de- fraying tho expenditure necessary to sus- tain it, contributes a net revenue of 20,000 dollars annually to tie State.

The whole question of Prison Disci- pline, in its widest sense, is peculiarly important at the present time when the ablest men of the mother country seem at a loss to kuow how best to dispose of

their criminals. And we think that in

an improved system of Prison Discipline will be found the only satisfactory solu- tion of the question as to the continuing transportation. Physically it must end some time, from the want of suitable places for transporting convicts, but long before this, we apprehend, it must cease from other and moral causes, for no free people will tolerate near them anything so dangerous to the morality and well being of the community as a regular re- ceptacle for all the concentrated villany of another country. Mr. FORBES, the Visiting Justice of the Paramatta Gaol, who has been one of the chief movers in this question of improving prisons, de- serves great credit for the zeal and acti- vity with which ho has brought the

attention of the Government to boar on tho matter.

KATTUDAY. DECEMBER 19, 1857.

SYDNIiY AND .MORETON HAY.

MORETON BAY enjoys a large chare of Sydney attention at this moment. Whe- ther we ought to feel flattered or uneasy io not doubtful. Whenever Syduey poli- ticians have turned" their eyes towards the Northern Districts it has been for the purpose of looking after their own

interests. And now when we aro about to leave thom, they cannot conceal the ohagrin which the approaching Separa- tion occasions. DONALDSON makes an onslaught upon the Northern members because they refrained from voting upon the "five shilling clause" in the Land Bill, and ho is followed by lawyer FAU CETT, wbose virtuous soul is indignant at what be is pleased to designate " the dis- creditable conduct of the Northern mem-

bers." This cowardly cur, whose political capital consisted of a cheap profession of li- beralism on his arrival in this country, but who carefully sneaked behind the scene in Ireland, where his stock-in-trade was treated as dangerous sedition-now comes to light, in borro»ved feathers, as an " Irish patriot," and presumes to sit as censor upon the conduct of men who, with all their faults, are more honorable und holiest than himself. Aud then with brazen impudence he attempts a feeble Kcply to Mr. BUCKLEY'S reminder that ho, the immaculate FAUCETT himself, had " on an occasion in that Ilouse, after promising to vote in a certain way, ab-

sented himself on the division !"

The Northern members should have refrained from voting, not only upon this clause, but upon the whole Land Bill. They had a perfect right to take the position they did, and to say as their constituents would have said, had they been directly appealed to, " Give-us Se- paration, and we will enact a land bill for ourselves." But they should have taken that stand from the beginning. There was less occasion for Mr. DONALD- SON'S remarks, as the votes of those gen- tlemen would not have affected the result of the division. We apprehend it is not imperative on members to take part in every division of the House. The only legislation we require from New South Wales now is the enactment of the More-

ton Bay Debt Bill ; with the passing of that measure, so far as any legislative act is concerned, our members might ab- sent th?msclve8 entirely from the House. They, probably, had in view the reten- tion of the present Ministry in power, so that no time might be lost in pitting tho Debt Bill. So long as their votostended to subserve this good object, aud were harmless to Now South Wales, they can- not be blamed, and, indeed, deserve the

thaßkj of tliOir coBStitllOOte, «*V

Our I»**bt Bill, now kiure the Umuc, iiulit.uü-> the intention of the tfydue) lenisliiture to carry the accounts bet« con the two colonies back to the year 1842. Of this, we will not complain piovidcd tliorc accounts be fairly taken. "We do, however, protest against the attemut to render this colony liable to the extent . ' the whole debt in the event of the iu?ol vency of New South Wales. We ;,latV.) quotf tbo views recently cqiri' .M1 on this point by several witnesses before the Select Committee on Railways. They fully accord with tbo. view wbicb ha¡^ been held by this journal, although the} do not embody the whole of the argo meats which we have enforced against tho attempt to pledge the lands of the now colony for more than a fair propor- tion of the public debt. Mr. WILLIAM BitowN, Director of the Bank of Austral- asia, says,-" The separation of Moreton Bay tnigbt affect a loan at first, but not when all the circumstances came to be known. The remaining security is ample, provided the public debt is limited to a certain amount within the next twenty

or tbirty years." Mr. JAMES HENDER- SON, Director of the Bank of New South Wales, says-"The separation of Moreton Hay might, in lingland, be looked upon w a ¡»lire tiikcn off the security, but in iJie c iloiiy the present colonial resourci s uuild be regarded as ample, even nl'iui -eparatimi." Mr. J. A. JACKSON, In- spector of the English, Scottish, and Au

traliun Chartered Hunk, says,-" Tin eparation of Muretoti iîay would dimi

.'tish the security to be offered by tin colony, for though the remaining terri

tory would lie ultimately valuable, i1 migbt not prove so till a' distaiit date." The whole effect of these opinions' is, " your estate is ample" for present de- mands, and even for further expenditure, but you must be economical." The ne- cessity of exorcising a strict economy would be a wliolosoiTio discipline for New Sou til Wales. With the whole public burden guarauteed from the new colony, what is to prevent the Sydney Govern- ment going on as heretofore, and becom iug hopelessly insolvent ? The Herald presents a new phase of the question :

We are «rind to see, at nil events, that the absurd and scandalous claim to discharge the territory ot Moreton Bay fiom its liability to the piiblio cre- ditors is not likely to be admitted. No doubt, our legislation can be neutralized,-and the Pailiament of Moreton Bay can repudiate. We should be extremely sorry to seo u crisis when the holders of dcbentuies might bo obliged to go to that territory. But the Ciown ouyht toyvar antee the fulfilment of this obliyatitn before as stntiny to the conditions of this bill. It is the Crown as nell as the other branches of the Legis- lature whioli has gi anted the retenues of Kew South Wales as the pledge ot tho debt; and the Crown will violate its pioper function if it impose on the creditor any, even the slighest, trouble in his claim beyond tue original terms of tho con- tract. We do not think the bill does place those who have trusted their money to the public faith in a situation us Baie ns at present. We aro aware that some tiho profess to defend the in- terests of Moreton Bay snap their lingers at all these obligations. We cannot help tbis. Let us, however, seo that nothing is done with our assent inconsistent with tho public faith, and let us cast on tho Secretary of Slate tho responsi- bility for accepting for the public creditor less than was promisefl to him under the sanction of a constitution established by the Pal Hument of England.

Does it not occur to tho Herald tbat

"repudiation" might begin in Sydney? And where is it so likely to arise as in a colony which can thus coolly anticipate its own insolvency ?

How happy would the Herald be to make this Separation an excuse for ask- ing the British Government to gurantee the public debt of New South Wales ! Wo fear tbat journal has made a mis- take and given us a portion of a leader a few months iu advance, when tbe old colony may be going in earnest to beg a guarantee or advance from the Home Go- vernment, and when, possibly, their re- fusal may drive lier to "repudiate " The reluctance of New South Wales to re- lease the new colony from unjust bur- dens on account of Railway expenditure may be seen in the following reply of Mr. JOHN WATT, to some anxious en- quirer before the Railway Committee. " There are some districts where the Go-

vernment might wisely incur debt to make | railways ; others where that would not be the case. The expenditure, though lo- cal, would benefit all, inasmuch as it would add to the general prosperity of the colo- ny. Northern settlers would gain by a southern railway, inasmuch as it would make food cheaper, while a market would be opened up for the sale of fat stock

from the north."

The "general prosperity" of the country under the debt is manifest in the present depressed state of its finances. We do not believe that we would gain by a railway, made to carry certain legs of mutton and rounds of beef, to Sydney. JBut bow, Mr. Watt, would northern settlers gain if this îailway wero formed it a distance of 500 miles from thom? Watt's affection for railways may equal that of his renowned namesake, b>* -ic must give us some bet- ter proof of practical judgement.

The Government and press in Sydney begin already to chafe and fret under the restraint imposed by Mr. LABOUCHERE'.« assent to the equitable recommendations contained in the Governor-General's de- spatch. In two particulars they have receded from that document, one of them the making the new colony jointly with New South Wales, and severally by itself, liable to pay the whole of the public debt out of its revenue-the other, as to the date of commencing the account.

[Since writing the foregoing, we have received our latest Sydney files. The Herald, in its issue of 10th December, intended for transmission by the mail to England, has a long leader which verifies the anticipations we have expressed above. The Herald desires the British Govern- ment to guarantee the public debt ! What a disgracefully profligate people will this journal make the colonists of New South Wales appear in the eyes of the Home Government! They will cer- tainly, when they read this violent nr ticle, consider that insolvency and " re- pudiation" aro iramiuent. The "guar- antee" is the pith of the leader, but the greater portion' is taken up with quota- tions to prove this indisputable proposi- tion, " that the Separation of Moreton Bay is against the wish of New South .WAles," WbnttboB? Wh/tlw^TmrW

wil' nu* " -,io,\ t'iittlie people of Xevr Ninth Wiles have until 1 itely beet» sup poiteil in the belieÍ that the Sepas atton ?A oui c1 not take place until some remote ppnod " And tlieoe aie put foi wird by t', < leading journal in the colong *¡r rea

ior delaying the consummation of a A meaMire of iustice ! Supv^se Se i «.lion to bo di-fcmd, will the I.riti'h

,,i minent guai&ntre MoieUu Bay againtt New Soutb'Wales íunning moro deeply into debt, and pledging its lands still further ? We fear the loss of the Bill on the third readiug, when the people of the North will be under the necessity of forwarding to her Majesty's Govern- ment a most indignant remonstiance, »vhen- the credit of New South Wales, bad now, will be swept away for ever, and when, we trust, the Home Government »vill exercise its undoubted power to frustrate if not to chastise any insolent attempt at spoliation. Let New South Wales beware how she acts in thib mat- ter. The power that made can unmake her, and she may find a heavier reckoning against her than her present public debt.

SATUßDAiT. DEOEMBER 12, 1857.

THE MORETON RAY PUBLIC DEBT BILL.

o-t

THE Ministry have at last introduced the Bill which is to regulate the division of the public debt between the colonies of New South Wales and Moreton Bay. We published the intended Act, as intro- duced to the house by Mr. COWPER, in our Supplement on Monday last. The character and number of the accounts to bo taken are specifically sot forth, but the details are left to future investigation and arrangement by commissioners to be nominated by the two colonies. The first and second clauses dispose of the public debt for sewerage, water supply, and other public works, by confining the liability of each colony to the amount actually expended within its terrriiorial limits for these undertakings. We are thus relieved from the burden of railway expenditure, except, ofcourse, for the surveys which have been made with a view to the construction of any railway, within our own territory.

The third clause relates to the nature of the account for Immigration expenses. Two preliminary accounts are to be en- tered into under this head :-The first is to shew the whole number of immigrants for whose arrival in the colony our money has been expended, and of the respective numbers who have remained in or pro- ceeded to any part of the territory within either colony. The latter portion of the account will, we imagine, find the com- missioners no trifling amount of labor. The second account is to shew all moneys arising from territorial land sales, and in the third, which is to be prepared from the two former, each colony is to be debited with a proportion of the immi- gration debt, equivalent to the number of immigrants ithas received and is to be credited with an amount equal to one half the proceeds of its land sales. It does not appear for what puipose the re "raaining half is to be retained by New South Wales, whether for the ex- penses of surveys, commissions, &c., of'whether our credit is tot be for x>ne-half of tho gross or net proceeds. The bill is rather loosely worded in this

section.

The fourth section fixes the liability of each colony in proportion to trie number of its inhabitants at the time of Separa- tion, for the outstanding deficiency, under the Act 20 Vic., No. 1.

The fifth section regulates the division of the current revenue and expenditure of the colony, and the proportion to be borne by the colony of Moreton Bay. Five accounts must bo taken under this section, commencing from the 1st January, 1842. First-An account of all moneys which, within the sixteen years from that time, have been specifically contributed to the revenue by the peoplo of Moreton Bay. Secondly-An account of all moneys, not before mentioned, specifi- cally expended upon the people of More- ton Bay. Thirdly-An account of the average population in each colony during the several years of the same period. Fourthly-An account in which Moreton Bay is to bo debited with such an amount of the general expenditure of New South Wales in each year of the period, and a proportion of the year of Separation, as shall have been in proportion to the popu- lation of the new colony in each year and to be credited with the like annual proportion of the customs' receipts. Fifthly-An account current in which áfareton Bay shall be credited with its specific contributions under the first ac- count, debited with its specific expendi- ture under the second, and debited or credited, as may be necessary, with the balance on the fourth or general revenue rand customs' account. Tho balance, if against us on this account, is to be borne and discharged in like manner as the amount which may be duo under other sections of the Aot. If in our favor, wo are to have credit for the amourft.

It will be observed, that in taking this general revenue account the Executive Council have adhered to their own views, and departed from tho despatch of the Governor-General. " They advise," says his Excellency, " that a sort of debtor and creditor adcouut should be drawn up, in which the new colony should receive credit for all the revenue, from whatever source arising, which it may hnve contri- buted ; while it should be debited with all the payments made for local objects ; and also with a fair proportion of the cost of the general government,-that is, of the cost of all those departments which have no special local attributions, but deal with the colony ns a whole. In this suggestion of the Council, however, I cannot concur. I do not, in the first placo, consider that it is founded upon correct principles; and I am afraid, in the second, that it would lead to inter- minable diificulties between the two co- lonies." Assuming, however, that it is intended to take the account in the man

56,

<c.o

if»i< i

Der 'proposed by the Act, we see no other practicable method ol' ascertaining the balance due from this colony than hy the several accounts mentioned in the bil!, and by the principle of dividing the debits .vnd credits in proportion to the population. It ¡.corns clear that the ac- tual customs leccipls in Sydney, on Moreton Bay account, could never be fully discovcicd ' We will, however, by this pian ' ¡> nude to pay for the poorer dis- tricts 'A' Now South Wales, inasmuch as ow\ i we aro pi ok:My, in propoition lo our on3 population, the largest consumers of

goods subject to customs' duties.

The Bill assumes throughout that the new colony will be indebted to New South Wales, and accordingly no provision has been made for the payment of the balance if it should be found to be in favor of Moreton Bay. There is small expecta- tion of this being the case, although on the Separation of Victoria, we believe New South Wales was indebted in a large sum which-she has never paid. Perhaps it forms part of the " outstanding defi- ciencies," to which we are to contribute.

Clause 6 relates to the appointment of a Commissioner by each colony, with power to appoint an umpire, to deter- mine by arbitration "the several por- tions of the public debt to be borne and discharged by the colony of Moreton Bay." By clause 7 the proportions of the public debt, with interest thereon, payable by the new colony, shall be charged upon its Consolidated Fund, and shall be paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund of New South Wales, six months at least before the debts, of which they respec- tively form part, shall become payable. By clause 8, these payments are to be secured by debentures given by the Trea- surer of the new colony to tho Treasurer of New South Wales. By clause 10 the Act is to commence on and from the day on which any Order of her Majesty in Coun- cil, constituting the colony of Moreton Bay, shall be proclaimed in this colony.

It will bo remembered by our readers that sometime ago a claim was set up by certain Sydneypoliticiansto hold the lands of the new colony liable for the whole pub- lic debt, jointly of course with New South Wales. In the copy of the bill laid upon the table of the House and published in the Empire,

this claim wa3 embodied in clause 9 Sia W. DENISON in his despatch discounten- anced this claim. By the bill as at first drawn it was proposed to give the deben- ture holders a charge as well upon our revenue as upon that of New South Wales, making the latter, however, liable in the first instance to pay the amount. By tina arrangement it was possible that we, having given our debentures to the old colony for our proportion of the d°bt, might have been called upon to pay not only that, but also the whole debt to the public creditor, in the event of the Syd- ney Government failing to meet its en- gagements. We hope this will not pro- voke a smile from our neighbours, as they themselves, in their Act, suggest the possi- bility of a failure, by providing ngainsfc the contingency. We observe in oui local contemporary a copy of the Bill, which has been altered in this particu- lar. "Nothing herein contained shall in any manner prejudice or affect the security of any debentures issued by the Government of New South Wales or the absolute right and claim of any holders thereof to demand aud receive payment of the amounts thereby respectively pur- porting to be secured out of the consoli- dated revenue fund of New South Wales." Weapprehcud the debentures are charge- able upon the revenue of New South Wales and not upon the land in the na- ture of a mortgage, so that the above clause would relieve the new colony from all liability to the public creditor, and leave the debt chargeable only upon the old colony.

TO THE INHABITANTS OF MOKE TON

BAY.

articleText:
I "PROPER TREATMENT OF MORETON BAY> L

I To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier. \ L

Sib,-On the 9th July the Sydney Morning Her-

ald published a leading article whioh has caused ¡ : , fióme comment, professing to show that tho Sepa- j

ration of Moreton Bay from New South A ales was * very properly delayed, and that all that was really ' wanted at present was a sort of Municipal Council, ' ivith a definition, "by the Exeoutivo," of the ^ southern boundary of tile province. This article 1 haB already boen before j'our readers, who are able ' * fully to appreciate its mischievous intent ; hut I 1

wish to show how detorminatoly that intention has " 1 been.persevered in, and that it was with no light B ( Purpose that the article was composed. In the '

Nows Summary of tho Herald forwarded to Eng- ¿ ' land by tho Columbian, certain articles on lending '?

topics, whioh from timo to time appeared in that ' journal, aro re-printed, furnished with headings, t t; »nd having references at foot, so that they may t

la all ready for extracting by means of the sois- t sors, for convenient transference to the English A jwpors. Amongst the articles so dished up again

is the one alluded to, on the subject of Moreton ! lliy, and this (as the Herald's leaders aro or- t dinarily published without heading,) is now fur- g tiislicJ with a titlo quito in accordance- with the I spirit of theavticle. it istbis:-"Piior-Ett TreA'j": s uest of Moreton Bay." ' !

Tho probable coiiseqnonce, as foreseen, is thnt

tlits article will be'extonsively copied in the United t Kingdom, and that many ' ötnerwiso innocent ( / ninds will bo impressed with tbo Herald's pre- |

cious recipe for tho "Proper Treatment of More- i ton Bay." The fact, trilling as it may appear, ' shows tbo extremo necessity of untiring vigilaiioo i in watching and foiling the plans of the Î003 of t Separation. This insidious article will have gain- i ed n month's march on us beforo anything can bo \ '? done to counteract it; but the best antidote, t

though late, will bo a speedy transmission of tho 1 I truo state of the caso to the leading journals and '

Mombors of Parliament in England. If this bo i not done forthwith, such potions ns the Herald t

j Bolus will indeed bo tho " Proper Treatment of 1

Moreton Bay." t

I am, Sir, f

Your obedient sorvant. i

I ." " SCRUTATOR, j

articleText:
SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1857

THE COLONIAL DEBT AND MORETON BAY.

OUR readers will observe in our Parlia-

mentary Summary, the financial state- ment which has just been made by the Colonial Treasurer. Upon his ?????? ing Mr Donaldson is a kind of financial wizard before whose magic touch ?? de- ficits" disappear in the most easy way imaginable. " Who saved the money?" "I," says Mr D, "I saved the money;" and so on in a strain of bombastic egotism the wizard Treasurer sounds forth his own wonderful financial "tricks." We suspect, however, the assumed saving is more specious than real, and that the witchcraft consists in making it appear a saving rather than in its really being such. Our immediate object is not to enter into the financial statement general- ly, but to refer to the concluding portion of it, which affects Moreton Bay in par- ticular. We apprehend that the country will doubt the genuine nature of at least a part of his saving. He stated to the House that £10,000 appropriated would not be required, of which £4500 came under the head of the pensions to the Judges This is tantamount to saying that time has dealt lightly with the Judges, not afflicting them with any disability to dis- charge their high functions, and, that consequently they have not requited their pensions; but how the Government can claim credit for this as a real saving we are at a loss to conceive. How much more of the assumed saving consists of similar items, the Colonial Treasurer did not inform the House. We may safely say, however, that as regards the £10,000 the Treasurer showed the fairest side of the picture.

At the close of his reply to Mr. PID- DINGTON and Mi. RUSDEN he said the amount realised by the land sales was £15,0U0 per month-and expressed his

desiro " to sec the debentures placed on j such a footing that they might be cn- j abled to compete foi the uce ot British

capital on the ¿ame te ins as other coun- | tues " It sec nu, hovvr-w, that the j puncely possédions, of Moreton Bay aie after all the gi eat fun! by which the

liquid ition of flic colonial debt is to be I eflected. ï'be " cloud rising in the hori- zon-the threatened dibmemberbent of the colony"-was " most emphatically protested against,"-and the protest was, of course, received with cheero; for upon this, at least, theie is harmony in the House. " At all events," said he, " if the country is to be dismembered, More- ton Bay should take its fair share of the debt;" .ind then he put in a protest by

Mr. WENTWORTH and other debenture holders, which was submitted to the Sec- retary of State for the Colonies in Lon- don, and in which it is asserted that " the public lands in their entirety now form the security for the whole debts"-and " that the most valuable portion of the territory lies northward of the 30th de- gree." We give the various items for

which the debt was contracted :

Immigration . £364,200

Loans to Sydney Railway Company.. 217,500 Fuiclmsoof'HunterKivor mid Sidney

Ballway Compunios propoi ties. 233,400 Railway MOIKs- .;. 030,400 To pay off lund and immigration de-

bentures .7. 54,000 Foimnnont public works . 300,200 Sydnoy seweiage . -178,300 Sydney water supply,. 115,400

Total debt on 31st Heo , 1856.... £2,099,400 Now, we ask, how.much of this was expended for the Northern Distiicts? The following are the only items to'which they can havo any claim on\ us for con- tribution, viz. :- i i »

Immigration .....'.. £3~~G4,200

To pay off lund and immigration de-

bentures .?.'/.. 354,000 Permanent public works . 300,200

Total.'.-£718,400

')-!il

¡Our portion of this will bo small indeed if it is to be measured by the actual sum expended for our benefit. The arbitra- tors will look in vain -for any evidences of our having had our fair shareiof publio works-and our' contribution for immi

Sgration cannot be very largo Butj if we calculate our share upon the proportion of our population to .that of the colony in general, viz., one-twelfth-our pay- ment will be somewhat less than £60,000 j Sydney has received tlio benefit of more

than half the colonial debt.

It would appear, however, from the protest we have mentioned, with which Mr. DONALDSON expressed his perfect agreement, that the lands of the Northern Districts are to be treated as security with the " less valuable lands of the South" for the whole of the debt. Now we cer- tainly protest against this attempt to binden us with a debt which we do not

owe. Moreton Bay should secui o its'/air share of the public liability, and no moro. The debentuio holders-guileless Mri WENTWORTH and others who signed the protest-were all aware of the purposes for which the money was borrowed. They knew that these sums weie required to make railways, &c , for Sydney/ and wo

contend that those commercial under-

takings, together willi the geneial re- venue of New South Wales, should form th&wsecurity for their advances. 'More- over, when they made their advances, they knew that Moreton Bay Separation had been agitated, and that its consum- mation was a mere question of time. With this knowledge they could not look to the lands of Moreton Bay as their se- curity, but if they did, and wero parties to such spoliation on the part'of'New South Wales, they should hold only the security of the lands of New South Wales (as she will bo when separated; and her revenue, and we believe that these are sufficient ; and that the' claim of the debenture holders is a more move on the part of Sydney politicians to delay Separation, and to embanass'us in our endeavors to establish the new Colony.

articleText:
CHURCH SCHOOLS -THE MEANS AND

THE END.

To the Editor of t/te Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,-I need not apologise for asking admission to your columns of n few remarks upon a subject which lins lately been exciting some comment

amongst us.

It appears that certnin members of tho Church of England have resolved (in an overflow of zeal for lha cau-,0 of religion, only too tardy in its demonstration) to augment the funds required for tho erection of Church Schools, by a publio Subscription Bull.

Considerable aolivity is being- Bhown in the salo of tickets. Tho usa of tho Immigration Depot has been granted for the occasion. The brass baud engaged ; and* no exertion to render the affair the " most successful of the season."

It is reported-too truly I fear-that this

movement is carried on under the sanction of the Minister of our Church-that be has promised to graco tho Assembly with- his presenco-and to accopt in aid of the School Building Fund the prooc6ds of the tickets.

The announcement is a startling one, to nil who, with myself, havo buen accustomed to regard tho mission of the Church as snored, and to look to har ministry as tho chief means of "stemming tho tide of worl'dliness and hoedlessness, which is ever gaining force. It is no unusual thing ,to hear a a voice from hor pulpits prohibiting the slightest approach to the haunts of fashionable gaiety, and although not of those who look upon the fre- quenting of the ball-room n.s a sin, I confess to a feeling of shamo when I hoar of a Christian Minis- ter, who prays for tho deliverance of his flock from sin and conformity with the world's ways, thus lending thom into the vortex of dissipation.

It is urged, that funds aro greatly, needed for tho erection of Schools to supply the wants of tho distriot-and so they are-and I will willingly contribute, as far as my means will admit, towards suph an object. But 1 have yet to learn that the end can, in this or any other cause, justify the means ; nnd desirable though the objeot, it were bettor left uiiaecomplifahod, than attained in suoh

a way.

Most earnestly do I hopo that those whose zoal has been awakened in this mattoe, may again con- sider tho tendency of tho step they havo taken. " Except tho Lord build tho house, their labor is but lost Unit build it ;" und on a work began Hilder such auspices, His blessing can never reU.

Should they porsist, thèy will nlioniito tho hearts of many from tho Pastor, whom it is a duty to lovo anil rospoot j will add to _ existing causes of dissonsion in our Church, and inflict an injury on the cause of religion, tho oxtont of which cannot b8 estimated on this side the gruvo.

1 um, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A OilUKOUMAN.

15th July, 1857.

TUENA.-These gold fields are very dull, no paying ground Ins been struck of lite, if some- thing don't turn up shortly, \vn slnll lose the gn-iter part of our population. The Commis sionei's Paddock is a pet feet failure. I hear of no paity having stmi-kapiyingclaim. Croker's party have bei'ii suiklng on Graham's Point. I am afraid that the season is too fur advanced to work tho bed claims to advantage,-Goulburn

IkraUl,

articleText:
ORIGINAL COIUESPÍMDENCE.

THE BLACKS TU 1¡¡ ULAUÍV.S.

7b the Editor of the Moreton Hay Courier.

SIR,-I sill anxious to draw the attention of the public at large, and moro especially of those " of- ficials" whom it may concern, to the very Jax su- pervision exercised over our nboriginnl population. The blacks to whom I now refer, "resido at present in the immediate vicinity of our township. Ono's heart is fired with indignation at the filthy and indecent manner in which these wretched speci- mens of Immunity are permitted to parade our streots, and to come into contact with our families. Thejast eighteen months seem to me to present a decided contrast in this respect. Many of them now enter our town with scarcely n rag upon their b.ioks. It is a common sight as j ou walk up and down Fortitude Valley to witness men and boys playing at marbles, &a.~in a peifectly nudo state, -surrounded by numbers of our own boys and giris. The appearance, too, of the women is often most sickening and disgusting. Now, Sir, 1 am not a " new chum,"-my feelings are not those of a neophyte, for I have "seen moi e of the blacks than many ; but in the name of everything that is bright, and elevating, and becoming, and espe- cially in the name of common decency, I do most solemnly and earnestly protest against this shame- ful neglect. It is fearful to contemplate the effect which such a state of things must inevitably exort, if allowed to continue, on the morals and well-being of our children. The remedy for this evil is nt hand, and n very simple one it is. Let our policemen, properly authorised, do their duty, and it is obviated at onco. Ido sinceiely hope, that for the sake of tho public weal, something may be done to put nn effectual stop to these dis- graceful and demoralizing scenes. In illustration of my opening remark, 1 might refer also to the drunken state in which many blacks are permittou to leavo the town-lighting with their fellow blacks, and insulting the Knropeans they may meeton the road, 1 might refer again to certain instances of cannibalism I which are snid'to have

recently taken place among these same blacks, and the facts of which, I believe, are patent to many. Only imagine, no*', people being allowed to feed upon each other almost beneath the very shadow of our houses, and we standing by with our arms folded, and our tongues silent. But I forbear enlarging, as my more direct object in penning these lines is to seek, if possible, speedy redress for the grievous wrong mentioned above.

I remain, Sir, yours obediently,

AMICUS,

Brisbane, Sept. 22nd, 18.57."
heading: ORIGINAL CORRESPONDENCE. THE BLACKS. To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.
snippet: SIR,—I am anxious to draw the attention of the public at large, and more especially of those "officials" whom it may concern, to the very lax supervision exercised over our aboriginal population.

articleText:
TO THE PRESBYTERIAN INHABITANTS

OF THE NORTHERN DISTRICTS.

("Per favor, of the Moreton Bay Courier.j . j

EELLOVT-CHRISTIASS.-Sineo I addressed a few lines to you somo weeks ngo on tho subject of union among all Piosbytorians throughout the colonies, there has boen various changes in thoso bodies in Brisbane. Dr. Lang has purchased the houso known as the Evangelical Chapel, and wislios it to stand open for nil Preäbyterians. This is so far favorable to the great object of a union. But on tites other hand, what was known as tho Freo Church congregation in Brisbano, havo divided, and each worship as thoy aro lo- cated north or south of tho majostio river that divides tho town, separated by wator only. But to have threo distinct bodies, occupying throe se- parate buildings, and taking up the timo of threo ministers of religion in one small town whoro ono houso could hold thom all, and ono man with an ordinary tongue and pair of lungs could mako thom all hear him, is surely ono of tho ovils that wo might rotnedy hy a very little of our own solf-deniol, and by oxorcining a littlo of that oharity that vauntoth not itsolf, we might unite into one powerful, useful, and oxomplary body, showing something of that oneness which tho founder of Christianity oxpooted in his followers, to onduro tho " world, to beliove" his mission. But as wo aro now, wo aro smoothing tho way for tho apostato and'tho infidel who follow in the wake of Julian, who gùvO as One reason of his apostaoy, that " when ho saw tho dissensions of Christians, and thoir rancour against oach other, ho took ro fugo from these broils in tho quiet of Paganism !" Thoso divisions may havo caused in somo mea- sure by unskillfully handling that doublo-edgcd sword which, when brought to boar in a salutary mannor on tho consoionco, is powerful to heal ; but if othorwiso, it is also poworful to accomplish tho work, " tho strange work]' of destruction. And can wo look on tho divisions arising from our passions, and thus breaking us into fragment- ary cliques, without profound sorrow? Not only aro thero low that como to worship, but wo aro also çonsoioii3 of an absonoe-tho Groat Inhabitant is gone, tho extinct fires, and tho deserted shrinos loavo only the painful omotion that " hero God once dwelt." Vorily our divisions call for »Writings ani pon,d.erjngf} fa o^ret¡rem.eut8,

Now for all these ovils the remedy lies (under God) with ourselves. It is very evident now tim! the clergy cannot and will not effect a union, and it is" ju3t as evident that that union would be bé- néficiai to "them in a high degree They would bo better sustained and encouraged in their la- bours, would seo soma good resulting from their exertions, and their pecuniary circumstances bo much bettor rogulated. They nre now expected

to mako bricks without straw, and to build walls without cement. And in order to effect union and discipline, and also to assist tho teachers, we must stir up thoso who havo takon the "over-

sight" of the various churches in the capacity of I ruling elders. Thoy aro invested with tho man- agement, and this mattor of uniting is their pro-

vince. The teaching cldors have, as stewards of | the mysteries of God, and regulators of the im- mortal dostinios of man, momentous labors to at- tend to. Bat the ruling elders, if supported by

tho laity, can efùct moro than the teacher or | minister, because they aro, or ought to be, elected by all those who intend to submit to their govern- ment. They ought in thoso colonies to bo elected

annnnlly, as was the case in Scotland until about j tho middle of the 16th century, and is still prac- tised in France ; while in Holland and America,

in tho Dutch churches, the election ia every two I years. In Scotland now, tho office is for life, and thÍ3 custom his been introduced and acted on in Australia.

In these colonies, however, elders should be olected annually for many reasons.^ We aro so migratory in our habits, and are receiving contin- ually fresh blood among us, some of whom would annually become available, and wo would also got rid of an indolent and unsuitable person, as such would not be re- elected. We have, moreover, a good few among every bJdy, who have a great talent for grumbling at every proceeding dono by office buarors. Now somo ol' these might be elected to the office, and if they showed themselves equal toits duties, so much tho botter for all, but

if thoy failed to givo satisfaction, or declined tho ? responsibility then their mouth would be stopped in future. There aro other reasons for annual

elections of elders in these communities, but 11

must leave these for another occasion.

And, remain fellow Christians,

Yours sincerely,

A LAYMAN.

County of Stanley, June 1, 1857.
