articleText:
THE Moreton Bay Courier.

SATURDAY, MAY 30, 1857.

THE LATE NEWS.

NOTWITHSTANDING tho long delay of the Simla, her arrival has brought disappoint-

ment to the inhabitants of the Northern Districts. The expected despatches re- lating to the Separation of Moreton Bay luve not yet been received. This delay will afford time for the reception of all that may have been urged against our claims by the Sydney Government ; but as it will also give time for the receipt of our own response, we have full confidence

in the issue. Mr. E. DEAS THOMSON'S

representations on the subject of the pro- posed boundary, in spite of that gentle- man's qualifying remarks as to the ab- sence of official documents for reference, will have been received as the confiden-

tial opinion of an officer who for very many years may be said to have governed this country. While protesting against the inclusion of New England in the pro- posed colony, Mr. THOMSON acknowledged tbo geographical propriety of connecting the Clarence with Moreton Bay, and bore testimony to the ability of the Northern colonists to form a Council of their own. These two facts, together with the official statement of the amount of population in the north, will be sufficient to determine the question, which, indeed, is now on all hands acknowledged to be settled. The despatch of Mr. LABOUCHERE might have prepared us for some little delay, for it was necessary to-have the advice of the Governor-General and Executive Council, respecting the division of the territorial debt between New South Wales and the new colony. Our readers will now see Hie sound policy of the activity which we advised in endeavoring to procure the ira luP'KlÄP fäW®ßÜF9uSL fefíJS?. voted

.The delay of the expected despatch may he further attributable to the unex- pected embarrassments of the ministry. If 00, this cause may not have ceased to operate by the timo of the next mail steamer's departure from England. Our readers ave aware that the government of Lord PALMERSTON had sustined a defeat in the House of Commons, on a motion brought, forward by Mr COBDEN, con- demnatory of the war in China. This defeat was not anticipated, it having been confidently expected that a majority of twenty-five, at least, would have been on th" other side. But the ministry was opposed by all classes of politicians. Mr. DISRAELI, Mr. ROEBUCK, and Lord JOHN RUSSELL siding with COBDEN. Tho mo- tion, which was tantamount to a censure upon ministers, was carried by a majority of sixteen-a result which is said to have not more astonishod the Government than

llio strangely' heterogeneous opposition, the conservative allies of which expected nutliing more than to give a blow to the ministry, without breaking it up. The consequences have boon still moro annoy- ing lo them, for Lord PALMERSTON had le^olved upon a dissolution of Parliament, diid an appeal to the country. Tho Gc tic-, al Election was expected to take place about the end of Maroh, and the new Parliament would meei in May. In the iíK"iütime, as there was pressing business to dispose of, the parliamentary session was proceeding. Opinions were various. It was considered tolerably certain at first that an appeal to the country would give I AH »i PALMERSTON a largo majority, and a moro firm and compact party thap ho had hitherto had j for tho war with China is decidedly not unpopular, and many look upon the Premier as an injured man. L.tcr opinions inclined to the probability ol' another and more decisivo attaok beiug mule before the dissolution, in order to drive tho ministry from office if possible, and thus save the inconvenienco, expense, and risk of a Qbneral Election, to the Con nonutive party in particular. Should hitch au attack bo made, and be success- ful, there scorned no party to rely upon as successors of the ministry but the rem- nant of the old Whigs. Lord JOHN RUSSELL lins boen daily drawing nearer to the Manchester Behool. Should he bo

awaiti intrusted wjth power, it is quito possible that COBDEN may be associated with him. Such an alliauco, however welcome it might, be in some of tho thick- ly pi-tuilated manufacturing towns, would not have the hearty approval of England. Tlio Conservative party, on the other hand, seem to be ineapabjo of construct- ing a ministry, oven should they havo nu opi a I unity of attemptiug. This, how uvi-r, js mere speculation. . The greater probability ia, that minis tors would hold llictr own until the dissolution, and that the olToot of the General Elüctjon would bo lo strengthen Lord PALMERSTON'S position.

It ii remarkablo that, ia tho House of Tinrrl i, which might not have boen counted upon as favorable to the Promier, a similar motton to that of Mr. COBDEN in tho

Coiiiino.is was brought forward by Lord. DuiUiV, aud, although supported by Lords

fyffllMVBW ftjjd, Sj, L^NAttPfy m] %

Bishop of OXFORD^.waa"tejeotecl by a. majority of thirty-six. The" fact proves that Lord PALMERSTON still depends for support upon the intrinsic force of his own character, and his thoroughly Eng- lish ideas, instead of mere party. At the same time, there is much inconsistency to be found in the policy of the sturdy old politician, and this his enemies are ¡ by no means reluotant to lay bare. His tamo consent to a mere remonstrance in the case of Naples does indeed strangely contrast with his fiery zeal formerly in the case of M. PACIFICO. But it must be remembered that the Prime Minister of England cannot always carry out his own dearest wishes, but must at times place those under painful restraints, in obedience to the dictates of prudence. No doubt the Emperor of the French, notwithstanding many strong temptations to the contrary, has hitherto had the good sense to maintain faith in his engage- ments with England, and, this being the case, England is bound jo listen to his suggestions as to the adoption of any policy which might create disorder in his dominions, or endanger the throne to which England has acknowledged his right. And if active interference in the affairs of Naples or Italy would enoourage revolutionists in Fiance, allowance must be made for Lord PALMERSTON'S position, and his desire to maintain good relations with his favorite ally. "Wo are by no means strong in faith as to the perma- nence of this alliance, although it should be preserved as long as possible; and hence arises another complication of the Italian question. If, unfortunately, any circumstance should arise to cause a

rupture with France, an immediate and cordial alliance would, doubtlessly, be formed between that country and Russia, and Prussia would probably be disposed to join it, unless prevented by the per- sonal relations about to be established with our Court by marriage. At all events, such an alliance would be for- midable in a military point of view, and it woulol not be desirable, by injudicious activity in Italian affairs, to array Austria

also on their side. Some such considera- tions as these have, in all probability, had their weight with Lord PALMERSTON, as they should also have with those who censuro him. It may sound very well to condemn mere expediency; but al- though it is distressing to reflect upon the political slavery of the Italian States, it would be still more distressing if Eng- land, thiough rash statesmanship and ultra-Quixotism, should ever lessen the power she now has of protecting her own subjects from similar degradation. Loid

PALMERSTON has shown himself firm in

supporting the independence of the King of Sardinia, in whom the Italians would be wise to recognise their leader and their1 example. "

The war in China is to be carried on with vigour. General PENNEI? ITIIER, has been appointed Commander-in-Chief of the troops, and the Earl of ELGIN, for- merly Governor-General of Canada, has been sent out as Plenipotentiary on the part of England. Now that the sword relinquished merely'up'onMie seloYonient of the ostensible cause of quarrel. Eng- land is backed up by other nations in the opinion that advantage should be taken of the present occasion to enforce free

commerce and international intercourse in China. It Avould have been difficult to Belect a bettor man than Lord ELGIN for the task intrusted to him. At one time, indeed, his heart failed him in Canada. Broken-spiiited and disgusted at the opposition, and even peisonal ill treatment, which he met with, he tendered his resignation ; but this Eail GREY, then

Colonial Secretary, refused to accept, and . the result was that Lord ELWIN remained long enough in his vice-royalty to witness the establishment of peace, prosperity, and full responsible government in the Canadas In his new field of action he will have the advantage of the experience of Sir JOHN BOWUINO, whom he is not to supersede but to co-operate with. It is expected that, when General PENNEFA- THER has organised his forces and is ready for the field, and the naval reinforcements aro " complete, Lord ELGIN will lay his demands before the Court of Pekin, and authorise immediate measures of force if

they be not conceded. In all probability the Emperor, with a powerful and almost triumphant rebellion in his own domi- nions, will bo constrained to accept the proposals offered. If not, there will be a war in which undoubtedly the bloodshed «lust rho great, for, though poor soldiers, th? Chinese have but little fear of djqath. Mr. COBDEN and his party violently con- demn the 'use of force in opening 'up a barbarous and exclusive country to the world ; but if it were not for such things

that woild would have made but slow

progress, and Mr. COBDEN himsolf, assum- ing that he is of purely British descent, might now have bceu scampering about the oak forests of England, with no ex- ternal adornment but a few suns and moons painted upon his skin. The Times ingeniously disposes of the complaints about the opium trade. Opium, the great journal says, has been shown to be absolutely necessary to the Chinese, from habit, and beneficial if used in moderation. The great mortality that occurred in a cer- tain Chinese passenger-ship was traced to the insufficiency of the opium supply This necessary article the Chinóse rulers wished to keep a monopoly of. What then would be thought of England if she suddenly shut her ports against the gin of Holland, tho brandy of France, and tho wines of Spain and Portugal, on the plea that some of the English-a great number indeed-abuse the use of those liquids? The present war, however, is not about opium, although the freedom of commoron generally is very much con- cerned. A late report, by way of Mel- bourne, stated that a division had taken place in the couuoils of the so-oalled Ohinoso rebels, a party of whom had gone over to tho Imperialists. It is by no means improbablo, as overtures from the same party had boforo boen made to the British, and rejooted.

The settlement of the Persian question is satisfactory. Herat is to be given up Jo the independent government of its own

cWefy lind, i^hjre ja tfmn. to bofyftouajgd,

í

a_] by the British. England is to .be allowed

the same privileges in Persia as any other nation. This will serve as a check upon Russian influence. In exchange for this concession, England abandons, as of course she ought to do, all claim to protection over Persian subjects. Mr. MURRAY, whose interference on behalf of a lady caused that first misunderstanding which Russia was so anxious to improve, is to be received at the Persian Court, with honor ; a stipulation which will certainh be humiliating to the Sohah. There can

be no doubt but that the firmness o France in her alliance has thus far as s sisted in foiling Russia. The treaty wa

executed in Paris, and an armistice was' proclaimed, to allow time for the ratifi-

cation.

The only other circumstance in the late news that calls for particular remark here, is the fact of a letter having been addressed to the Times, by a Mr. WIL- LIAM GOSLING MOORE, in which that gentleman takes it upon himself to re- commend the'forwarding of convicts to Moreton Bay, for the cultivation of cot- ton. He complains that an application to the Government on the subject had not been attended with any satisfactory result, but thinks that, independently of the convict part of tho proposal, the mat- ter is well worthy of consideration. So we think also ; but it is amusing to ob- serve the perfect coolness with which 3ome people appropriate the ideas of others. The merit of the cotton suggestion is undoubtedly due to Dr. LANG. Mr. MOORE'S proposal for the employment of convicts he is welcome to all the credit of. Wo want no such importations here, nor will the inhabitants ever tolerate them.

Although the sanguine may have been disappointed by the non-arrival of the Separation despatch, they should not per- mit the delay to engender apathy. On the contrary, advantage should be taken of this interval to make the best use of the means placed at our disposal. The law does not yet allow us to select our govern- ment, and those who have undertaken that task iu the meantime must not be

permitted to evade it. Not only must they be urged to perform their duty, but duo care must bo taken that they perform it, as bound by every tie of honor and conscience, in the manner most likely to benefit the parties chiefly concerned.

EXPENDITURE OF GRANTS FOR THE

NORMERN DISrRIOTS.

As we intimated last week, the expendi- ture of the sums which have been voted under the Loan Bill for 1857, for the use of the Northern Districts, has now, after considerable delay, been sanctioned by the authorities ip, Sydney, and we shall soon have the gratification of seeing some of the more urgent of our public works pro- ceeded with-the making of roads, build- ing of bridges, formation of streets, &c. It will be seen from our advertising columns that á beginning has already been made in the matter, tenders for ad- ditions to thq Immigration Depot in

Brisbane havinir '»-*.. -""^ ft»-» .*-J ll%

»--".«pneemönt of the other works is only dependent on tho arrival from Sydney of the necessary plans and specifications, which aie expeoted by lho next steamer.

The direction of the vtorks in the neighborhood of Brisbano aad Ipswich has been entrusted to a Board, composed

of the GOVERNMENT RESIDENT, E. E. ROBERTS, Esq., (District Surveyor of Roads), and A. BEAZLEY, Esq., (Clerk of Works) ; and the delay which would attend the reference of every little matter to Sydney will thus bo avoided. The works in the Wide Bay and Fitzroy dis- tricts, and the neighborhood of Drayton, &c, are to be conducted under the su peiiutendenco of the authorities in these localities. The improvement of the streets of Brisbane and Ipswich will be under the management of committees, -the Ipswich committee to consist of Colonel GRAY and two members elected by the inhabitants generally ; that of Brisbane consisting of Captain WICKHAM and two of the inhabitants nominated by

him. We do not understand the reason

for this distinction ; and indeed we do not attach much importance to it, pro- vided the selection is wisely mado ; but, in reference to Brisbane, we would have thought that an elected committee would be more likely to give satisfaction.

It is well known that the sura voted

for the repairs of the streets of Brisbane is quite inadequate for the purpose, and would scarcely make three-quarters of a mile of street properly ; and when it is remembered that the sum has to be di- vided between North and South Brisbane, it will readily be seen that the improve- ments will be of a very superficial cha- racter, and the distribution of the funds will bo likely'to cause some little jealousy. For this reason, if for no other, we should have thought Captain WICKHAM would have been very, willing to have had some of the responsibility removed from his

own shoulders to those of the inhabitants. However, we do not feel inclined to lay much stress on this point; wo would simply urge upon him the necessity of securing the services of two practical in- dividuals, whoso only desire may be to have the money expended as fairly and profitably as possible,

For the present, the Board has been entrusted with the prosecution of the fol- lowing works, involving an expenditure of £ 14,154:

Immigration Depot, Btisbane. £2590 Bridge at Western Suburbs. 500

Streets of Brisbane . 2000 Bridge at Laidleys Creek. 500

Do Lookyer's Creek . 1000 Do Breakfast Creek . 1500 Do Norman's Creek . 1000

Bridges at other crossings . 1000 Repair of the roads, Little Liverpool

Range. 1061 Road between Brisbane and Ipswich.. 3000

£14,151

Besidos the above works( to be carried out under the direotion of the Brisbano Board, there aro sovcral others provided for in the Loan Bill which, we presume, will bo proooodod with without delay. Directions have already been given to the local authorities for the proseoution of Hw"" '

Repairs to the streets of Ipswioh.... £2000

. Formation of a roadway, and construe- «

" tionofatank, at Dray ton...,., ßOO^ Immigration Depot at Maryborough. 250* Court and watch-house at ditto .... 1000 Do do at Nangango, Wide Bay .... 500 Do de at Tarromeo, Wide Bay...... 500 Improving navigationof the riverMary 500 Publie wbarf at Maryborough . 500 Road between Maiyboiougb and Bris-

bane . 400

Road purposes in tbo Leichhardt Dis-

trict. 200 Removing obstructions to navigation

of the Brisbane and Bremer.... 1000

£7,350'

Some of these sum.3 will appear ridicu- lously small for the purposes indicated ; for instance, £400 for a road between Brisbane and Maryborough ; but it ought to be explained that several sums voted previous to the passing of the Loan Bill are now being expended in forming parts

of the road between the two last-men- tioned places. At present, we believe some men are engaged in forming a road- way, 60 feet wide, through the Three mile Scrub ; and when the bridges, al- ready provided for, are erected along the route, the country will be open to the northward nearly as far as the Burnett. By the opening of this road, a country which is now nearly inaccessible will be brought into comparative proximity with

Brisbane.

Now that good weather seems to have setin, wehope that advantage will be taken of it to forward the different works, es- pecially the roads and bridges ; so that, by the time of the next wet season, town and country may not be shut off from each other, as they have been lately.

articleText:
MB. nOLT AND HIS CONSTITUENTS.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Cow ter.

Sin.-Judçing from tho peculiar style of advocacy employed by tin fi iends of Sir. Holt, lost Mon- day night,,'it is clear that they ara ignoranfr of, or eke sappi ess their knowlodga of, "the tiha position in which this constituency stands to Mr, Holt, or which ho occupies lo the constituency. When a representative is also a gentleman abo liberally assists every good and benevolent object» it is a pleasant feature in his character, and oS course much to his credit. But if, as is tho'case« with Mr. Holt and his advocates, it is sought lo institute some killel of connexion between his in- dividual charities and his political positron, so ni to ground tho latter to any extant upon the former, n most pernicious error is fallen info» Mr. Holt expected that a donation lo a'religious denomination would be a good political invest- ment, and seciii o its obsequious unreflecting ad- herence to his interest ¡or nil time to come Really, the public have heard much more than, enough of this new style of money qualification. Let "Air. Holt be entreated not to lay tho flatter- ing unction to his soul, that tho chink of raonoy bags will he accepted as a substitute for brains, and the application of common-sense. It is only ,whên thVmpnóy is the best part of a man tlmt such prominence'is'given to it. To urge tho right to sit in the National Council Chambers, becaiiso' of a succession of painful pecuniary dis- bursements, is intensely absurd. When Mr. Holt has for some little time rigidly abstained from the concoction of heavy pamphlets, and tho writ- ing of mawkish letters, and has informed himself as to what tho franchise renlly is, ho will not bo telling people that it is shabby conduct to discard nn effigy of a politician, the wealth of Croesus notwithstanding.

I am, Sir,

Yours truly,

avis.

articleText:
THE

MORETON BAY COURIER.

SATURDAY, MAY 2, 1857.

THE FATE OF LEICHHARDT.

A correspondent of the Sydney Morn- ing Herald, under the signature of " Z," has been exciting the wonderment of those who have a predilection for mar- vellous tales, by a strange story of the alleged captivity of Dr. Leichhardt and his companions. The statement is that some young man, now undergoing punish- ment for an offence against the laws, has made a confession to his clergyman, in which, he declares that he for a consider- able time. formed one of a society existing in the far interior, and composed of run away white men, aboriginal women, and

their children ; that these people grew their own wheat and ground it in steel mills ; that they were in possession of large flocks and herds: had located them- selves on the banks of a large river ; and procured such necessaries as they did not possess by conveying them from a distance on pack-horses. These people, he says, fell in with Dr. LEICHHARDT, and made him and all his companions prisoners, in which position they remained two years ago. No doubt the narrator of this ro- mantic tale would be glad to exchange his present position for that of a guide to a searohing party, trusting to ingenuity and chance for an opportunity of enlarg- ing his freedom. We do not forget what colonial history tells us—that a poor con- vict was once flogged for declaring that he had found native gold, which in all proba- bility was the truth ; but this story con- cerning Leichhardt exceeds the bounds of all reasonable probability. Those villa- gers of the wilderness are said to be in possession of books, and to have employed Leichhardt as a schoolmaster to their children. The idea that any number of lawless men, seeking only escape from the consequences of crime, would remain in a position of this kind while they knew, them, that every facility now existed for their undetected return to civilised life ; for their participation in the chances of the gold-fields, or for their departure from the colony, is simply preposterous. Equal ly improbable is it that the native blacks would fraternise with them in such a way of life ; and tolerably certain is it that a secret of this nature would have been long since tracked out by outriding stock- men or garrulous natives. The tale, however, such as it is, has been submitted to the consideration of the Government, with further particulars not yet made public; and there the matter rests.

Our chief reason for adverting in this place to the report in question arises from the hope that it may give a fresh stimulus to the search for the unfortunate Au-

stralian explorer. We have repeatedly expressed our conviction that, whatever may have been the fate of Leichhardt, all the inquiries hitherto instituted into that mystery have ended most unsatis- factorily. An expedition into the in- terior of this continent is undoubtedly not so agreeable a recreation as an afternoon walk in the Government Gardens; but when we think of what Dr. Rae has done and what Livingstone has but recently accomplished, the difficulties attending a further search for Leichhardt appear far from formidable to Anglo-Saxon energy. Mr. Hely's investigations may have satisfied his own mind, but they have not satisfied the public, and that was the object of his journey. Neither have we derived, as might have been ex pected, any information on this point, from the more recent enterprise of Mr Gregory. That expedition has added little to our previous knowledge, and appears to have left even the question of the existence of gold-fields in the neigh- borhood of the Lynd and the Burdekin, as it was before.

Some time ago a suggestion was thrown out for the employment of a party of Native Policemen in any future search for Dr. Leichhardt ; and we are inclined to think that they would be found most useful auxiliaries. In discovering water- ing places for encampments, tracking strayed horses or bullocks, guarding against surprises by hostile natives, and almost instinctively detecting the traces of any previous traveller, these men would bo invaluable. With a hardy, intrepid, and, above all, zealous leader, and a well selected and well equipped party of sturdy bushmen, a company might thus be formed from whom something satisfactory could be confidently expected. As the case stands at present, a deep reproach rests upon the colonists; a reproach applying not only to their liberality, but also to their courage. Leichhardt was willing to risk his life in the cause of science for Australia, but Australia does not produce a man who will risk anything to follow on his track. That is the practical fact of the case, although there may be many men who would go if able. It may well be, indeod, that poor Leichhardt is past all earthly care. Yet his existence is quite within the range of probability, The only warrant for believing him dead is the blackfellows' tale of Bundarabella Creek. If the alleged slaughter were really perpetrated there, some trace or relic of the murdered men might yet be

found. The present state of uncertainty is, we repeat, discreditable to the colony.

While it exists, such tales as that made

public by " Z" will over and anon be told,

and at intervals there will continue re- newals of that public anxiety which any

more vigorous government than our own would have long since set at rest.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, MAY 2, 1857. THE FATE OF LEICHHARDT.

and the wants and wisheäof the Moleton Bay district set at nought

That our picsent juflifiiliuangoiuuuts aietimpeifeet, is everywheie admitted. Apiisoner while ¿waiting his trialy is ofton subjected to a preliminary punishment, which would be considered quite com mensuiate with his offence In our last

week's issue a oase is îepoited^of a mau being committed for trial for stealing two bottles of gin; and accoiding to present anangements he will have to abido in gaol for nearly four months before he is declared innocent or guilty. And at the last Assizes we had a striking instance of the hardship which is ' sometimes in- flicted on the innocent, in the case of ALEX. articleText:
THE RECENT DECISION UNDER THE

SCAB ACT.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,-In this day's Free Press appears a letter signed George Appel

His letter contains the statement that "a steamer arrived on Sunday night, during chapel time, and rams which had been packed in a large case were forwarded in the greatest hurry early on Monday morning, being at once transferred from this Sydney steamer to one of the Ipswich

boats "

This statement is false.

The Yarra Yarra arrived on Sunday, the 19th ult, with the rams on board. They remained on board the whole of Monday the 20th, and till the middle of the day on Tuesday the 21 st, when they went on per steamer to Ipswich. Thus it will be

seen that the rams were nearly 48 hours in Bris- bane before they were shipped onward from the south side, where the inspector lives, thus givng ample time for any vigilant and active officer to have been on the spot, and to have done his duty.

I greatly regret that this misstatement should have been made, as the obligation I feel under to contradict it has alone caused me to reply to a letter which otherwise would certainly have re- mained unnoticed by

Your obedient humble servant,

NEHEMIAH BARTLEY.

Brisbane, August 5th, 1857.
heading: THE RECENT DECISION UNDER THE SCAB ACT. To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

I THE PUBLIC STREETS. co

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier. jts

Sir,-You ore aware that sums of money have

been voted by tho Sydney Government for im- : ' proving the streets of Ipswich, as also those of ' Brisbane ; and as it is ot the greatest importance ' that these monies should he expended to tho best

call in a certain number of tho inhabitants to assist ' in getting rid of it, and he is himself a person of ' no ability, ho will be sure «to select those who are j as incapable ns himself-for naturo compels every ' oreature to cling to its kind-and should he name ' i hy chanoo a practical man, that man may not fool ' I inclined to work for a body of muffs, and perhaps j

bear tho blamo of their doings in tho end. J - I would suggest, if tho trustees for this purpose ' > are not to bo olected, that the persons by whom- j

soever thoy bo pained, Bhpnld consist of at least ' onp-half pi actical persons ¡ tho other half being ' amateur street makers, who would thus hayo th.o '.

, bonofit of somo oimerienco ainong them., j , I am, Sir, <

Your obedient servant. '

articleText:
THE BRIDGES IN THE MILTON SUBURBS.

To the Editor of Oie Moreton Bay Courier.

Sm,-I yvould orave a small space in your columns to draw attention to the manner in y-hicli a por- tion of the grant for public works has been ex- pended. When wo invest our money in the eric» tion of bridges, we may reasonably expeot that those in authority will see that we secure the best possible article for our cash. Three bridges have just been erected in the Milton suburbs, one near to Mr. M'Dougnll's, and two others at intervals towards Lang i*'arm. The first does not seem ob- jectionable, the second is below the level of the road ; but, being anxious to avoid, the reputation of being a mere grumbler, I avoid further comment. The'- third, however, is a very stupid 'job, and, to the eye of a person uninitiated - in the mysteries of Government engineering, presents "a perfect puzzle. The workmanship in all those structures does not ap- pear, to ;bej open to .censure, the fault is in the plan of the third ! Instead of being placed so ns to. form,a continuation of the right line of the road, the third bridge crosses it diagonally ! The creek does the same, and the party preparing the plan seems to have been anxious to set the bridge square'across the latter ! I should like lo see our Engineer (if "it is his planning) drive a team of bullocks and a dray past the sharp angle of this bridge. It is possible that ho has been unjustly censured, and that' he is not to blame for this waste of money, so pitiable, where a few pounds

more would have avoided the evil. Whothei it is attributable to the Engineer himself, the "Board of Work'," or the ". Board of Incapables," may be doubtful, but this is certain, that as at present constructed, the bridge ih question is made to lit

" tho road to Nowhere."

VIATOR.

articleText:
THK BRISBANE SCHOOL OF ARTS.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,-The wretchedly thin attendance of members at the Sehool'of Arts on Thursday evening did not surprise roe "in the least. All I wondered at »vas, that there were more than a round dozen present, for the publie interest it» that institution has been for some time pistât the lowpst po«sible ebb. No one questions wAv this should be the case, as the cause is patent to nny observer. An institution may have fifty officers and yet »vork badly ; while another of n similar class, with three or four good managing men, will be a blessing to the com- munity, and be an effective auxiliary to the great cause of progress.

At the meeting last night I noticed five of the committee, but there were no other honorary offi- cers present. It »vas a quarterly meeting, and the members had a right to expect one of the

Vice-Presi lents, if not the President himself, . should'be in his place. Men »vho cannot attend to the duties required of them should not accept honorary posis in an institution which requires

" men of thought and men of nction." I have ( some recollection of the last yearly meeting, when tbo_officers »»-ero appointed, and unless my memory is very treacherous, thero »Tere somo pro- digious promises made by those whom tho mem- bers " delighted to honor.'" Knowing the general character for energy and business like talent at- tributed to Mr. W." A. Brown, 1 did expect that

the institution had nt last found nu efficient officer. For the first lew months Mr. Brown »vas »'cry assiduous, but it »vould seem that nn acces- sion of publio »cork lins entirely extinguished the Vice-Presidency. As to Uie other vice, all that can be said about him is-that where little eau he done, little is to be expected. The Treasurer would be quite a, rara avis in the ball, and the visita of the President nie not so frequent as they ought to be, nlthouirii I must admit that the gen- tleman does »vhat he can, by contributions of books, «to., for the fuithereuce of the institution. There are some fi»-o or six of iho committee who are always to be found in their places, by whom all the work is done, and »\ho really deserve some little credit. One really active and zealous officer would, if seconded ¡ii his efforts by I he members, raise this institution to its legitimate status. No»»*, it is nothing more than a common reading

room. - *

At the meeting on Thursday some allusions »vere made to lectures which were promised and never ¡¡¡ven. One member of (he Committee who "put his name down" said he hod »vith-held his lecture because of the paucity of attendance at others ; while another member said that be »vonld give his when he could deliver one worth paying a shilling to hear. I thought this rosher a stupid excuse at first, but really the gentleman »»ho made it »vas right. It may seem rather bold for me to advance such a belief, but it is_ my opinion that there nre very, very few men in this to»vn »vho can deliver lectures »vorth the shilling. Small as the sum is, it presents n very great ob- stacle, and a few experimental " free admission" lectures »vould prove the ti nth of what I say.

The committee tell us that 'the building is dilupi latcd, and wants repair, while others talk about enlarging it. Tho front ii in a tumble doivn state, and ought to have lind its ugly and ponderous ornamentations (forgive the anomaly) knocked away long ago. Enlargement is rather an absurd point to move just now, »vhen a muster of twenty members shows up at a quarterly meeting. The Secretary says there nre 230 on the roll, I nm glad to /tear it ; but I would much rather ste thom in their places. 'The paid officer suggested at tlie meeting that an effort should bo

made to raise extra contributions from the mern- | hers. Strong in his acknowledged talent for ilmining.adj«'thought £200 might "easily bo raised." AU I can -my is-" Try it."

In conclusion, Sir, I »vould urge upon the mem i hers/ throutrh the medium of your columns, to , attend at the next public meeting, (as one is to , bo called in a few weeks,) and do something, if it . is only'to pass a vote of censure on 1 heir officers.

Progressing (!) as at present, the institution will . soon be a mere nonentity. With a little enemy

mid attention, it might he mudo a little more I ivorthy of the title which the Secretary pronoun nea

. »vith such unotion when he reads tlie annual , report, &t. '

I Apologising for the length of this,

, I am, Sir,

Yours, Ac,

OBSISRVANDUS.

Brisbane, Oot. 9, 1857.

The meeting was vory indignant tit tho time tho Doctor »vas speaking'nbont it; ho »vas describing tho district as in a hopoloss htitto of insolvency, and that it was relieved by Mr. Holt's kindiioss in bringing up the Brishitno Branch of the Joint Stock Bunk. Wo »»ill, for tho sake of the argu- ment, gi»'e Mr. Holt tilt the benefit or praiso the Doctor awards him, and suppose that it »vas wholly by h:b influence that the think i»'ns brought up, and that it lins proved a real Alladin'« Lamp ;

and that at film first rub this miserable state ol' bankruptcy (so feelingly described) »vas imme- diately changed into a siuto of great prosperity ;

in filet, that »io were saved. Lot us examino the matter fairly:' Did Mr. Holt, us Director of tho Bank, do this for tho bonofit of that corporation, and lins it buen successful ? if io, no doubt his brother directors and hliareholth-rs »»ill teiiiember his servios ut their annual inciting, und wc shall hear ol' un addition to his load of honors in tho hlmpo of it hearty »-otu of thanks of tho company. But are the electors of tho Stanley Boroughs to bo treated like children, with this lollipop to draw offthnir alli'iitinii lunn tho gievions arong in- flicted on thom hy hi* voting against their vital inioro^t Ï What lins it to tlo »»¡th, Mr. Hull's ability ti repiesent as in Parliament? I do not think 1.0 bad rf Mr. Holt us his support ors do. I admit the tcrew was put on, and more, that 1 have felt it, nr.d lost us much, i.r more, than any uno by the o| nation. DouUloss the Dircctois thought it a fnvonibla lime to enm tnence operation», wisely thinking- that they had

along list of the Do'ctoi's pust services, I am - the hist to underrnto the sert ices of any public

man, but if former services are put forward as a, . set oil" for dereliction of duty, 1 think the obli- gation is cancelled and the .account balanced. articleText:
SCHOOL OF ARTS FOR SOUTH BRISBANE.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,-That the god's help those who help them- selves will not be denied, and that a community can never be raised above lgnorance and vice ex- cept they exert themselves, is equally true. We ought, thorefore, to provide the means of hearty, healthful, mental industry, for the young in their leaisure hours thus giving them the means of growing up with a sound mind, and sound body, and saving them from the vicious influences of the wayside groups of idlers whose language is often a disgrace to our common humanity, as well as preventing them from loitering at the corners of streets, as if being in wait for evil.

Now, by no means within our reach can we so well accomplish thisas by opening among our- selves one of those institutions which are the basis of the social and intellectual progress of the rising generation, as well as the best boon left us by the past age, for the amelioration of physical evils. Separated as we are from North Brisbane by a broad river, and a long distance of often indifferent

streets, the institution there is comparativelv of little use to us. Our families cannot attend the lectures and the debates there but at considerable exertion, as well as a waste of time and morey. Our young men cannot stop in to see the papers in the evening when they have a leisure hour, nor can we enjoy any such treat ourselves but at the expense of a journey that few of us would have time to take. Surely it is necessary for us to consider whether by a little exertion on our part we could not have a reading room as a nucleus of a School of Arts in South Brisbane, be- ginning with a suitable variety of papers and

periodicals, and proceeding with the gradual acc- cumulation of a library. We are bound to make some such exertion, that intelligence may grow grow up among us; that we may know something of what is passing in the world around us; and that those who wish to apply themselves to knowledge may supply the omission, or correct the defects of early

education. If we thus exert ourselves no doubt

the Government will deal liberally with us, and gentlemen will bo found who will give us lectures on such subjects as would be instructive and at

tractive. Let it not bo said that we confine our-

selves wholly to the useful, and such as has refer-

ence only to the bodily and the material, leaving our minds naked and hungry. Nor would our exertions injure in any way the institution in North Brisbane, those among us who are members there would continue to be be still,

because they would have the use of more valuable works than we could for some time be able to procure. Somethng of rivalry will be very beneficial in making tho Committee of the

North Brisbane School of Arts clean its Creole

countencance and smooth its ragged aspect; it never

was a very good looking building, but if the

face is any index of the interior as it now appears,

well may a stranger enquire-" Does the human mind expand within such a ragged abode as that?" Let us not neglect the.place where we dwell, and the improvement resulting will be am- ple recompense,

I am, Sir,,

Your obedient servant,

A SOUTH BRISBANITE.

South Brisbane 17th July, 1857
heading: SCHOOL OF ARTS FOR SOUTH BRISBANE. To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

articleText:
THE LATE MEETING OF MR. HOLTS

FRIENDS.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,-I have to call attention to a letter in your journal of 4th instant, signed " An Observer, " the

writer of which does not scruple to make state- ments which he must know to be false. He states that I, the proposer of the amendment in allud- ing to the remarks of the proposer of the resolu- tion about Mr. Holt's services in establishing a Bank, said, "It seemed to have taken the screw off him, meaning the proposer of the resolutions." Now Sir, the reports of both papers, and I believe the testimony of every person present at the meeting, having any recolection of what was said

will prove the above statement to be false. I said the mover of the resolutions had given them a very exaggerated picture of a time of depression, and callee upon them to appreciate Mr. Holt's services in taking of the screw: and I added, it was very evident that he, at all events, highly appreciated those services. The allusions to such a matter was altogether out of place ; it was un- just to Mr. Holt to suppose that he had any other

end in view than the benefit of the Bank. The way in which he talked of " grasping avarice," and "threatened ruin," when "every man was afraid to look his fellow in the face," was monstrous, and created more surprise, perhaps, than anything said at the meeting. I certainly thought he was over-estimating such services.

I will not notice his conclusions and insinua- tions, as his premises do not warrant them ; but as he makes another charge, also grounded on a falsehood, I must state that I never used the words, "Mr. Hodgson would oblige me, and why should I not oblige him ?" I trust I shall never, in the discharge of my duty as an Elector, act on any such principle.

Your obedient servant,

GEO. RAFF.

Brisbane, July 6, 1857.
heading: THE LATE MEETING OF MR. HOLT'S FRIENDS. To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

THE WEATHER PROGNOSTICATOR.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,—I send you the accompanying " Weather Prognosticator," it is from an old number of the Wesleyan Magazine, but how it got there I cannot inform you. I have heard many powerful opinions on the subject upon which it treats, and if you do not grudge the space it will occupy in your columns, its re-publication may be benefi- cial by calling attention and even by promoting discussion. If you print it in one column, so that it may be cut out of the paper and stuck on the wall alongside the thermometer, it will be easy

of reference.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

JAMES WARNER.

Kangaroo Point, Feb. 17, 1857

articleText:
TIÍG A. S. N. COMPANY'S STEAMERS.

To the Rditor of the moreton Hoy Courier.

SIR,-Pt'oplo in Sydney who oro interested in the communication with Moleton "Buy, havo causo to complain of tho small degree of reliance which they can safely place on, tho A S. N. Co.'s adver- tisements respecting the sailing of thfir stenmers. For sometime past it had become quite usual to advertise the sailing of the steamers for Tuesday evening, but, when that day arrived,"to alter tlio time'of departure to Wednesday. A short timo ago the Yarra Yarra was advertised to sail' on Monday, and absolutely caused disappointment because she was punctually despatched. All this week the daily papers have regularly announced that tho Boomerang would sail for your port on Tuesday (this) evening. I, for one, placing no great laith in those advertisements, wr.s not sntis licd until J saw that tho Boomerang had been hi ought over to the wharf, nftcr her ropnirs, when I believed. But this morning it is nnnounced Ihnt the Waratah is to go to Moreton Bay instead, and is to leave to-morrow evening.

. I nm well aware that unforeseen accidents will occur in the best regulated establishments, but tho uncertainty that pervades tho arrangements respecting tho arrival mid departure of tho Mole- ton Biy steamers is becoming a public incon- venience, which I hope you «ill lend your aid to remedy.

I am,-Sir,

Your obedient servant,

BOIÎEAS.

Sydtioy, 23rd June.

articleText:
THE TONGA COTTON-TREE,-MISSION

ARIES AND COMMERCE.

of I To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,-In your last issue you published a despatch from her Brittania Mnjest}'s Acting Consul at Baltimore, by which ive learn, for the first time, that the cotton-tree-yvhioh might become an im- portant staple product in this district-grows spontaneously at Tonga, an Island in the South

Pacific.

I believe that a Christian mission has been for some years established by British subjects at Tonga ; and it might occasion surprise to some thnt hitherto the above piece of information-so important to Great Britain ns a commercial and manufacturing nation-has remained wholly un- known until the present moment ; and lins at length, reached us through- such an unexpected mid apparently unlikely channel. It is not diffi- cult to discern the cause of this. It rosts chiefly iii what I, in common with many others, feel my- self bound to regard as a defect in the missionary system. Every icligious body, whilst endeavor- ing to spread abroad in distant countries the tenets of its peculiar form of Christianity, has forgotten the civilising agency of commerce. Nay, I dare affirm, that in many instances there lins been a stronger inclination to discourage than to foster trade. The artificial -vants and evils which undoubtedly accompany the spread of Euro« pean customs and civilisation, do not seem to all minds to bo counterbalanced hy the great advan nges and blessings which extended commerce brings to the larger number.

Cmimorco and religion have been looked upon as in some measure antagonistic to ench other, and no systematic endeavor has been made to combine the blessings of the two. _ The introduc- tion of agriculture with religion into Purnguay, by tho Jesuits undoubtedly exeroised for a time a beneficial influence upon the character of its in- habitants ; but their commercial relations being a monopoly in tho hands ol' their spiritunl teachers, the people did not experience the direct influence of traffic ; and when tho Jesuits wore driven out in 17C8, commerce, and agriculture ivhich is sti- mulated by it, received a death-blow.

Although I would not moko tho missionary a merchant, ho might devise means to create be- tween theheathen iiiidhis civilised brother a profit- able commercial intercourse. The missionary is not generally adapted to cll'ect this purpose. Science, art, and agriculture, are not greatly indebted tohim. His information is considerably narrowed. He is fully instructed in the peculiar religious views he has been sent forth to tench ; but his education has not generally proceeded further: mid in branches of knowledge calculated, to make him useful in discovering the resources of a now coun- try he^ is wholly ignorant. There are, of course, exceptions, hut this may bo accepted as the gonertl standard of attainment, more especially among the Protestant missionaries. . Grow ing for yearp, and yva'sting nt his door, among a savage people, is a tree, which had the missionary known its na- ture, woiildhave been in his hands a potent lever to raise the people of Tonga into an industrious, thriving, civilised, mid, I venture to nssert, Chris- tian community." Neither the missionary nor his mission nro yet rightly understood.

Could this tree-cotton bo profitably cultivated in Moreton Bay ? Its cultivation is described as "cheap and easy in comparison with the more expensive and laborious method adopted in the United States " This is no mean recommenda- tion in a country where labor is searco and costly, and yyhere it is essential, for health-sake, fo mití- galo the burden of daily toil. Tonga is, I believe, situated n little to tlio southwmd of .tbo 20th parallel, so that it is not unlikely ive sh'mild find the cotton tree well ndnpted to our Moreton Bay climate. Sir William Denison, it seems, has re- ceived some of the Tonga seed. Can you inform rno whether any has been forwarded to our Botani- cal Gardens? 'Is it not possible to transplant? And by what means could a supply of plants ho obtained ? Any render of your columns who could supply information on those points, would

oblige

AGRICOLA.

UPPER DAWSON BLACKS.-We are glad to be enabled to publish the following extract from a letter of Mr. W. H. Wiseman.—'Upper Dawson, Dec. 8.-There have been no more murders by the blacks in these parts since the shocking massacre of the Fraser family ; but every one, more par- ticularly the poor women at the out-stations, and there are a good many in places, are much fright- ened. Ten more police have arrived, so no more murders may be expected."

articleText:
THE BOUNDARY LINE.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,—Having resided for many years within a day's ride of the town of Brisbane, it may natu rally be supposed I look with regret on the pro-

posal of Separation at the 28th parallel, the effect of which would be to place myself and many others, who at present are almost considered as residents of Brisbane, within the boundary of the

Botany Bay Colony, and I think you have not sufficiently considered the loss the Northern colony would sustain, should such a decision be arrived at by the British Government. Allow me, therefore, to draw your attention to the following facts. The colony of Victoria, between the 141st meri- dian of longitude, the south and south-east coast as far as Cape Howe, and the rivers Hume and Murray, contains nearly 98,000 square miles. The colony of New South Wales Proper, that is, between the thirtieth parallel of latitude, and Victoria, the east coast and the 141st meridian of longitude contains 250,000 square miles. The disputed portion of land between the 28th and 30th parallels of latitude, the eastern sea coast and the 141st meridian of longitude contains 105,0000 square miles, or more than the whole of

the colony of Victoria, and if added to New South Wales will make that colony nearly four times as large as Victoria ; it would also cut off from us the town of Warwick, and some of the best stations in the Moreton, Darling Downs, and Maranoa Districts, besides the towns of Grafton, Cassino, Tabulan, Tenterfield, Wellingrove, Glen Innes, Stonehenge, Dundee, Byron Plains, Wari- alda, and Bingera. It would take from us the Mount Mitchell, and Bingera Gold Fields, as well as all that splendid alluvial country on the Clar- ence and Richmond Rivers ; it would place Brisbane and Ipswich at the extreme south east corner of the Northern Colony, and thereby take from them all chance of becoming the seat of future Govern-

ment, the probability being that some more central site would be chosen.

I need not speak of the fall in the value of pro- perty that must then take place, but would urge the inhabitants of these towns to unite while there

is yet time, or their greedy neighbour will most certainly rob them of the best portion of their just inheritance. I remain, Sir, Your obedient servant,

ALFRED WM. COMPIGNE,

Nindooinba, Albert River, 25th July, 1857.

«

LAND SALES AT DARLING DOWNS.

s To the liditor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,-I observe jour Drayton correspondent is very uTcrtfí because sufficient land is not put up for'sale at the Swamp for the benefit "of tho moro than 100 men returning from sheep-washini;, sheep-shearing, and other station work, iritli cheques and money orders in their pockets aver- aging from £5û to £100 each, (what a blessed cdltntry 1) aild which mostly would be laid out in the purchase of a piece of ground, «fee." j and I am happy to observe in the same paper that at tlio ".Sivninp" a large number of farms ate to be sold on tho 18th and 19th current, when the holders of the cheques nnd money orders will have tho opportunity of disposing of them,and should there not be sufficient land exposed on these two doy», plenty moro farms will be put up for sale. I will watch anxiously the result, and see if the Drayton correspondent will report that the whole of the lots will be sold. Furthermore, I can in- form your correspondent at Dalby, that shortly they will have nn opportunity of investing too large extent their surplus capital, as I understand ii largo number of allotments will bo exposed for sale tbei'0. The cry on tho Downs a short timo ago was " lot us have some land sales," and now that they know they will have more thun sufficient tlicy growl nt some imaginary oversight of their member, whom I know to be' most indofatigublo for their interests, mid who bus been the cause of so much land beinjg thrown open for sale.

articleText:
THE WARWICK-POSTMASTER AND THE

" NORTH AUSTRALIAN."

To the Editor Of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,—I was much astonished on perusal of the North Australian of the 21st inst., to find some strong reflections on the management of the Post- office in this town, of which I have the honor to be Postmaster : wherein the Editor of that journal, on the authority of "a letter received from a re-

sident in Warwick," and which he considers unne- cessary to publish, thereby inferring that the charges contained in it are so generally known and acknowledged, as to render such a step super- fluous. He then proceeds to make a few sage re- marks, intended doubtless to reflect on my cha- racter and position, and with a view of bringing me into public ridicule.

The charges said to be contained in the letter I shall be ready to answer publicly on the publi- cation of the same : but until such a step is taken, I shall deem it unworthy my notice.

I have all due respect for the Press as a cor- rector of the abuses which may, and doubtless do exist in society ; still I consider it derogatory to the dignity of the editor of a respectable journal to descend to personal attacks on any one ; and in his capacity of public censor, to convict, without either publishing the charge against, or the de-

fence of,

Your obedient servant,

JONATHAN HARRIS.

Post-office, Warwick, 24th April, 1857.

articleText:
THE RECENT DECISION UNDER THE

SCAB ACT.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR, —Having been recently convicted and fined

under the above Act, allow me to make a few re- marks connected with the subject.

I wll not here argue on the justice of the deci- ion against me as the culpable party; but I merely wish to give an illustration of the old proverb " Prevention is better than cure." I therefore put it to you whether it would not be better calculated to promote the interest of a pastoral district like our own, if the Govornment

Inspector, living on the spot, and knowing the law on the subject, charged with and well paid

for a duty so fraught with influence for the weal or woe of the said district, were to board every steamer that arrives coastwise, and find out if any sheep had arrived, and not wait till his leisurely and perhaps accidental perusal of the local journal had, as it did on this occasion, made him acquainted with the settlers' peril. Seeing

that in the mean time, in default of his so doing,

any persons equally ignorant with myself of the law, and even (which is easy) more connected with the sheep than I was, may have inflicted more injury on the district than seven or fourteen

years' salary to the Government Inspector might suffice to cover. I have no personal feeling in making these re-

marks, and merely throw out the suggestion from a wish that no harm may in future befall the colony in whose prosperity I myself am so much concerned. I am, Sir, Your obedient humble servant,

NEHEMIAH BARTLEY.

Brisbane, July 30th, 1837.

-

Tun news received "by every .«uccesMvo ,mail from the JJhitcd* States of America

is of'a character to impress the frieuds of freedom and of representativo institutions with very unpleasant feelings and fore- bodings. The enslaved peoples of Europe have been long accustomed to look to America as a place where the principles of civil equality were fully recognised, and where they might find refuge from the despotism of their rulers; and to the United States the advocate of represen- tative institutions lias always pointed for an illustration of his arguments. And there is no doubt that the example of the American Republic has done much to promote the cause of liberal institutions in imuy pM'ts of the world. Hut we have always felt the hitter taunt thrown out by the opponents of human progres- sion, thufc the nation which professed to he the freest on earth was also the foremost in its fmpport of slavery._ ^Yll.Uo-"£ ",;!. cannot l»«t vogi'ot that its pro-slavery laws should have afforded such a ready handle to the friends of despotism. With jio slaves in the United States, there would probably at present be no Bomba in Naples, no irai tor on the throne of i France, and no absolute monarch in Vienna and other of the capitals of Eu- rope. The maintenance of slavery in its worst form by a people claiming to be tho greatest and freest " in all creation" has done much to retard _ the fuller de- velopment of free institutions in Europe.

But the violation of tho laws of right and justice is as certain to be avenged as is tliß infringement of the more palpable

laws of nature ; and the retribution is j ! now beginning to be felt hy the promoters ! and abettors of slavery. The Southern

States, in their maintenance and exten- sion of slavery, and tho Northern, in their too ready acquiescence with the wishes and demands of the former, have broken every law, human and divine; and we see some of the effects of this

violation in the complications which now , surround the government of the country, and in the low state of morality which prevails in the States inoi'c subject to slavery influences. We see the angriest contention ia both branches of the Legis- lature, the legislative and executive powers in fierce antagonism, and civil war actually raging among the people.

In the Southern and slave-holding States | of the Union morality is at the lotvest ebb ; and from the highest to the lowest its claims seem almost totally repudiated. The bowie-knife and the revolver ave used ou the most trifling occasions; drinking, and gambling, and fighting ave the regular amusements of the people.

In the recent doings in Kansas wo have an illustration of the unfortunate

condition of the Union. The demon-j like conduct of the -pro-slayery party jn I

thoir endeavours - to foist slave institu-1

tions upon the new territory, has been | ably delineated by T. H. Gladstone, Esq., vwho visited the locality in question in t^o month of May last, and who gives the result of his observations in a letter publish^ in the 7.Hmes of the 10th Oc tober. til the course of his travels, he got iiito the company of some of the pro slavery party oil board of ono of the Missouri steamers. île has preserved a few specimens of their conversation, which will perhaps go further than anythiu^ clso to show the demoralising influence of the slave system. "Let me, ns one that knows the ways of the >' people hore, givo you n word of caution, which ii yon may find useful, now that you'ro setting foot s in these parts. Don't lot a sonl of them know

that you'ro an Englishman. Should it got out, it's just as much ns your life is worth, mind that. - That's the state we're in just now, nil alongside

of that careel slavery question. If }ou sav you'io nil Unglishman it ali the same as being a Yankee; not a bit better. And you know the Jaw there a Yankee is a nuisance, and nuisances must bo - abolished. That's what they all say there. So

you mind; and don't forget what I say.

At a hotel in Learenworth, where Mr. Gladstone remained a few clays, similar language to that which ho witnessed on board the steamer was common. Ho says :

"Sick of honringsuch oppression-*;, filled with the - vilest oaths, I went into the office of the hotel and

sat down on a vacant chair to meditate and to ob- serve. In the corner of the room, in place of trunks and travelling bags, were rifles and double . barrels, dirks, and ¡.ticks of that weight and c.i _ libre which only a Western Atneiienn thinks of ~ carrying. The clerk and the persons passing in

and out had nothing to speak ol but "the light = in¿'." On the counter were papers, heading their

columns with tho words-"War to the knife." Everything around was suggestive of warfare and e bloodshed. Iliad sat for a Yew minutes, when there a entered a mau-¡v Southerner by his very'looks.' jP " Hand mo a pair out ol' them hundred pistols I

left nilli ion, Captain," were the words which la with a slow drawling voice, ho addressed to the i- clerk nt the counter. Then, glancing his cool e eyo nt mo and another in the room, and feol . g ifig probably that wo might desire an oxplana l tion, he slowly added -"I've just had a turn ¡s down here with a d-d Free-soilcr." Wo still I) looked injuiringly, and ns ho adjusted his ]>is n tols in his bdt he proceeded for our satisfaction e -"I'd got nothing with mo. I didn't ought to

have left those here tools behind this morning,

anyhow. Idid'nt le.ne him though till I made 'r him give in. Ile name out with his cursed aboli d tionisin. I settled him, though, mighty quick. e I just put my hand behind me, liko this, pietend

ing I had got my pistols with nii ; mid so with, my hand upon them, us ho reckoned, ho did'nt s itimJ nut long. But 1 felt mighty qncei, I tell e you. Still I was'nt goin' to stand his sarcy talk, li in course ; so I just shut him up mighty quick."

By lhislimethopistolsworoadjusted,aiidasho walk oil out their valiant wearear continued a kind of so 0 liloquy,-"Well, I reckon I'm Iked now ; They it wont bj so sarcj willi their talk now that I've 1 £!:?.:A'vi'D-fiv.'iv io j-J-,1- .i-nu\Vö.x^nVmecT.n'

y _ These illustrations o'f tho state of feel y ing and morals among the pro-slavery li Party> while they may cause regret, can e not surprise us. Slavery, wherever in v troduced, has a deteriorating influence f on all who come in contact with it in any a way. When the first principle of Chris . tinnity, which teaches us to do to others

Jas we should be done to, is .forgotten, 3 there is uo length to which man may not . proceed. The feelings both of master . and slave become blunted with the com-

mon use of the lash ; aud treating the fc black mau as a proper object for the ex " ercise of his cruelty, the slave-owner very 3 soon comes to regard his white brother ; in the same light, and when he has it in ' his power, to resort to the same mode of 5 treatment; hence the frequent use of the 1 revolver and bowie-knife, and the harden-

ed state of feeling, and indifference to the claims of morality, so generally manifest j ed in the Southern States of the Union.

' It is difficult to foresee what may be

' the result of the present complication of '

United States affairs. Probably matters

may be compromised for a while between , the two great piirties ; but wo cannot be-

lieve that peace can be long maintained i while such an institution as slavery is ! allowed to exist. We would not bo sur- ( prised to see a disruption iu the Union . itself, though such a result would be de- < precated by nearly every American. ' But this is an extreme view. Who j

know3 but that the cultivation of cotton *

in India, Australia, Algeria, &e., may be -J the destinod means of destroying slavery ? in the States, by the removal of the J monopoly they have enjoyed, and by 'j making the employment of slave labor ii unprofitable? The appeal to the pocket h

is generally the most forcible in human J

affairs. j.

articleText:
OVERLOADING OUR STEAMERS.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIB,-It is nt all times a most unpleasant duty to censure our friends for their faults. But we must not forget our duty on that account. The matter I wish to bring beforo the public, through the "medium of your columns, is one involving very sar'.ous consequences, and which carno under my notice on Wednesday last.

. Happening to bavo some business transaction with Sydney, I was on board the Yarra Yarra just before she sailed, when I was astonished to find . the deck crowded up with cargo to such an extent .that the communication between the fore and after part of the vessel was almost entirely stop- ped-there being barely room for a mau to squeeze himself past, between tho paddle-box and the cargo. And as if the steamer authorities really desired the loss of their vessel, there were not loss than six bales of wool placed upon the bridge, close to tho paddle-boxes, and tovered over loosely -with-a-tarpanlir-,. In addition to all this tlioro - were, ten ,or eloven _bales in tho fore cabin,' the

smell and heat from which was unbearable ; and yet the steerage passengers had to put up with it or remain on desk. If this is rot a gross injus- tice to the poor creatures who aro compelled by necessity to travel, in this way, I should like to

know what elso to call it ?

Now, Sir, will it be believed that this vessel had on her deck about sixty bales of wool, and with ? what was on the bridge,- and in the fore cabin,

ranking a total ofsovonty-seven bales-justhalf a . cargo for tho Boomerang.

To say nothing of tho illegality of taking deck cargo (for you must bear in mind that it is a breach of the Navigation Laws) there can be no two opinions about the danger of it. Just think of this overloaded steamer in such weather as she

had to contend against on tbo night when the ill fated Dunbar was lost. It was fortunate for the Yarra Yarra that sho had no cargo on deck on that eventful night, but as it was, she rolled and pitched to such an extent that the stoutest heart on board was filled with anxiety, and the wonder was that she escaped without accident. Who can

duubt tbo result if she encounters such weather

on her passage to Sydney ? It makes one shudder at the thought of it.

It will no doubt be snid that if there was any

danger apprehended the wool would be thrown overboard. But, Sir, if the wool once got wet it would defy all tho ollbrts that could be made to get a bato of it from under the bridge. It took five men with levers to jam it into it» place when dry and the vessel steady-but how many men would it take to get it out when wot and tho ves- sel rolling about, and no room for the men to

work?

It seems to be .the feverish anxiety of the cap- tain to see how many bales of wool he can cram into his vessel ; and the feat of landing four hundred undumped bales on the wharf at Sydney would be greater to bim, than " beating ten Knaves in Lincoln Green,"-was to thegreat Falstaff.

I trust, sir, some restraint will be put upon these dangerous efforts; aud that a greater re " gard to human life will be enforced by those

whose duty it is to see to these matters.

I remain Sir,

Your obedient servant

A LOOKER ON'

articleText:
NAVIGATION OF THE RIVERS BRISBANE

AND BREMER.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sin,-As the navigation of these rivers aro greatly impeded by the number of land slips, and tha banks mid shoals filling up various portions of the original channels, I think you will agree with me thnt it is lime tho inhabitants of Brisbane and Ipswich were bestirring themselves in the import- ant tvoik of olearing tho obstructions of navigation between Bi-isbnno and Ipswich. There is now a good opportunity for the Government to purchase un oxeeliont dredging machine, well adapted for the clearing and deepening of these rivers, and can be pin chased at a moderate price. I may also state, that tho largo punt now attached to tho South Brisbane ferry, but which is never used, as it is not suited for that purpose, is well adapted for tho dredging machine ; two or three lighters would also bo required, which could be builtJiero at a trifling expense. Two experienced practical

men with a sufficient number of laborers to work

the lighters, would be all that is required for the works to be performod by tho machine. Y'ou may tell tho Government authorities that we can dis-

penso with tho services of the theoretical " surveyors, such as tve had in survoyin<r tho river bar, for it trns nothing moro nor less than a waste of publio money. All that is wanted is the machine, and men that know how to work it. This machine would lift 100 tons a day when at work. In forming or de-epeninir channels through shoal parts, great care should he taken in examining the sot of the tides ; following their vurious nulles from right to left banks, and particular at- tention should be paid in ilopositing the stuff from the lighters, lifted by the machino. lu almost every reach there aro suitable places for discharg- ing tho lighters, which could be pointed out by fixing temporary beacons at low u'ntor, always taking caro that the proper places are where tho least tidoway or currout is. I am informed that Captain Towns is authorised to sell the Steam Dredge to tho Government for tho clearing of tho Brisbane and Bremer rivers. The people of Bris- bane mid Ipswich should stand firm togother, and with one voice demand of the Government to pub this work in immediate oxecutiou. There is no- thing to stop them from going on with the work immediately.

I am, Sir,

You« obediently,

A SUBSCRIBER.

articleText:
THE SUPPLY OF WATER.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,-Pray do sympathise with the many of your fellon-townspeople who have to drink the water from the pond, called a Reservoir, in North Bris bane . The color, taste, and smell, of that water prove it utterly unfit for use; it contains animal and vegetable substances in a state of putrifac tion, and is totallv unfit for use without filtering, but, as many of the inhabitants have no conveni-

ence for putting their drink through this process, they use it as it comes to them. The consequence will be detrimental to health, probably productive of disease. We have read of epidemic colic being generated by bad water, and also the deformity called Derbyshire-neck : and we find that it is the generally received opinion that the Cumberland disease among cattle rose from a deficiency in the quantity as well as quality of the water to which

such cattle had access.

But were it ever so pure, the quantity of water contained in the Reservoir, or duck nursery, at the bottom of the Windmill hill, is far too limited for so many inhabitants as Bnsbane now contains, as well as cattle and horses. Any person may satisfy himself on this point who will view the pool, with the three-rail fence dividing the water without from the water within, such fence answering no apparent purpose save that the top-rail serves for a resting place for the manv families of ducks, while they are finishing their toilets.

Hoping that you will call attention to this matter,

I remain, Sir, yours &c.

A CITIZEN.

Brisbane, 16th September.

articleText:
THE LADEIS' EVENING PARTY. I

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier. I

Sin,-A lottor signed " A Churohman" having appeared in last Saturday's Courier, which is liable to injure and mislead, I trust you will allow mo, through tho medium of your paper, to moko a few observations with regard to it.

Somo ladies, bolioving that an Infant School was rcriiuicd, (tho Mastor of tho Church of Eng- land School having frequently stated that it was

injurious to tho interests of the sohool to have i childron of nil ages mixed together), deoidod that I they vvould try and obtain funds for that object I by giving a party, nut! requiring their friouda who I

' U » ' T. - ?

came to it to contribute so muoh- for that objeot Those who" uro interested in the mutter have cer- tainly used considerable activity, aild_ many also who are not the promoters have promised to con- tribute liberally to the entertainment; but the ladies havo to thank the Churchman for making it n publio ball. Such publicity, as has beon given to it, was, I fancy, never contemplated by them.

Instead;of the brass band having been engaged, Mr. Digglos will, I beliovc, play for the amuse- ment ol' tho party " gratuitously."

The Minister of our Church was not asked to support the party, neither is ho ono of tho pro- moters of it. Peihaps he may agree with " A Churchman" in thinking tho frequenting of a i ball-room no sin ; and it so, in what way does the ' obtaining money by n dance differ from obtaining . monoy by a bazaar? (I do not say a lottery or ' rallie, for very many would condemn thoso who would not condemn dancing or a bazaar.) But perhaps the " Chuiclnnan" will say, 1 neither like nails nor bazaars, I liko some other wa}'of collect- ing monoy, I have conscientious objections to both. Of course then, ho does perfectly right in not countenancing them, But does his objection jus- tify him in holding up to public censure his Minis- ter aud some members of his Church, who, ha ac- knowledges, are zealous in the cause of religion ? Who made him a judge ?

Might not snob a letter load some enemies of our Church to avail themselves of it, and try mid draw away-some of hör mo3t seiiouä if not most enlightened members ?

Allowing that theso zealous ladios are not not- ing for the best : allowing that our Minister may not be very anxious to put down what may bo considered by some too mueh gaiety, vet does " charity" lead us to publicly condemn tiioso who are allowed to ho actuated by a dosiro to do good, even if, in our opinion, the moans cannot be en- tirely justified î

The mission of tho Church is no doubt to oppose worldliness, but its objeot also ought to be lo pro- mote "chai ¡ty."

"A Churchman" stales his willingness to con- tribute. Not knowing who that individual may be, it is out of my power to call up3n him and nsk bim for a subscription towaids tho Infant School. But I have no doubt that those who are anxious to obtain money for its oroction by the means of a ball, will not object to accept his offer ing_and any he may bo able to collect; and per- haps, if he uso as much zeal as tho laJies, he may collect' moro, and thus prove practically the su- periority of his plan ovor theirs.

If the means used by the Indies were positively sinful, in that case, most would admit, that oppo- sition would be justifiable, huton no other grounds can 1 understand tho objection to receiving tho monoy obtained by them for tho promotion of a charitable object.

Would1" A Churchman" rofuso to accept £100 from a publican for ohnritablo purposes, because a portion of that money liad been obtained by tho sale of intoxicating di inks '!

I do not allow that the end justifies the means.

But I. do think that ohuichmen would consult better for tho interests of thoir Church and truo religion, if thoy woro not so willing, whenevor an opportunity occurs, to publicly censuro and con- demn whatever may not exactly meet with their approval. ,

I am, Sir,

» ' > ' Your obediont servant,

One who is also a

CHURCHMAN.

22nd.July,,(1.857. ? .. .
