articleText:
AUDI ALTERAS! PARTEI!.

THE CLAIMS OF THE ABORIGINES.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier,

Sin,-In your impression of last weok I was much pleased with the zeal ovinced by Humanitas, in whioh ho advocates tho rights and olnims of the aborigines. During the few weeks I havo resided in this town, \ havo had frequent opportunities of conversing with the nativos, tho majority of whom I have found willing nnd anxious to ncquiro a de- gree of that knowledge which weare possosse'j, both Hplrilual and temporal ; and I should be most happy to assist llnnianitas in any way by which our sabio brothron, the wandoring sons "of this fruitful land, moy bo benafilted. It will'scarcely bo denied that as nn enlightened and Christian people) wo are at least bound to do to the ignorait opprosbed inhabitants of theso lands that which we should, in similar circumstnnooB, dobiro lo be done to. But boyond. tho obligation of comnion honesty wo aro bound, l-,y two considerations--^ First, thal of tho ability which wo possess to con- loi- upon thom thô most important bonofits » aud, secondly, tlit\t of their inability to resist any on cronchments, however unjust, howevor misohiuvous, which tlio^uiouUlsns' a body arc disposed to make. 'i'l'.S atrocities and cnu'ltios porpolratcd, the in- justice, tho sufferings, and tho loss of life which have resulted to the aborigines, and the stain upon our national honor, uro loo well known to require any ÎJiigtlu'iiod doini!. That those eryhig evils havo mainly arisen from the aUsoucu of au cTifioionfc mode of diffusing religions knowlodgo und civiJiüa. Mun uiiiong-t Mihi people, who wo by bivth-y'mht pttUro'B IwtlftQf tWWU YTC iljhijblt, Tb,6. CO1Q,

nists"ïhould have been compelled to raspect the rights of the natural riihnbitnnts, and to concilint their good-will, instead of which, cruelty, tyranny, and oppression, have been the result, loading- to tho ivorst species of despotism, nliko degrading" to tho oppressor and the oppressed. Hard indeed is the lotof the poor untutored aboriginal inhabit- ant; suddenly invaded by a race of mon whose very name and existence in ninny cases wore pre- viously unknown, hois and has'bean hunted as a wild beast, driven from his fatherland, and obliged to seek among a warlike mid perhaps hostile tribe, that home which the civilized usurper denies him, until he finds refuge in death by the hands of his enemies, or in misery pines away his existence. Is ho permitted to remain near tho white man, the picture is still moro melanolioly ; where is he on the Sabbath, surely'no man careth for his BOUI'S future welfare ; ho is treated as a creature of inferior nature, unable to copo with civilized habits ; without property, no respect is paid to him ; without knowledge, ho becomes the dupe of his civilized neighbor. Is he wronged, lie has no redress : without experience in our laws and customs he is expected, as Humanitas justly observes, at once to conform or to suffer punish- ment. '-Where aro his Christian brethren, who have professed to civilize him? Have you not stood oy with heartless complacency viowing him clothe himself with the vices of civilized society Î Is this Christianity 1 Is this civilization ? For- bid it, justice, truth, humanity, forbid' it. Our duty is to enlighten thoir minds by reason, and not lo darken their understanding by deception or mystification ; to help and not to oppress ; to hold out the hand of enanty and Christian for- bearance, leniency to thoir faults, allowance for their prejudices, and liberality for their good deeds, should be our object. Wo should then arouse nnd enlist their good feelings, which would infallibly lead them to bo moral, intelligent, peaceful, and happy, attached friends and faithful allies. k If to these objects wa add tho ennobling desire' of spreading civilization by means of the diffusion of intelligence, of the useful arts and sciences, of religion, virtue, and morality, of raising tho character of the aborigines in tho scale of hu- manity, and teaching him to become ns one of ns. To obtain so great an object we must be simple and true in our communications mid deal- ings with them, be candid and open, or wo shall foster Suspicion. Wo must improve their physi-

cal habits by creating physical wants, while prac- j f tica! utility Bhould be a leading object in view, t Peace .must be our motto ; the olive-branch our weapon ; the wheat-sheaf our offering ; and the

Bible the code from which to frame our laws.

Experionco tolls us that the most forocious ani- mals may be oharmed and tamed hy the genius of man without force or violence. If this can be effected with mere bruto instinct, what may we not expeot to do with men by the effect of reason. If brutes with mero instinct can be brought to love man and obey him, how much more shall untutored minds be influenced by superior intelli- gence. It is the universal law, that intelligence, which is the offspring of truth, must prevail. How soon, how far, it shall prevail over these ex- tensive regions where civilization and religion bave yet to make their way to tho gradual ex- tinction of savage barbarism, cruelty, oppression, famine, and bloodshed : nnd by turning tho sword into the ploughshare,and tho spear into the prun- ing hook, tend to the gradual spread of intelli- gence, virtue, freedom, peaco, good-will, and civilization, in this new world called into exist- ence by European enterprise and philanthropy, depends much on the means made use of, and the method of using such means. With a view to permanent good being done, I would suggest that manual labor schools bo provided, upon the solf supporting principio as far as practicnblo. That such schools shall embrace instruction in agricul- ture and farming, the breeding nnd caro of ani- mals, the oui turo of some staple produce of tho country, the various useful mechanical arts mid handicraft occupations, including tho manufacturo of simple implements of husbandry, the construc- tion of farms and other useful buildings.

Trusting that the good wishos and efforts of all friends to this cause may bo crowned with success,

I remain, yours, ftc.,

B. FAWCETT, ti

c1

Stn,-Having been present ata meeting held this otoning in the School of Arts, for the purpose of taking into considération the' conduct of the Committee appointed by theGoverment Resident, for the expenditure of the sum of f}000 of publio money voted for the repairs of our,streets, I un- derstand that the Government Resident had the option of eithei- calling a meeting of the inhabit- ants, or ofnominating. -lind ha (the Govcrriincnt Uesideiit) adopted the popular Rystem of culling the inhabitants together, in'order to take their opinions how the money oould bo best spent, in- stead of chosing the system of nomination, so' long and so righteously condemned, such a'conrso would havo met the approbation of the publier taken nil lesponsibility off his shoulders, and ?would also liaye deprived the enemies lo Separation ' fiom saying that if we could uut even expend the small sum of, £2000 without a quarrel, wo cer-

articleText:
AUDI ALTERAM PARTEN.

DEFAMATORY ARTICLES.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,-In your issue of the 28th ult. appeared a paragraph headed "Peter Gentle again," relative to a horse which l am charged with taking for- cibly from a traveller in Ipswich, and which ¡f uncontradicted is calculated to do me considerable injury. There is always two versions of a story, and one is all very well until the other is heard. The horse alluded to I received from Mr. Thos. Price, of Drayton Swamp, in January last, and while staying at Mr. Prior's, at Little Ipswich, was stolen from the door of his house. The horse with the requisite descriptions was duly advertised in the columns of the North Australian, and a reward of five pounds for the conviction of the thief. Nothing was heard of the horse until Sunday, Feb. 22, I observed him in the possession of a ticket-of leave holder, not a traveller, who, when informed of the circumstances of the horse being stolen, quietly gave it up. The district constable of Ips- wich witnessing the whole transaction. Now, Sir, I should like to know what is irregular, dishonest, arbitary. or contrary to law, in the above proceed- ing? Had I have given the traveller in charge for having stolen property in his possession, and sent him to the place from whence he came, what would your Ipswich correspondent have said? I leave him to reply.

With regard to his insulting inuendo about the mail contracts, I will observe, that I am in a posi- tion to prove, that I am as worthy of receiving and as of capable of performing the contracts, for the conveyance of the mails as any man in Ips- wich or Drayton. When complaints are made of the irregular delivery of the mail or of letters being purloined from the mail bags, will be the proper and legitimate time for your correspondent to call in question tho "choice selection of the government." To wantonly injure a working man through the columns of the Press as your correspondent has done, to screen an intimate ac- quaintance, is the very height of injustice, and I trust to your good sense and better judgment not to recognize or tolerate it. Trusting to your sense of honor to insert the above,

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

PETER GENTLE.

Drayton, March 8, 1857.
heading: AUDI ALTERAM PARTEM. DEFAMATORY ARTICLES. To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

articleText:
THE STREIiTS OF SOUTH BRISBANE.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier. I e

SIR,-I would avail myself of the medium of you valuable journal to call attention to the disgrace- ful state in which Stunley-street,' South Brisbane, has been left by the contractor for several week?, past. The greater portion of the street has been formed, nnd in the centre a Bingle layer of stones, about twelve or fourteen feet wide, has been placed, plenty of which are as large as a brick, and some even larger ; in fact, if the wheelwrights and blacksmiths lind formed a " secret associa- tion" for tho speedy destruction of drays and , horse-shoes, they emild not possibly have hit upon

a better plan than that so disinterestedly adopted by our worthy contractor.

But what I in common with other inhabitants of this neghnted locality have principally to com- plain of is, that the contractor ¡sallowed to with- draw his men to Ipswich before ho had finished hi.s work here, such ns it i«, .-everal bundled feet remaining to be formed and metalled. And I cer- tainly consider the gentleman, who ncceptcd the olfico of superintending the expenditure of the money devoted to South Brisbane, bus neglected his trust, in not forcing a tul'filment of Um cou-' tract entered into by Mr. B. Fawcett. It is no answer to lay ho made a bad bargain, and tnerefnre wo must no1; bo hard upon him, that is his (the contractor's) business, not ours. If the enso had been the other way, and he lind netted a handsome profit, I apprehend he ivonl.l not have declined fiocketing.it, therefore he should be held

to his contract.

I have, been reluctantly compelled to troublo you with this, asno abler pen seemed inclined to bring it beforo.tho public, and hoping that our

street commissioner will at on co enforce the com- pletion of the conti act

I remain,

Yours obediently,

SOUTH BRISBANE.

Nov. 20,1857.

P.S.- 1 would just draw the attention of our commissioner to the desirability of expending some poition of the funds remaining to tho ciudit of South Brisbane, in employing a couple of men, for two or three weeks, in clearing away the stumps that obstruct the road, after you pass Mr. Áppel's residence, that being the point at which (if I um rightly informed) the present contract terminates, sufficiently nido to alli.w of drays passing, each other ; and also to dig n surface drain ulong the upper aide, to curry the water off, and tims obviato the necessity for thoso natural watorcoinsps, some two or three feet deep, with which it is interspersed, to the imminent peril of

life and limb.

articleText:
THE

SATURDAY, 'OCTOBER 3, 1857.

THE PUBLIC DEBT.

WE are enabled to state, -apon good au- thority, that it' is intended so soo«, as the Bill" for the division of the public dobt between New South Wales and Moreton Bay shall have been introduced into Par- liament, to move to have it referred to a Select Committee of the House, with a view to its details being thoroughly sifted. The evidence of gentlemen officially con- nected with this district for years past, will then be submitted to the Committee, in order that Parliament may be fully informed before they pass the measure, and in the hope that the people of More- ton Bay may be saved an ultimate resort to her Majesty's Government for justice. We hope that the evidence, and the re- port of the Committee, will bo appended to the enactment/ should the Bill pass into law ; so that in the event of our being compelled to dispute the decision of the Colonial Parliament, the expense and de- lay of taking evidence in England may be

avoided. The Home Government will thus bo furnished with the moans of ascertain- ing whether the Bill is based upon sub- stantial justice, and the knowledge that such evidence must come before her Ma- jesty's advisers, may operate as « salu- tary check in the Councils of New South Wales when dealing with this important

measure.

We observe an article in the Herald on the publio burdens in connection with the new oolony-in which it is urged that the lands of the two colonies should bo a joint security for the publio debt to the Debenture holders. W e have already urged reasons for our position that the territory and future revenue of New South Wales should form the security for those advances. The position assumed by the Herald would require this colony to se curej jointly of course with our neighbor, the .whole public burden, which on the 31st Dec., 1856, amounted to £2,009,400. We shewed in our issue of Sept. 5, that probably not moro than £60,000 of this sum could bo fairly charged against the new colony. To this must be added the recent advances for publio works in this district. Against the total so chargeable

wo shall have to deduct the handsome sums received from the sales of our lands the duties received at Sydney and More- ton Bay upon articles imported for these

districts-besides the assessments on stock -rents of runs-and other sources of re- venue. We have no doubt that should an equitable apportionment bo made, the uew oolouy will have a considerable ba- lance against its neighbor. Wc can hardly hope that the spoil of our noble province will be so easily relinquished The Herald distinetly intimates that an attompt will be made to saddle us with the railways, &c, on the plea that More- ton Bay was a party to the bargain-thal we have been engaged in a great io-part nery-und the loss must be eanally di- vided. The proportion of the debt for the railways, &o., is about one and a half million, which wo, as co-partners, are as- sumed to have generously handed to New South Wales for her special benefit !

Upon the admission of tho Herald it- self, " Moreton Bay derives no benefit from the railways already executed'; and except on special grounds ought not to bo called on to pay any part of the debt " The special grounds aro those already mentioned as arising from the new colony being a party to tho bargain. A glance at the items for whioh the public debt was contracted, will shew th.it the matter between the two colonies is not as the Herald puts it but that it may, with greater truth, be likened to a co-partnership in which one partner hav- ing the whole oj its funds in his hands unrighteously applies to his own use, partnership monies which he must in the day of reckoning refund out of his own fortune. In the article alluded to it ap poars that Moreton Bay is to havo a co parterny of loss, but not of profit, and New South Wales having .Bcctrred improvements, commercial faoilities, and large publio properties in the neighbourhood of her capital city, and in her own district, is to retain all prospectivo advantages and profits. And yet in taking the lion's share the Herald makes an impudent shew of" liberality," and tells us our neighbours " cannot af- ford to be extravagant in generosity." It is woll that the final sauction of tho division of the debt is reserved to lier Majesty, and that we are not left without appeal in the hands of Sir \V*M. DENISON, and his council. We are glad that our sug- gestion has boen attended to by requesting one of the members for the District to movo for a copy of the Governor-Gone ral's Despatch of the 5th February which contains the principle ou which ho has raoommended the division of the debt to bo made.
heading: THE Moreton Bay Courier. SATURDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1857. THE PUBLIC DEBT.
snippet: WE are enabled to state, upon good authority, that it is intended so soon as the Bill for the division of the public debt between New South Wales and Moreton

articleText:
ORIGINAL CORRESPONDENCE.

AUDI ALTERAM PARTEM.

BRISBANE HOSPITAL.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,—My letter, published in your last issue, I

find is not yet answered. There certainly is a communication addressed to the Editor of the Moreton Bay Free Press of last Wednesday, signed K. Cannan; it contains a large amount of personal abuse, and may serve as an exhibition of character, but beyond that it amounts to nothing. I shall have something to say about Dr. Cannan and the Hospital by-and-bye, but for the present will be corresponding with the Com- mittee of that Institution, whose province it will be to investigate the subject.

Thanking you for the space allowed in your valuable journal,

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

AMBROSE ELDRIDGE.
heading: ORIGINAL CORRESPONDENCE. AUDI ALTERAM PARTEM, BRISBANE HOSPITAL. To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

articleText:
ORIGINAL COBÄESPONDENCE.

no THR BESERVOrR.

0*p To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,- I must crave space in the columns of your ¡oumul t» dr.iw the attention of the authorities concerned to the present state of the Reset voir, and the quality of the water we are compelled to drink. It does not need iinv scientific knowledge to sec ut once the impurity of the water,-full of animal nnd .vegetable lifts and thicken«! hythe visits of e-ittle, horses, ducks, ¿to., stirring up the mud. and giving it a body.

This is really putting the brightest nido of the picture forward ; «s it only requires the visit of a few minutes toconviiioe anyone of the abominably filthy state of ibis Reservoir, from which the greater number of the inhabitants have to be supplied, and pay dear enough for it besides.

It is almost impossible that the Reservoir could have got to this state without the attention of the authorities concerned being called to it; mid if this is really so, ¡tis time tho inhabitants took the matter into their own hands, as they aro princi- pally interested.

The expense of putting it in a state of temporary repair and cleaning it, would nóteos' above £250; and this would get u* np to the time when we shall have the management of our affairs in our

own hands.

I confess, Sir, that I know but very little about tile proper plan of preserving water in a pure state. But I would suggest, thut in order to keep horses and cattle from stirring up our water into a puddle, the fence should be taken hack 10 feet from where it now stands ; which would place it on a high bank, and allow the ground beneath to retain its porosity and give a much greater quantity of wntor in the Reservoir. I would also extend the feinta about 100 feet in length, and tit the upper end of the Reservoir I would build a stone wall, to be three feet alio ve ordinary water mark. The wall »houlii huve a grating a little from the bottom, alni on the oiitsido I would place a bank of sand, so that the water would filter through it at all times except a flood.

In the Reservoir itself a deal of denning is ne- cessary, but which could be dona tit u trilling eos', onmpared with the importance it is to the health

of the inhabitants.

I believe, Sir, the supply of ivaler is the first thought of the founder of a now settlement, -and wax certainly one of tim first things that the late lamented Sir George Gipps gavo his attention to when ho visited this town immy years ago. It was then shown to be quite practicable to bring water from tho upper part of Breakfast Creek, in sufficient .quantities to supply our n-ante for oil ti-no to come. Tho present Reservoir was merely lonketl npiin as a temporary thing, till the neces siry arrangement» were made to bring the water

from liretikfost (!ieek.

I trust, Sir, this matter will not be allowed to rest an.v longer. There can be no two opinions, that the present state of our Reservoir is a dis- grace to the officials concerned, and a stigma upon the residents of Brisbane for allowing it to romain su long, without'some decisive steps boing taken Our population is fast increasing, and is certain to increase much faster; and it is a duty ne owe to ourselves and to' posterity to provide u good and sufficient supply of puro water. .

I am, Sir,

Yours obediently,

October 18th, 1857.

BUáBlr>3 BORE.

articleText:
íe -

ill THE

to .

SATURDAY, JANUARY 31, 1857.

THE LATE ASSIZES.

Li, In almost every epoch of British history, al and in overy clime where the Eng ,e lish flag proclaims the sovereignty of y British laws, the result of a gaol delivery

has been looked upon as a pretty sure

m te«fc of the social condition of the coiuiau ?n hity within the periphery where her

|® Majesty's representative periodically sits

j enthroned in ermine to dispense justice r : to all her lieges.

3 : How far the results of such an event. Ï? particularly in this colony, may he consi 10 dered a fair criterion is, after all, rather :- problematical. True it is, that in refer to ence to positive crime, cognizable by law, 11 the proceedings of an Assize Court may t afford pretty accurate data on which to a. found conclusions as to the "prosperity or

converse of a people. On the other hand R> there is an enormous amount of guilt ,g the real constituent of crime-with which a human legislation does not, in our days, m attempt to interfere, traceable in all the v_ ramifications and windings of society, j and perceptible to an observant eye in ,o every grado and station of life, from the If, lowosfc to the very highest in the commu k n'ity, but which although sufficiently ap J, parent to carry conviction as to its fear S; ful existenco and ultimate consequences, lo cannot bo ascertained with an accuracy '. and precision essential to statistical de _ velopmenfc. Hence it is that wo consider ,t a gaol delivery in this colony is not a s correct index as to the general state of 10 society, although in the old and thickly ,? populated countries of Europe, where tho j means of subsistence is much more difli ie cult to acquire than in a now country, » thinly inhabited, with ample employment '. for all-such an event may be regarded ¡j as a close approximation to accuracy.

"We have been led to these observations by a review of the proceedings of the last 1 Assize Court held in Brisbane. Of some

j thirteen or fourteen prisoners committed ii- for trial before a tribunal, holding in its n hands the issues of life and death, only u two convictions took place, namely, that "j of a hoary-headed miscreant for coramitt

r. ing an indecent assault upon a child of ; lo tender years, sentenced to three years' '

S> hard labour on tho roads, and a mau for

? stealing a saddle, sentenced to six months ' ,t in Darlinghurst Gaol. Now there must ' », be something radically defective in the ' <r law whioh permits such a state of things. ] y Tho number of acquittals at' the last As- i 0 sizes was proportionably great beyond ' n any thing wo remember, and after a care- { . ful perusal of the evidence adduced in ' l' eaoh case, we have reason to believe that i

every verdict of acquittal was founded on < ,. justice. < o The fact of so many acquittals at one '

Assize Court is, however, suggestive of ' ''. some weighty considerations. Why was ' '0 it that so many individuals had thus to j 0 run the gauntlet of a criminal ordeal ] li without the least chance of their being <

convicted? It may perhaps be eonsi- ! ' dered somewhat difficult to answer this [ I, question, but wo will try to solve it not- > - withstanding. In the first instance, the < h obvious incapacity of our local magis- 1 1 tracy conduces in a groat degree to suoh c

iniquitous results-for it is iniquitous c to consign an innocent person to such a s Draoonian course of procedure-and in \ r the next place the desire too often onter- s

tained by witnesses for a trip to the As- 3 ' sizes, at tho expense of the country (for s , unfortunately a groat many whose attend- ^ . ance is thus required, regard such an I t1 event more in the light of a pleasure ex- r J cursion, than as a solemn duty to tho ne- * , oused, thoir country, and their God,) but r . too frequently operate injurious to the $ i intorosts of parties criminally ac- c ' cused. It is a fearful thing for an in- l

dividual invostod with magisterial au- t . thority to prevent justice either by do- t

priving the laborer of hi« biro, or unjustly t' consigning a servant to the chances of a g criminal trial. Some there may bo found e who would justify such a course on tho I1 plea of necessity, taking 'for their guide ci the diabolical principle whioh enjoins d the oom mission of evil that good may tr on^uo. Novor was thcro a moie por- ni nickms doofrino, nor ouo'miro certain p to load to the most flagitious aotn. It Is c1 the very doctrino preached by lion1:?- ti Pimía whilst ho was desolating Fnuce T ( with horrors unparalleled in tho hibtory I U,

--t^-*--- I - '?.

r of crime. He nursed, ifc áurxng its ino 1 piont growth, clothed it with a panopl \ bearing the emblems of virtue, and fina ¡ ly produced it to tho gaze of the mult i tude ia a shape and form which led caj

tive the wisdom of a mighty nation ^ f enthroned the san».»-ary ¿em011 of' ;apin

> an - uiooaahed. It may he urged again! ï us that such results can never be pri t duced in a country under the sanction c j Briliôh laws with comparatively bo sma ä beginnings. To thi3 we answer, that 1 really wise and virtuous people will neve '» for a moment tolorato its existenc ¿ amongst them, and Wè trust that et 0 long therô will be such an arrangeraer ?? or rather reconstruction of the Magis » tract/ of tho Territory, and of the NoH) na ern Districts in particular, as will fe j over preclude the possibility of such

0 number of innocent persons being place v in such critical positions. We will tais lf one case tried at the last Circuit Cour t by way of illustrating our observation! d The man Larkin was tried for stealin o some property belonging to Wilmai ° Mctaggart Dorsay, on the 7th of Sej J( tember last. The prisoner was undefene - ed, and his Honor Mr. Justice MiLroR' ? said, in addressing the Jury, " that ther

was no evidence to fix the crime upoi the prisoner-the larceny might hav s been committed by some one else.

From the above quoted expressions c _ the Judge it is quite clear this mai _ should never have been committed, whic' _ would have saved the country consider

able expense. But WrtLiAM McTao sart Dorsay was, at the time whei Larkin wa3 committed, a Justice of th< Peace, one who for a long period stooi very prominent amongst the good people jj of Ipswich and its neighbourhood ; am 7 was celebrated for the peculiar manne _ in which ho administered law instead o

justice. His influence was sufficient ti have any man committed for trial, ni & matter how slight the accusation Wi - will just contrast the case of Larkii

with another case como to our knowledge s wherein the same honorable prosecutoi

bore a prominent part. A certain J.P. the owner of a Station some distance

'. from Ipswich, had an order presented ti f him, signed by his Overseer in favor ol » a man who had boen shearing for him, 3 for X11. The worthy in question gave . the man three pounds on account. Dur |. ing that night the man lost the order, s and although ho verified the loss he never 3 received a farthing of the balance, but

was threatened by the honest employer with such vengeance of the law as a mau '_ in his position could inflict, if he ever .' attempted to ask for any more money on

the order, thus depriviug the man of eight pounds of his hardaud honest earn- ings. We believe the vessel has already , spread her swelling sails, and is bearing

away from tho shores of Australia the [ man who has left behind bim such a bad . celebrity. Fortunately such instances k are of rather rare occurrence, although

we could mention another case during ! the late Assizes, where private influence

succeeded in placing aman upon his tiial J in order that ulterior views might more j effectually be carried into operation '" against him. The man was, however,

acquitted, to the chagrin and disappoint- ment of those who sought to gain by his conviction. Any system admitting of such tLings is a most nefarious one. Nothing can more strongly tond to bring . the whole administration of the law into , contempt than such instances as we have ' cited. In the eye of the law, up to trial

and conviction, all should stand upon nu . equal footing. After conviction, indeed, . it would not only be just but wise to vest , a discretionary power in the Exeoutive. , Many there aro, who from a combination I of circumstances over some of which they

possess no immediate control, are led to i a violation of the law. The young heart, , too often betrayed ft oin its sanctity, runs

riot amidst scenes of dissipation and [ vice, and tenders its devotion at polluted

shrines, yet the original germs of purity struggle with and obtain the mastery of , evil passions, and after ha\ ing undergone

the ordeal of suffering, emerge from the ' abominations of vice purified aud strength-

ened against tempation during all time. With such dispositions labouring under , the lash of penal coercion a nice judg-

ment and discrimination is essential. On the contrary, with those old and hardoned in crime, a course of discipline is necessary, which will, even by means of corporeal suffering, afford at least a guarantee to sooiety. The proper con- sideration of this subject will be of vital importance to the well-being of the new colony of Moreton Bay. As we remark- ed at the commencement of this article, there are other causes besides the direct ' commission of crime which bear upon the ! moral and social condition of our people,

and amongst them we may safely rank intemperance as the primary one. The evils springing from this baneful source are generally latent, working their way through every vein of society, eating intp the heart of the community like a deadly disease ; ulcerating all thats healthy in this life, and at the same timo carrying with it a damning sense of ini- quity which appals the spirit on its being summoned to " cross that bourn from whence no traveller returns." Such spots and blemishes in our social state are bo yond the control of human legislation, and require the strenuous offorts of Di- vinely appointed influeneo for their sup pressinn and total annihilation. Our own duties pertain moro immediately to the scouring a striot and impartial ad- ministration of justice to every indivi- dual in theso Dibtiicts, no matter what country or denomination ho may belong lo. And in passing wo would remark, that the first and most essential step to the .securing of this groat object will bo

the imparting to the ymth of the rising ] generation nsound moral cduoation, blend- I

ed with religion of cóurso, Snob a pre- j l'uninary would niako tho youth of the ( colony acquainted with the dutios which devolve upon them on their attaining

manhood, and onco thoy arc conscious , of the power which O-ol intended nun to t possess, there will bo little fear of any class of men, no matter what their posi

H ^n, lording it ovor thom in tyranny. " Tho pot feting of the lmman chavacuer a lo au extent within tho means of those T

who wish well to their species will bo a mighty task worthy of the greatest phi- lanthropists that ever graced this earth. We live in a ¿lorious land of almost boundless extéht and illimitable resour- ces, and with ^n hûuêst, industrious, and intelligent population, wó may acquire a greatness and renown which even on comparison with the mighty nations of the past, will astonish posterity. Never was there a country in the world where more depends on individual exertion than this. Every individual possesses within himself the power of contributing some- thing to the future prosperity of this

whether his native or adopted country.' The day is riot far distant; when every man should feel himself ready and pre- pared to act his part in the great and eventful crisis which will determine whe- ther we will at once be elevated into a happy and prosperous colony, oí proceed in a statu quo routine, recording from time to time the events incident to peri- odical gaol deliveries. The time is fast approaching xvhen the words of the im- mortal Nelson should sink deep in every heart, when he requested, in the name of his country, that " every man should do his duty " We trust to find that the

Northern Distiicts of Australia will not

be behind those -who responded so gal- lantly to that ever-mernorable call.

EXPORTS from the NORTHERN DISTRICTS.

On the 3rd of the present month we pub- lished a list of the exports from Bi isbane for the quarter ending 31st December, 1856, and in keeping with the promise

we made on that occasion we now furnish returns of the articles exported from the other ports of the Northern Districts for the same period. As we explained be- fore, we do not give these returns as ab- solutely correct, bub only as approximate ; for owing-to the indefinite mode in which some articles are entered in the manifests, there is considerable difficulty in arriving

at their value.

From Wide Bay the exports during the last quarter were as follows :?

articleText:
MR.'. HOOD'S CONVICT PETITION.

\To the Editor of Ute Moreton Bay Courier. . | ti

SIR,-^-I beg to annex an extract from a private letter of Mr. Riohardson|s, addressed to myself, and bearing date 19th instant, fiom which you will seo that the anti-tunspoitationists havo no cause to find fault with bim so far as he has had to do with Mr. Hood's Convict Petition.

Mr. Richardson says : "I saw in tho Courier a few remarks rplatiye to Mr. Hood's Convict Peti- tion, whioh it is desirable for mo to notice. Will you say to the Editor, that when Mr. Hoodmen tionnJ to mo ' tljui; a great many in the district wero willing to receive prisoners,' I at once told him he wr-s greatly mistaken ; and aided, that the very idea was ridiculous."

Will yon have the kindness to inseit this in your issue of Satnrday, in order that the public may seo that the views of Mr. Richardson on the above important subject remain unchangod.

I am, SV,

Your most obedient, servant,

D. R. SOMERSET. Ci

Brisbane, 28th May, 1857. JL

articleText:
MR. HOLT'S REQUISITION

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir.-I would claim a space in your valuable paper to contradict a gross falsehood which ap- pears in a requisition to Thomas Holt, Esq., now in course of signature, for the purpose, if possible, of doing away with the effect of the expression of public opinion at the meeting held in the School of Arts yesterday evening, convened by the sup- porters of that gentleman.

In the requisition referred to it is stated, "that the amendment was carried by newly arrived im- migrants, and boys taking a part in the meeting." Now, as chairman of that meeting, I felt it my duty to look closely to the show of hands, and from my long residence here and knowledge of most of the electors, I was able pretty nearly to tell the number of electors for and against the amendment, and I positively state, that about 80 electors were in favour of the amendment, and about 50 against it, or in favor of the original

motion.

As I am aware that some have been induced to sign the requisition without reading it, I write this to put people on their guard.

I am, Sir, your obedient servant,

WM. PETTIGREW.

Brisbane, 30th June, 1857.
heading: MR. HOLT'S REQUISITION. To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

articleText:
A BROKEN BRIDGE.

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

SIR,-The state of a dilapidated bridge over the Creek in Ed»vard-street, opposite tho »vorkshop of Mr. Jeays, builder, is certainly most dangerous to passengers ; and the moro so as a smooth in- cline leads the stranger on, unwary, dowh from Queen-street, right on to this trap. Several lesser Occidents have already ocourred to persons coming in the dark on the naked ribs of this rack. If

this place cannot bo made passable, let it be de- molished, so that it may no longer mislead tho traveller, »vhether cquestiian or pedestrian, or he a by-word and a derision to the visitors of our town. Your calling attention to the above »vill oblige the many inhabitants whoso business loads ihem through Edward-street, as »veil as

Your humble servant,

SPKING-HEEL-JACK.

North Brisbane, 15th Dec, 1857.

articleText:
BRISBANE OVER A VOLCANO !

To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.

Sir,—I hate "occurrences," whether "melan- choly," " singular," or " tragical," besides "hor- rible murders," "fearful massacres," and "catas- trophes." The latter I particularly detest, and to avert one, I hasten to communicate to my neighbors the terrible truth that—Brisbane slum- bers " from morn to noon, from noon to dewy eve," over a volcano! I am afraid the man who does the "melancholies" for some local sheet will soon find employment in recording the departure of her Majesty's postal establishment into the "dusky air!" A huge quantity of gunpowder has heeu deposited in a cottage close by that valuable de- partment—and we may daily expect to hear that "yesterday" has "lighted" her Majesty's ser- vants "the way to dusty death!" Our conster- nation would be great, on askiug for the English mail, to find "a beggarly account of empty boxes," but greater far would it be to find it recorded in a local print that "yesterday, about midday, the inmates of the Brisbane Post Office were discharg- ed into the circumambient atmosphere in a storm of gunpowder and dust. Nothing has since been heard of them. One gentleman was last seen gallantly riding a broomstick, with a basket on his arm, capable of holding provisions for a month, within which time it is supposed tho rate of his projection from this planet would enable him to reach the moon. As good frequently comes out of evil, it is supposed this involuntary journey will add greatly to our astronomical lore, and solve the problem "whether the moon is inhabit- ed?" if the gentleman in question—can get back. At the same time ascended an adjacent cottage, within which tho rich tones of a harmonium were pouriug forth the beautiful melody of ' Vilikins,' with a voice singing the words of Mrs. Leo Hunter's delightful ' lines on an expiring frog.' "

Will any one tell me how this gunpowder can be removed, and so many valuable lives saved ?

I hear it darkly hinted that the deposit of this combustible matter in tho main street forms part of a detestable conspiracy of red-tapists to "blow the ship up" on the accomplishment of Separa- tion! Fancy the horror of such an " occurrence" being chronicled ia the next edition of tho More- ton Bay Almanac.'

TIM BOBBIN.
heading: BRISBANE OVER A VOLCANO! To the Editor of the Moreton Bay Courier.
